Name: Alpha Epsilon Pi
Description: We are the Chi Alpha chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi at the University of California, Berkeley, founded in 1949 and re-founded in 1985. Since our founding, we have been growing constantly. Several brothers hold executive positions in many organizations on campus, including heavy involvement in the Jewish community: ASUC (UC Berkeley's Student Government), Jewish Student Union, TAMID Group, and many others. Along with Jewish leadership, we continue to further our relations with other houses in the Greek system, holding several joint social and philanthropic events on a weekly basis.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: We are the Chi Alpha chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi at the University of California, Berkeley, founded in 1949 and re-founded in 1985. We are developing future leadership for the Jewish community.

Name: Alpha Epsilon Zeta Fraternity, Inc.
Description: Founded in 2003, Alpha Epsilon Zeta (AEZ) is one of Cal's longest-standing student organizations, with over 160 active and alumni members placed at top firms including Apple, Google, Point72, Blackstone, Carlyle, Goldman Sachs, Moelis, and Lazard as well as elite graduate schools including MIT and Harvard Business School. AEZ is an undergraduate Professional Fraternity that differentiates itself through its multidisciplinary focus, with a proven track record of pushing students to success in whatever field they choose to pursue, whether it is medicine, technology, software engineering, finance, consulting, law, or startups. With weekly professional development training from university faculty and experts in industry, AEZ members are well-rounded and knowledgeable in a variety of fields. Our current brothers also hold leadership positions in a variety of other clubs on campus including Berkeley Investment Group, Berkeley Business Society, Berkeley AI Research (BAIR), Capital Investments at Berkeley, The Berkeley Group, Codeology, and more. Joining AEZ gives students the opportunities and network to explore their interests and further pursue them both in their time at Cal and in their careers. As a part of AEZ, brothers also have the opportunity to work in our elite consulting wing, Paradigm Consulting. Paradigm Consulting delivers top-notch, actionable solutions to the C-Suite of Fortune 500 companies. Past clients include Amazon Web Services, Johnson & Johnson, eBay, Bose, Roblox, and Visa. Come join us for our rush! Visit relevant links here: https:// linktr.ee/aezberkeley Any Questions? Please contact omawate1@berkeley.edu or sreekar_nagul@berkeley.edu.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Alpha Epsilon Zeta (AEZ) is an undergraduate professional Fraternity founded in 2003 with over 160 current members and alumni. AEZ differentiates itself with its multidisciplinary members, who push its members to success in every members desired field.

Name: Alpha Gamma Alpha Sorority
Description: The purpose of this organization is to unify students to work towards the advancement of Armenian causes, our college community, and the greater community, spread and further the Armenian culture and aid in Armenian causes, and guide fellow sorority members in academics, life decisions, and social relationships while building life-long ties.
Summary: Alpha Gamma Alpha is a sorority focused on the Armenian community, established at Berkeley in 2024.

Name: Alpha Gamma Omega
Description: Alpha Gamma Omega (ŒëŒìŒ© or "AGO") is a national, Christ-centered fraternity. It was founded in 1927 at UCLA, making it one of the oldest national fraternities in the United States that have retained its Christian values. ŒëŒìŒ© at UC Berkeley was founded in 1938 and is the second oldest chapter of ŒëŒìŒ©. There are currently eleven active chapters. ŒëŒìŒ© maintains a close relationship with its Christian "sister" sorority Alpha Delta Chi. ŒëŒìŒ© exists for the following reasons: 1. To win others to a saving knowledge of Jesus Christ 2. To promote Christian fellowship 3. To present Christian ideals in word and deed 4. To search reverently for the truth 5. To uphold the traditions and ideals of the university 6. And to deepen the spiritual lives of the members.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: We are UC Berkeley's only Christ-centered fraternity. We believe that we are to love & serve our university and Greek community as Jesus loved & served us.

Name: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc.
Description: Since its founding over a century ago, Alpha Kappa Alpha‚Äôs mission has been to cultivate and encourage high scholastic and ethical standards, to promote unity and friendship among college women, to study and help alleviate problems concerning girls and women in order to improve their social stature, to maintain a progressive interest in college life, and to be of ‚ÄúService to All Mankind.‚Äù Rho Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated was chartered at the University of California, Berkeley on August 21, 1921 by 6 women under the leadership of Soror Ida Louise Jackson. With the chartering of Rho Chapter, the landmark expansion of the sorority to the West Coast began. Rho women have been striving to fulfill Ida‚Äôs dream of nothing short of excellence for the chapter. The women of Rho exemplify the Alpha Kappa Alpha woman through their professional and personal development, community service, sisterhood, and commitment to academic excellence at Cal and beyond.
Categories: CalGreeks National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) Fraternities & Sororities
Summary: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated is an international service organization that was founded at Howard University in Washington, D.C. on January 15, 1908. It is the oldest Greek-lettered organization established by African American college women.

Name: alpha Kappa Delta Phi Sorority
Description: As of March 16, 2024, the University of California, Berkeley chapter of alpha Kappa Delta Phi International Sorority, Inc. was re-chartered. Founded in at Berkeley and Recognized by the College Panhellenic Association on February 7, 1990, aKDPhi continues its mission of creating a timeless bond through sisterhood for Asian-American women with over 60 active chapters across the United States and Canada. Our pillars of sisterhood, leadership, scholarship, Asian-Awareness, and service guide our members long after they graduate from college.
Categories: CalGreeks Multicultural Greek Council (MCGC) Fraternities & Sororities, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: alpha Kappa Delta Phi provides our members with lifelong empowerment, support, and friendships through sisterhood. We strive to live by our core values and advance our pillars - sisterhood, leadership, scholarship, service, and Asian-Awareness

Name: Alpha Nu Sigma
Description: Alpha Nu Sigma is the UC Berkeley chapter of the national nuclear engineering honors society. Students are invited to join based on academic merit starting their junior year of undergrad. Alpha Nu Sigma at Berkeley holds academic development sessions including practice presentation workshops for students who will present at academic conferences. We also work closely with the American Nuclear Society chapter at Berkeley to offer professional development opportunities.
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: ASUC Sponsored per SB 70 SP12 3/6/13

Name: Alpha Phi
Description: Hello everyone! If you want to know more about our chapter, please visit our Instagram @calalphaphi or feel free to reach out to our Chapter President, Jayla Jerro, at calalphaphipresident@gmail.com!
Categories: CalGreeks Panhellenic Council (PHC) Sororities

Name: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc.
Description: Alpha Phi Alpha (ŒëŒ¶Œë) is the first Black, inter-collegiate Greek-lettered fraternity. It was founded on December 4, 1906 at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. Its founders are known as the "Seven Jewels". It employs an icon from Ancient Egypt, the Great Sphinx of Giza, as its symbol. Its aims are "manly deeds, scholarship, and love for all mankind," and its motto is First of All, Servants of All, We Shall Transcend All. Alpha Phi Alpha evolved into primarily a service organization and provided leadership and service during the Great Depression, World Wars, and Civil Rights Movements. It addresses social issues such as apartheid, AIDS, urban housing, and other economic, cultural, and political issues of interest to people of color. The Martin Luther King, Jr. National Memorial and World Policy Council are programs of Alpha Phi Alpha. It also conducts philanthropic programming initiatives with March of Dimes, Head Start, Boy Scouts of America, and Big Brothers Big Sisters of America. Members of Alpha Phi Alpha include Jamaican Prime Minister Norman Manley, Nobel Prize winner Martin Luther King, Jr., Olympian Jesse Owens,Justice Thurgood Marshall, United Nations Ambassador Andrew Young, singer Lionel Richie and Atlanta mayor Maynard Jackson.
Categories: CalGreeks National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) Fraternities & Sororities
Summary: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. develops leaders, promotes brotherhood and academic excellence, while providing service and advocacy for our communities.

Name: Alpha Phi Omega
Description: Alpha Phi Omega is an international co-educational service fraternity founded on three principles: Leadership, Friendship, and Service (LFS) with over 85 years of college volunteerism, it is the largest fraternity in the world. Our chapter at UC Berkeley consists of over 100 active members who contribute thousands of hours of service annually. In addition to service, we have numerous events during the semester to promote friendship and brotherhood within the chapter and with chapters on other campuses.
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Alpha Phi Omega is an international co-ed service fraternity. The UC Berkeley Chapter is the largest network of leaders, friends, and volunteers at Cal!

Name: Alpha Rho Chi
Description: Alpha Rho Chi (APX) is UC Berkeley‚Äôs only professional co-ed fraternity dedicated to architecture and the allied arts. Despite our name, our brothers come from diverse backgrounds with some studying Architecture, and others studying Computer Science, Landscape Architecture, and Mechanical Engineering. Our brotherhood cultivates creative thinking and helps foster academic and professional growth, while our alumni network provides mentorship and extensive networking opportunities. We host professional and technical workshops, academic lectures on critical topics, and firm tours around the San Francisco Bay area.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: National Professional Fraternity for Architecture and the Allied Arts

Name: Alpha Sigma Phi
Description: Alpha Sigma Phi was founded on December 6th, 1845 at Yale University, and today stands strong as one of the fastest growing fraternities in the nation. Our fraternity stands on the pillars of Silence, Charity, Purity, Honor, and Patriotism, and our brothers strive to embrace these values in order To Better The Man and become Brothers For Life. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact us! Sean Collins, Chapter President Kyle Mak, Chapter Vice President
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: The home page for the Nu Chapter of Alpha Sigma Phi at UC Berkeley. Our goal as Alpha Sigs is to perpetually Better the Man through our values and actions.

Name: Alpha Tau Omega
Description: Established in 1865, Alpha Tau Omega was the first fraternity created after the Civil War. ATO was founded at the Virginia Military Institute by three cadets who sought to create a brotherhood based on eternal and immutable principles to unite men and heal the divisions caused by the war. ATO continues to reinforce these principles today, as embodied in the fraternity's creed: "To bind men together in a brotherhood based upon eternal and immutable principles, with a bond as strong as right itself and as lasting as humanity; to know no North, no South, no East, no West, but to know man as man, to teach that true men the world over should stand together and contend for supremacy of good over evil; to teach, not politics, but morals; to foster, not partisanship, but the recognition of true merit wherever found; to have no narrower limits within which to work together for the elevation of man than the outlines of the world: these were the thoughts and hopes uppermost in the minds of the founders of the Alpha Tau Omega Fraternity." The Gamma Iota Chapter of Alpha Tau Omega at UC Berkeley has received several awards ranging from academic to athletic successes. We provide an excellent way to delve into a rich life at Berkeley with socials with sororities, brotherhood retreats, philanthropy events, club nights, sporting nights, and a whole lot more. We have consistently successful intramural teams in basketball, football, soccer, softball, and volleyball. We live in the largest fraternity house on campus, which has been recently renovated and is well taken care of. Our brothers are diverse in their backgrounds and their studies - we are open to all who are charismatic and outgoing. Our alumni range in successes from former US Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens, the Vice President of Fox Sports, a major Hollywood talent agent, a world class anesthesiologist, a senior partner at Goldman Sachs (who was named by Haas as the Business Leader of the Year for 2014), and a former California superior court judge. One of ATO's most notable contributions to Cal is the original Oski. Oski was a bear cub who lived in the ATO house in 1923 until he grew too large and was moved to the Oakland Zoo.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: ...Founded at Berkeley on April 10, 1900, the Gamma Iota Chapter of Alpha Tau Omega strives to build character, academic success, and the ties of brotherhood amongst the men who join us.

Name: Alternative Breaks
Description: Since its founding in 2001, Alternative Breaks has offered students opportunities to connect with the greater community through meaningful service, education, and reflection during their academic breaks. Many participants return from their experiences with greater insight into a particular social justice issue and a deeper understanding of what it means to get involved in the community. This year, Alternative Breaks offers seven trips to different locations during the spring break, covering issues such as environmental justice, healthcare, immigration, housing insecurity, and more. Check out our website for full details! These student-led trips travel to various locations in California and Puerto Rico to deepen their understanding of the community and to share the knowledge gained on-site with the Berkeley community. Students not only participate in a week-long service trip but also enroll in a 2-unit spring DeCal course to explore various topics related to each social justice issue and engage in reflection both before and after the trip. Our Spring 2026 experiences include: Central Valley - Environmental & Farmworker Rights San Francisco - Economic Justice East Bay - Environmental & Food Justice South Bay -Public Health Puerto Rico - Sustainability San Diego - Immigration Rights Apply now! Link to Spring 2026 Participant Application! Infosession slides. Priority deadline: Friday, Oct 17th at 11:59pm Final deadline: Sunday, Oct 19th at 11:59pm
Categories: Berkeley Public Service Center Designated, ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Alternative Breaks offers service-learning trips during academic breaks for UC Berkeley students to explore a social justice issue through education, reflection, and immersion into an impacted community.

Name: Amanecer at Berkeley
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, LGBTQ+ Student Organizations
Summary: Amanecer is a club dedicated to creating a supportive environment for spanish speakers of different levels by encouraging, nourishing and forming connections as well as language goals for members.

Name: American Advertising Federation
Description: Better known as imagiCal, we are UC Berkeley‚Äôs award-winning creative strategy agency. Established in 1980, imagiCal is a Haas-sponsored organization, serving as Berkeley's chapter of the American Advertising Federation. We engage in real-world projects such as the National Student Advertising Competition, consulting projects, professional development events, and case workshops. We pride ourselves in our diverse community composed of students from various majors, passions, and backgrounds, allowing us to work cross-functionally across five departments: strategy, creative, public relations, media, and design, to elevate each other's ideas Interested in learning more? Visit our website here.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Better known as imagiCal, we are UC Berkeley‚Äôs award-winning creative strategy agency. Established in 1980, imagiCal is a Haas-sponsored organization, serving as Berkeley's chapter of the American Advertising Federation.

Name: American Cancer Society of Berkeley üíô
Description: We are UC Berkeley's official chapter of the American Cancer Society! Our goal is to bring the community together through cancer advocacy, research, fundraising, and patient support. Whether it's writing letters to Congressmen, hosting Relay For Life, or educating community members about preventing cancer, we are dedicated to ending cancer as we know it. Website: https://acsofberkeley.weebly.com
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: We encourage everyone to join our fight against cancer! Every cancer. Every life. üíú Website: https://acsofberkeley.weebly.com

Name: American Chemical Society at Berkeley Student Chapter
Description: ACS at Berkeley is the student chapter of the American Chemical Society here at UC Berkeley. We provide academic and professional resources for chemistry, chemical engineering, and chemical biology students through info-sessions, workshops, panels, networking events, and mentoring/advising. In addition, we also promote chemistry throughout our local community through our education and outreach efforts at local schools. Through these efforts, we hope to offer a network and community for students interested in chemistry and related fields. Our purpose:The goal of ACS@Berkeley is to improve the academic and professional development of all undergraduates while fostering a sense of community among its members. By making research and internship opportunities more accessible and providing its members with educational outreach opportunities and career advancement resources, ACS@Berkeley positions its members to be leaders at the forefront of their respective fields. Check out our website (acs.studentorg.berkeley.edu) or Instagram (@acsberkeley) for more information!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Professional Organization bridging the local and national ACS to the College of Chemistry and advancing professional and academic development. Visit our website for more information: acs.berkeley.edu

Name: American Constitution Society at Berkeley üíô
Description: ACS About Us The American Constitution Society (ACS) believes that law should be a force to improve the lives of all people. ACS works for positive change by shaping debate on vitally important legal and constitutional issues through development and promotion of high-impact ideas to opinion leaders and the media; by building networks of lawyers, law students, judges and policymakers dedicated to those ideas; and by countering the activist conservative legal movement that has sought to erode our enduring constitutional values. By bringing together powerful, relevant ideas and passionate, talented people, ACS makes a difference in the constitutional, legal and public policy debates that shape our democracy. Shaping Debate. The American Constitution Society brings together many of the country‚Äôs best legal minds to articulate a progressive vision of our Constitution and laws. Through its public programs (over 1,100 debates, conferences and press briefings across America each year), publications, and active on-line presence, ACS generates ‚Äúintellectual capital‚Äù for ready use by progressive allies and shapes debates on key legal and public policy issues. The American Constitution Society is also debunking conservative buzzwords such as ‚Äúoriginalism‚Äù and ‚Äústrict construction‚Äù that use neutral-sounding language but all too often lead to conservative policy outcomes. Using both traditional and new media to communicate with policymakers, judges, lawyers and the public at large, ACS presents a compelling vision of core constitutional values such as genuine equality, liberty, justice and the rule of law. Building Networks. One of the American Constitution Society‚Äôs principal missions is nurturing the next generation of progressive lawyers, judges, policy experts, legislators and academics. The engine that drives the organization‚Äôs work is its rapidly growing nationwide network: nearly 200 student chapters in law schools in 47 states, 34 lawyer chapters in large and small cities in every part of the country, and over 16,000 paying members and thousands of other supporters. ACS chapters offer platforms for debate and discussion about both enduring principles and the issues of the day, as well as provide opportunities for networking, mentoring and organizing around matters of both local and national significance. Making a Difference. The strength of ACS‚Äôs ideas and the scope of its nationwide network enable it to make a difference in legal and public policy debates and ensure that law is a force to improve the lives of all people. Recent examples of ACS initiatives and programs having an impact include an Issue Brief on the constitutionality of the individual mandate in the health care reform legislation, cited during the Senate floor debate and entered into the Congressional Record; Senator Al Franken‚Äôs 2010 ACS National Convention speech in which he stated that ‚ÄúOriginalism isn‚Äôt a pillar of our constitutional history; it‚Äôs a talking point;‚Äù and a concerted effort by ACS members to promote up-or-down votes on judicial nominations by engaging key decision makers.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The American Constitution Society believes that law should be a force to improve the lives of all people. ACS works for change by shaping debate on important legal and constitutional issues, and by building networks of progressive legal professionals.

Name: American Indian Graduate Student Association üíô
Description: The American Indian Graduate Student Association (AIGSA) is dedicated to bringing Native and Indigenous identifying graduate students together from across campus. Through academic, social, and outreach events, AIGSA works towards strengthening the Native American/Indigenous student community on-campus and beyond. AIGSA also provides opportunities for Native/Indigenous grad students to connect with other students, staff, and faculty who are Indigenous or work in areas that impact Indigenous peoples.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The American India Graduate Student Association (AIGSA) is dedicated to bringing Native/Indigenous grad students together. Through academic, social, and outreach events, AIGSA works towards strengthening the Native student community on-campus and beyond.

Name: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics at Berkeley üíô
Description: The objective of this organization is to further, within its institution, the purposes and programs of AIAA (the Institute). Additionally, the student branch is established to highlight to their university and local community the value of the aerospace industry and the role played by AIAA. Organizationally, student branches are part of the AIAA Regional Engagement Activities Division (READ).
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: To provide resources for students interested, and/or pursuing a career in aerospace.

Name: American Institute of Architecture Students üíô
Description: The mission of The American Institute of Architecture Students is to promote excellence in architectural education, training, and practice; to foster an appreciation of architecture and related disciplines; to enrich communities in a spirit of collaboration; and to organize students and combine their efforts to advance the interdisciplinary field of architecture. In the Berkeley chapter, we work in conjunction with the College of Environmental Design (CED) to form a community not just for architecture students but for all students inside and outside of CED.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: AIAS is a national, non-profit, student-run organization. The Berkeley chapter is affiliated with the national AIA through AIA East Bay. Through networking events, workshops, panels, and firm tours, we aim to expose students to the field of architecture.

Name: American Institute of Chemical Engineers
Description: Our organization has one simple goal: to better the life of a Berkeley Chemical Engineer. We have several new programs such as mentorship to help undergraduate students academically and professionally. We have information and assistance for students looking for internships and on campus research positions. Want to know who the best professors are? AIChE can help. Whether you‚Äôre interested in industry or graduate school, AIChE provides the resources you need to succeed as a chemical engineer at Berkeley.Throughout the year, and especially in the fall semester, Berkeley AIChE hosts a range of infosessions with companies like Chevron, Genentech, Procter and Gamble, Bolt Threads‚Ä¶just to name a few. And these companies are all interested in hiring full-time and interns from Berkeley. Basically ‚Äì you guys!
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Welcome to the UC Berkeley Student Chapter of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers! Please visit our website aicheucb.com for more information.

Name: American Lung Cancer Screening Initiative at Berkeley üíô
Description: The American Lung Cancer Screening Initiative (ALCSI) is a nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization consisting of physicians and students from across the country. By working with cities, local and national governments, and other organizations, ALCSI raises awareness for lung cancer and lung cancer screening. High-risk individuals can significantly benefit from lung cancer screening, and ALCSI focuses on promoting screening in this population to save lives.
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The American Lung Cancer Screening Initiative (ALCSI) at Berkeley raises awareness for lung cancer and promotes lung cancer screening for high-risk individuals.

Name: American Medical Students Association: Berkeley Premedical Chapter üíô
Description: The mission of the American Medical Student Association is to develop professionalism and activism in our members as physicians-in-training. We aim to prepare students for medical school by providing resources, support, and leadership development. As activists, we seek to educate premedical students about public health issues and advocacy, such as health policy, the culture of medicine, global health, and preventative medicine. We believe that comprehensive medical education is necessary for the development of every physician. If you are pre-med or pre-health, please consider joining our community! Our general meetings and social activities for Fall 2023 will have both in-person and virtual options to accommodate different levels of accessibility. For more information, email us at berkeleyamsa@gmail.com, contact us on social media, or check out our website at amsa.berkeley.edu.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The mission of Premed AMSA is to develop professionalism and activism in our members as physicians-in-training. We aim to prepare students for medical school by providing resources, leadership development, and discussions on social justice and equity.

Name: American Medical Women's Association at Berkeley üíô
Description: AMWA at Berkeley is a Premedical division branch of the National American Medical Women's Association. AMWA membership is comprised of physicians, residents, medical students, pre-medical students, health care professionals, and supporters. AMWA is the oldest multispecialty organization dedicated to advancing women in medicine and improving women‚Äôs health. AMWA at Berkeley aims to advance women in medicine, advocate for equity, and ensure excellence in healthcare. We seek to continuously empower and inspire our members through providing a loving and supportive platform for voices to be heard and transform ideas into realities. As a chapter divided into five task force-focused sub-committees (Mental Health, Cancer & Women‚Äôs Health, Gender & Sexual Health, Childhood Nutrition Education, Diversity in Medicine), we love to discuss topics that include women in medicine, women‚Äôs health, and gender equity. And, as a professional and community service-oriented organization, AMWA Berkeley offers opportunities for mentorship, professional development, volunteering, and support for individuals interested in healthcare careers. We welcome new members at the beginning of every semester but you are welcome to join anytime throughout the school year! We post information about infosessions, events, meetings, and pictures that our members capture on our Instagram, so follow us to stay updated! About AMWA Berkeley!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Women Interest Student Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: AMWA strives to empower those involved in medicine and health-related fields by focusing on women's issues, equality, and intersectionality. It will also promote service in the community and support members' professional and personal development.

Name: American Nuclear Society üíô
Description: The American Nuclear Society is a not-for-profit, international, scientific and educational organization. It was established by a group of individuals who recognized the need to unify the professional activities within the diverse fields of nuclear science and technology. December 11, 1954, marks the Society‚Äôs historic beginning at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, D.C. ANS has since developed a multifarious membership composed of approximately 10,500 engineers, scientists, administrators, and educators representing 1,600 plus corporations, educational institutions, and government agencies. It is governed by three officers and a board of directors elected by the membership. We, The Student Chapter The American Nuclear Society (ANS) Student Branch at University of California Berkeley is a subsidiary of the National ANS. The main objectives of the ANS Student Branch is consistent with those of the National ANS, which is to promote the advancement of science and engineering relating to the atomic nucleus and of allied sciences and arts.We are formed and managed by a group of students interested to contribute toward the development of nuclear science and technology at the University of California through activities in which student members and faculty may participate.Most of us are students in the Nuclear Engineering Department but we welcome students from all backgrounds to join us. The only requirements we ask for is a desire to learn and an open-mind for new technology. We organize events for the benefit of our own members as well as to promote understanding of nuclear technology on campus. The recent focus of this society has been to increase public awareness of the many benefits of nuclear technology and its place in our future. With the increasing threats of nuclear terrorism, our aim is to educate the public on the safety issues and responsibilities related to nuclear power generation as well as the peaceful use of nuclear materials in medical radiation as well as food processing industries. Our student section has sent many students to the ANS national conferences over the years. In 2002, UC Berkeley-ANS sponsored the National Student Conference for ANS and the conference was a tremendous success in bringing together students from all over the country to present information on latest technology in the field and to foster interaction between like-minded current and future scientists. Our Mission The American Nuclear Society serves its members in their efforts to develop and safely apply nuclear science and technology for public benefit through knowledge exchange, professional development, and enhanced public understanding. To receive our periodic emails about upcoming events and opportunities, please subscribe to our mailing list at tinyurl.com/ANS-MailingList and check out our website at https://ans.nuc.berkeley.edu
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The American Nuclear Society serves its members in their efforts to develop and safely apply nuclear science and technology for public benefit through knowledge exchange, professional development, and enhanced public understanding.

Name: American Optometric Student Association
Description: The AOSA is committed to empowering students to thrive as doctors of optometry and strives to be the guiding force that leads students into successful and impactful careers. https://vimeo.com/272671913
Categories: Graduate RSO (formerly Depart) Student Organizations
Summary: The AOSA is committed to empowering students to thrive as doctors of optometry and strives to be the guiding force that leads students into successful and impactful careers.

Name: American Physician Scientist Association at Berkeley üíô
Description: The mission of APSA at Berkeley (American Physician Scientists Association at Berkeley) is to spread awareness of physician-scientist and MD-PhD programs. It prepares members for training and development as physician-scientists by networking at the local and regional level, provides resources for success in MD-PhD programs, and inspires others to pursue careers as research physicians through community outreach and education. We do events like CPR/BLS certification courses, info sessions at Stanford and UCSF, panels with current MD/PhD candidates, resume/application workshops, and so much more! Everyone is welcome! Instagram for updates: https://www.instagram.com/apsaberkeley/Spring 2024 Interest to Join form: https://forms.gle/AKGwVs9xgkyNk2e36 (access to Slack + newsletter, open semester-round. WEBSITE: https://apsa.studentorg.berkeley.edu/
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: APSA at Berkeley is dedicated to everyone who is interested in being a physician-scientist or MD-PhD, or similar fields (e.g. biomedical research) in the future and/or would like to know more about this academic and career path.

Name: American Red Cross at Cal üíô
Description: Want to save a life? If so, keep reading! American Red Cross at Cal is an organization that includes 6 committees: Blood, Health & Safety, Disaster, Community Engagement, Publicity, and Outreach. We provide opportunities that allow students to volunteer at blood drives, CPR/First Aid training, and humanitarian relief/youth services. Join our diverse community of students who are making an immediate impact on those who need it most. For more information, use the contact resources listed below- we look forward to meeting you! Contact email: americanredcrossatcal@gmail.comFollow our Instagram for regular updates: @arcatcalGet added to our Newsletter! Linktree: linktr.ee/arcatcalWebsite: https://redcrossatcal.org/
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: ARC@Cal has 6 lines of services: Blood, Health & Safety, Disaster, Community Engagement, Outreach, and Publicity. Join us to volunteer at blood drives, CPR training, and more! Make an immediate impact on those who need it most!

Name: American Sign Language at Berkeley üíô
Description: ASL at Berkeley aims to discuss and learn ASL, facilitate a community between hearing and Deaf communities, and to bring awareness to ableism and the issues that the Deaf community face. Our goal is to spread resources made by the Deaf and hard of hearing people to amplify their point of views on the issues they face. If you are interested in bringing awareness to the issues the Deaf community faces, learning basic ASL then join us at one of our meetings. Fill out our Membership Form to keep up with meetings and events: https://forms.gle/ZtPQkccWFGWMAQaP6 Follow us on instagram @aslatberkeley or join our discord (https://discord.gg/kuUqwJDUUQ).
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose is to learn and discuss ASL, to facilitate a community between hearing and Deaf communities, and to bring awareness to ableism and the issues facing the Deaf community. We will also host events and activities surrounding ASL and Deaf culture.

Name: American Society of Civil Engineers üíô
Description: The American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) at Berkeley is a college chapter of the globally-recognized community of Civil Engineers pushing the boundaries of the Civil Engineering profession. As an extension of the broader organization, ASCE serves the civil and environmental engineering community on the UC Berkeley campus. We promote the civil engineering profession on a college level by fostering a fun and inclusive community, by offering career preparatory workshops, hosting professional development events (e.g. company-sponsored info-sessions and career fairs), peer-to-peer mentoring, and overall providing resources to promote the success of our students and the 8 competition teams that fall under our umbrella.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Berkeley Chapter of American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) contributes to the enrichment of the broad civil engineering profession by serving the civil engineering community at Berkeley through social and professional development opportunities.

Name: American Society of Landscape Architects
Description: The UC Berkeley student chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects(ASLA@Berkeley) is the student group representing all students studying landscape architecture, environmental planning and urban design (serving BLA, MLA, MLA-EP, MUD, and Ph.D students). ASLA@Berkeley coordinates professional development and skill-building opportunities, organizes social and community service activities, and represents the student‚Äôs voice at faculty and curriculum committee meetings, to the ASUC and GA, to the CED Dean‚Äôs office and to the regional and national ASLA organizations.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: The UC Berkeley student chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects(ASLA@Berkeley) is the student group representing all students studying landscape architecture, environ. planning + urban design (serving BLA, MLA, MLA-EP, MUD, and Ph.Ds)

Name: America‚Äôs ToothFairy at Berkeley üíô
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: To: 1. Provide education about the importance of oral health to children and the Berkeley community 2. Deliver accessible resources to underserved children 3. Develop social skills and establish positive relationships with members of the community

Name: Amnesty International at Berkeley (formerly known as Amnesty International) üíô
Description: Founded in London in 1961, Amnesty International is a Nobel Prize-winning grassroots activist, research, and documentation organization with over 10 million members worldwide. Amnesty International undertakes research and action focused on preventing and ending grave abuses of the rights to physical and mental integrity, freedom of conscience and expression, and freedom from discrimination, within the context of its work to promote all human rights. This organization was previously named Amnesty International. [5/2/24] LLAmnesty International at Berkeley works to promote human rights within our collegiate student body through advocacy, education, action, and service. Our past events have included film festivals, speaker events, letter writing campaigns, dinner discussion series, demonstrations, concerts, and more. Our Instagram is @berkeley.amnesty! *ASUC Sponsored
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Amnesty International is a global human rights movement of more than 10 million people. Since its founding in London in 1961, Amnesty has grown from seeking the release of political prisoners to upholding the whole spectrum of human rights.

Name: Amores Valientes üíô
Description: Amores Valientes is a community of Queer & Trans Latinx students at University of California Berkeley. The purpose of AV is to provide a safe space, to create a social environment for networking and community building for the Queer/Trans Latinx community on campus. AV does this by having programming and collaborating with other organizations on campus following the democratic principles of participation and where respect and confidentiality are fostered. Our meeting times will be on our Instagram linked below, if not @amores_valientes
Categories: Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose of AV is to provide a safe space, to create a social environment for networking and community building for the Queer/Trans Latinx community on campus.

Name: Animal Legal Defense Fund of Berkeley Law üíô
Description: The Animal Legal Defense Fund @ Berkeley Law is dedicated to providing a forum for education, advocacy, and scholarship aimed at protecting the lives and advancing the interests of animals through the legal system, and raising the profile of the field of animal law. ALDF aims to: (1) educate the UC Berkeley community about forms of institutionalized animal abuse, and (2) foster awareness about means of combating this abuse through litigation. We hope to provide opportunities, education, and assistance to Berkeley Law students working to promote positive legal protection of animal welfare.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: ALDF's mission is to protect the lives and advance the interests of animals through the legal system.

Name: ANova
Description: Berkeley ANova is a student organization that seeks to empower students by providing computer science education and mentorship to under-resourced schools and marginalized communities. Our mentors develop individualized curriculum to teach at each of our middle and high school partner sites with the goal of increasing equitable exposure and accessibility to the tech space. Each ANova member attends weekly site visits at our partnered schools and volunteers at events like ANova College Mentorship Program (a college-readiness program for high school students) and ANova Hacks (a 24-hour hackathon for high school students with little to no programming experience). ANova is driven by a tight-knit community of UC Berkeley students, who are passionate about social issues, educational outreach, and computer science mentorship. As part of our committees, members work on various projects such as curriculum building, web development, community outreach and event planning. We're excited to welcome new members this semester! No CS experience is required - just a desire to spread computer science education and willingness to learn. Please apply at: https://www.berkeleyanova.org/join For updated information on the recruitment process ~ Follow us on Instagram: @berkeleyanova
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Making access to computer science education and opportunities more equitable, available, and achievable for students of all backgrounds.

Name: Anre AI Berkeley üíô
Description: ANRE AI Berkeley aims to accelerate the growth of technical and interpersonal skills of our community by fostering a supportive community offering student-led projects and research, alongside valuable resources for career and personal development largely within the realms of Software, Hardware, Artificial Intelligence and Engineering.
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Further your career in STEM with our opportunities for growth and available projects/research opportunities.

Name: Anthropology Undergraduate Association üíô
Description: The Anthropology Undergraduate Association is a club for undergraduate students interested in anthropology that provides academic enrichment, professional enhancement, career guidance, and social events. Please email or contact us on social media for any questions.
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Anthropology Undergraduate Association welcomes Anthropology majors, minors, and other interested students to attend their many informative, academic, collaborative, and social events, which are held throughout the school year.

Name: Antitrust Law and Economics Association of Berkeley üíô
Description: ALEAB is dedicated to fostering a dynamic and inclusive community of scholars, practitioners, and enthusiasts committed to the exploration and advancement of antitrust law and economic principles. Our mission is to serve as a hub for collaboration at the intersection of antitrust law and economics. We strive to cultivate a deeper understanding of antitrust issues among our members and the broader UC Berkeley community through engaging discussions, seminars, and forums. As a catalyst for academic growth, we provide a platform for cooperative research projects, enabling members to collaborate on innovative studies. ALEAB is committed to establishing a strong network of individuals interested in antitrust law and economics . We provide various forums for cooperation and mentorship, connecting members with experienced professionals and scholars in the field. This not only enhances the learning experience, but also serves as a resource for career development within the antitrust domain and other related fields. As members of the Berkeley Law Community we strive to attract new antitrust scholars to our academic community. We aspire to contribute to the broader discourse on antitrust and economics issues, influencing positive change to the global antitrust law and economics sphere.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: ALEAB is a student-led organization dedicated to fostering a dynamic and inclusive community of scholars, practitioners, and enthusiasts committed to the exploration and advancement of antitrust and economic principles.

Name: Apple A Day
Description: Have fun and relax your brain with Apple A Day! Through engaging events, activities, and fun presentations open for everyone to join we explore and learn about neuroscience in a fun and exciting way. We have fun games, activities, arts and crafts, music, and snacks! Learn about your brain: Wednesdays, Dwinelle 258, 6:30-7:30 PM No application needed, open to all!
Summary: Have fun and relax your brain! Through engaging events, activities, and fun presentations open for everyone to join we explore and learn about neuroscience in a fun and exciting way!

Name: Arab Student Union
Description: We are the Arab Student Union, and our mission is to foster and maintain a social and cultural space of belonging for Arab undergraduate and graduate students, along with other interested community members, on the UC Berkeley campus. Alongside this mission is our goal to promote an understanding of Arab history, culture, and heritage through education and example, while simultaneously advocating for our community on campus and beyond. We hope you will join us! Follow our Instagram @arabstudentunion_cal to stay updated on opportunities to join our team as well as upcoming events.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Welcome to the Arab Student Union (ASU)! Our mission is to foster and maintain a social and cultural space of belonging for Arab undergraduate and graduate students, along with other interested community members, on the UC Berkeley campus. :)

Name: Archaeology Club of Berkeley
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Our club‚Äôs intent is to foster a community where students have access to opportunities, information, and education related to the field of archaeology.

Name: Argentine Student Association of Berkeley
Description: The Argentine Student Association of Berkeley (ASAB) fosters a vibrant community, celebrating Argentine culture and promoting academic research and collaboration.
Summary: The Argentine Student Association of Berkeley fosters community among Argentine and Argentine-interested students. We celebrate Argentine culture, host events, and support student development, creating a welcoming space to connect and share our heritage.

Name: Argentine Tango Club of Berkeley üíô
Description: Argentine tango is a social dance that originated in the late 19th century in the suburbs near and around Buenos Aires, Argentina. Learning tango is a great way to impress your friends/date/partner/parents at those awkward social functions that involve dancing. We offer a semester-long beginners' class; no prior dance experience nor partner required! For more information about current events and classes, please visit our website. Video
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Learn and enjoy dancing Argentine tango in a safe and welcoming campus community.

Name: Arknights Club
Summary: The organization's goal is to be a fun social club where students can connect over their shared interest in the game Arknights, allowing for a safe space where students can socialize and make friends. (Arknights Club a.k.a. Rhodes Island Berkeley Branch)

Name: Armenian Students Association
Description: The Armenian Students Association at the University of California, Berkeley was founded in 1976. Its mission since has been to foster a community where Armenian students can embrace their heritage and cultivate a spirit of appreciation towards Armenian history and culture through social, cultural, philanthropic, and professional events. ASA strives to foster and support its members, as well as enhance their college experience at Cal by allowing them to come together and connect with their roots, give back to their community, and celebrate their culture and history without any outside political affiliations and/or religious influence.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Join our group to receive up-to-date news and information about events hosted by the Armenian Students' Association at UC Berkeley.

Name: Army ROTC Cadet Club üíô
Description: This student organization works to support cadets in, and civilians interested in UC Berkeley's Army ROTC through non-government funded activities.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: This student organization works to support cadets in, and civilians interested in UC Berkeley's Army ROTC through non-government funded activities.

Name: Arnold Air Society
Description: The Arnold Air Society is a professional, honorary, service organization advocating the support of aerospace power.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: To provides opportunities for U.S. Air Force officer candidates to participate in campus and community service activities, demonstrating the close relationship between civilian and military institutions.

Name: Aro/Ace Space at Berkeley üíô
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, LGBTQ+ Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Aro/Ace Space at Berkeley is a safe space for Berkeley students on the asexual and aromantic spectrums. We host social events and gatherings for the ace, aro, and aroace community at Berkeley and celebrate Ace Week and Aro Week each year!

Name: Art and Mind üíô
Description: Art & Mind will meet for general meetings in which any Berkeley student is welcome to join. Our meetings are a combination of art de-stress events (such as painting, collaging, drawing, poetry, etc.), mindfulness activities, and guest speaker meetings with professionals in the art and/or mental health field. Painting materials are provided. The goal is to promote mental health awareness by de-stressing through art.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Art & Mind Club aims to promote mental health education and provides a safe space for Berkeley students to de-stress through art therapy.

Name: Artists in Resonance
Description: Artists in Resonance, casually known on campus as AiR, is the premiere indie co-ed a cappella group at the University of California, Berkeley. From our humble beginnings in 1987, we now feature a dozen amazing performers who perform a repertoire of self-arranged pieces, ranging from alternative rock and hip-hop to traditional fight songs and Top 40 hits. During the school year, you can find us singing on Sproul Plaza during the week, but don‚Äôt be surprised if you also see us performing around the Bay Area (and all throughout California) at a variety of gigs and events! We have made appearances at the Annual Big Sing-Off (UC Berkeley/Stanford), the California A Cappella Festival (UC Los Angeles), and the West Coast A Cappella Showcase (UC Berkeley). Interested in hiring us? Email artistsinresonanceucb@gmail.com Interested in auditioning? Follow our Instagram @artistsinresonance for information about our auditions process and timeline!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Artists in Resonance, commonly known as AiR, is Berkeley's premiere independent co-ed a cappella group. Our repertoire includes self-arranged pieces, with everything from alternative rock and hip-hop to traditional fight songs and Top 40 hits.

Name: ASCE Sustainable Solutions üíô
Description: Sustainable Solutions is an ASCE competition team focusing on construction project management and sustainable design in the built environment. Each year, we focus on tackling a competition prompt, comprehensively addressing a project from the master planning to construction stage. Members are equipped to employ industry skills such as life cycle assessment, need identification and urban planning. We also support members to use tools employed by planners and engineers, including 3D design and rendering, integrated environmental modeling and takeoffs. No experience is expected for new members, so if you share our interest in designing environmentally conscious spaces, come join us!
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: ASCE Sustainable Solutions Competition Team allows students to apply principles of structural and construction engineering to design and fabricate sustainable structures under real-world scenarios facing the built environment.

Name: ASCEND
Description: Ascend is the premier business organization dedicated to enabling its members and the community to leverage the leadership and global business potential of its members.The Ascend Berkeley Chapter focuses on a wide range of business industries; such as, accounting, consulting, finance, investment banking, tech, and marketing. Our Berkeley student chapter provides a variety of events and learning opportunities that allow our members to strengthen their professional skills, explore career fields, and make long-lasting friendships. Find out more about how you can get involved today at http://www.ascendberkeley.org and at our FB page https://www.facebook.com/ascendberkeleychapter. We welcome students of all majors and years and encourage you to discover what truly makes our organization unique and successful. Connect. Inspire. Ascend.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Ascend is the premier business organization dedicated to enabling its members and the community to leverage the leadership and global business potential of its members. The Ascend Berkeley Chapter mainly focuses on the accounting and finance industries.

Name: Asha for Education, Berkeley
Description: About Us: https://youtu.be/R8Feq7XARtw Learn more at: berkeley.ashanet.org Instagram: @asha_berkeley
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Asha for Education is a nonprofit organization geared towards catalyzing socio-economic change by funding education projects for the underprivileged in India, especially children.

Name: Asian American and Pacific Islander Health Research Group
Description: AAPIHRG Video We are a group of San Francisco Bay Area health professionals and UC Berkeley undergraduates/alumni. On this campus‚Äîwhere 42% of students identified as Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) in 2008‚Äîthere was not a single academic course devoted to the study of health in AAPI communities. The AAPI Health Research Group (AAPIHRG) was formed in 2008 to fill this void. The purpose of this group is to share our journey and findings in AAPI community health with other students and community professionals who may wish to join us or contribute to the work. Although the aggregate data for our community paints a picture of a healthy population, we know that good health is not enjoyed by all. Our community is not homogeneous. The diversity of the many ethnic groups that make up the AAPI community presents challenges in obtaining accurate data. Students who come from these diverse backgrounds can be an important conduit in raising our awareness of health problems that exist in these communities. This can foster a deeper understanding of health in the broader AAPI community. Besides the 4-unit Spring course (ASAMST 190 - "Asian American, Native Hawaiian, and Pacific Islander Community Health: Foundational Theories & Contemporary Issues"), we are inviting you to take part in our next steps as we develop as a student organization. We are open to all students interested in community health and specifically the AAPI community. We hope that through this organization, we foster in students a desire to serve the community as well as provide opportunities for leadership development and networking. We invite your participation in AAPIHRG as a student or as a health professional sharing the following vision and mission: VISION A healthy community can only exist within a healthy society. We strive to improve the health of the Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) communities through research and service within the community and through social activism in society. MISSION The AAPI Health Research Group was formed in the spring of 2008. The purpose is to encourage students to engage in AAPI community health in the following five areas: diversity of the AAPI communities historical perspective epidemiological perspective medical perspective social change
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: A healthy community can only exist within a healthy society. We strive to improve the health of the Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) communities through research and service within the community and through social activism in society.

Name: Asian American Association üíô
Description: The purpose of the Asian American Association is to be at the forefront of uniting the Asian American community at Berkeley. AAA seeks to develop proactive and community-oriented leaders through a social, educational awareness, and service network. It enhances the quality of life at Berkeley through its focus on diversity appreciation.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose of the Asian American Association is to be at the forefront of uniting the Asian American community at Berkeley. AAA seeks to develop proactive and community-oriented leaders through a social, educational awareness, and service network.

Name: Asian American Christian Fellowship üíô
Description: We are a student-run Christian organization seeking to create a warm, Christ-centered community. Mission: The mission of Asian American Christian Fellowship (AACF) is to reach into the university and collegiate community, primarily those who are Asian Pacific Americans, with the life changing message of Jesus Christ. Vision: We are committed to making disciples by educating and equipping students in biblical foundations, Christian disciplines, and the development of spiritual gifts in order to prepare them for witness and service on the campus, in the local church, in the marketplace, and in world missions.
Categories: Spiritual Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Community at Berkeley seeking to share the Gospel with students, primarily those who identify as being Asian American.

Name: Asian American Law Journal üíô
Description: The Asian American Law Journal (AALJ) is the preeminent law journal in the United States, and only one of two in the country, focused on Asian American communities in its publication agenda. Known as the Asian Law Journal until 2007, AALJ was first published in October 1993 in a joint publication with the California Law Review. AALJ‚Äôs first independent issue was published in May 1994. AALJ‚Äôs purpose is to explore the unique legal concerns of the South Asian American, Southeast Asian American, East Asian American, and Asian Pacific American communities, while recognizing the diversity and intersections within Asian American identities. By providing a scholarly foundation for a wide range of Asian American voices, we aim to mobilize the scholarship into action and to promote national understanding and empowerment of Asian Americans. In pursuit of these goals, AALJ strives to provide a forum for the many voices and opinions of Asian American communities through events such as its annual Spring Symposium and Neil Gotanda Lecture in Asian American Jurisprudence. AALJ is published annually, and each volume typically contains articles, book reviews, essays, and other contributions from scholars, practitioners, policymakers, and students. AALJ consists of Berkeley Law students, external members from nearby Bay Area law schools, and UC Berkeley undergraduates in the Undergraduate Fellows Program.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Asian American Law Journal (AALJ) is the preeminent law journal exploring Asian American issues, based at Berkeley Law.

Name: Asian Community Health
Description: Asian Community Health at Berkeley is a student organization at UC Berkeley with a mission to ensure that every individual, regardless of their linguistic or cultural background, can access the benefits of good health. We are dedicated to providing free healthcare services and resources to support Asian and non-English speaking communities in the Bay Area. We hope to be a bridge between the Asian community and the healthcare system. Members of our club will learn to give culturally competent care, engage directly with local communities, and work with nonprofit organizations. Our holistic health fairs feature stations including blood pressure, blood glucose, vision, bone density, Stop the Bleed, wellness information, and health kits. All students are welcome to become members of Asian Community Health at Berkeley. Your involvement can help us achieve our goal of accessible healthcare for all! To join us, please sign up through our interest form and follow us through the links below. Check out our website for more info!
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Asian Community Health is an organization dedicated to supporting Asian and non-English speaking communities. Our goal is to provide free health services and resources to overcome barriers to accessible care.

Name: Asian Pacific American Law Students Association
Description: Berkeley‚Äôs Asian Pacific American Law Student Association (APALSA), established in the 1970s, is a political, community service, academic, professional and social law student organization. APALSA is dedicated to serving and empowering the Asian and Pacific Islander American (AAPI) community at Berkeley Law and the Bay Area community at large. On the whole, APALSA‚Äôs goal is to promote a greater awareness of the diverse culture, rich history, and current struggle of Asian Pacific Americans. APALSA serves to create a safe space for AAPI students to explore their identities, build community, and honor their cultures. APALSA also works very closely with other affinity groups and student organizations in coordinating various educational and social events. APALSA is open to all Berkeley Law students of every background.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Berkeley‚Äôs Asian Pacific American Law Student Association (APALSA), established in the 1970s, is a political, community service, academic, professional and social law student organization.

Name: Asian Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus üíô
Description: The Asian and Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus is a group of MSW students at UC Berkeley who self-identify as Asian and/or Pacific Islander (API). The purpose of the group is to promote networking and connection amongst emerging social workers of API backgrounds, as social services catered to the broad API community are so sparse and limited. APISW Caucus was also formed to create a safe holding space for API folks to build community with each other and reflect about their experiences in and out of the MSW program. APISW Caucus also serves to empower and uplift the voices of self-identified Asian and/or Pacific Islander students within a program that lacks representation of this community.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Asian Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus is a group of MSW students at UC Berkeley who self-identify as Asian and/or Pacific Islander (API).

Name: Asociacion de Chilenos en Berkeley üíô
Description: The Asociaci√≥n de Chilenos en Berkeley welcomes students, faculty and staff at University of California at Berkeley, and their families, Chilean and Latin American members of the community, past exchange students in Chile and anyone with cultural or personal bonds to Chile are welcome to join the Asociaci√≥n de Chilenos en Berkeley. The Asociaci√≥n de Chilenos en Berkeley provides a safe environment for Chileans and people with ties to Chile to promote and celebrate the culture and traditions of Chile. Within the community and in all of the events it organizes or promotes there is no place for discrimination based on nationality, ethnicity, immigration status, sexual orientation, gender status, or any other form of arbitrary discrimination
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Asociacion de Chilenos en Berkeley (Assocation of Chileans at Berkeley) aims to bring together the Chilean academic, professional, and general community to share insights on research and work that helps make Chile a better place.

Name: Aspiring Educators and Student Affairs Professionals at Berkeley (Formerly known as Aspiring Educators at Berkeley) üíô
Description: AESAP Berkeley is a pre-professional organization dedicated to helping students interested in entering the education field. We welcome all students who are interested in learning more about the education field and its many different aspects. Education is power. Thus, we aspire to be an inclusive and welcoming space for students interested in the education field.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: AESAP (Aspiring Educators and Student Affairs Professionals) Berkeley is UC Berkeley's first and only pre-professional education organization. It is dedicated to students interested in careers in K-12 or higher education!

Name: Association for Muslim Professional Development
Description: The Association for Muslim Professional Development (AMPD) helps Muslim students create and plan a professional future through networking, information workshops, and personalized coaching; attempting to facilitate awareness and access to professional internships and vocations. These include, but are not limited to the professional areas of finance, medicine, engineering, consulting, sales and marketing, research, law and academics. Since its founding in 2005, AMPD (formerly known as the Muslim Business Students' Association) has hosted several events catered specifically to preparing Muslim students in their respective fields of study.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The Association for Muslim Professional Development is dedicated to empowering Muslims in the workforce by providing a strong platform for career building, networking, mentorship, industry insights, and professional resources.

Name: Association for Socially Responsible Business
Description: ASRB is a SERC affiliated organization that brings together an interdisciplinary group of individuals dedicated to using business for positive change. Through educational events, community-building, and social impact consulting projects, we aim to help you in exploring, defining, and progressing toward the personal social impact you wish to achieve. Join us and learn about how to mobilize the positive potential of business to create a more responsible, equitable, and sustainable society. This is what we do: Foster a community of interdisciplinary individuals passionate about sustainability and social impact dedicated to challenging the status quo of business Develop students to be highly effective in their future career paths and connect them to opportunities, resources, and mentorship Learn about how to mobilize the positive potential of business to create a more responsible, equitable, and sustainable society. Apply our values to hands-on projects that create measurable positive impact through working with campus, clients and the Bay Area community
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: ASRB is a SERC affiliated organization that brings together an interdisciplinary group of individuals dedicated to using business for positive change. Join us and learn about how to mobilize the positive potential of business through consulting projects!

Name: Association for the Latinx MBA Advancement (ALMA) üíô
Description: ALMA is dedicated to promoting the experience of US Latinx students at Haas by building a diverse, inclusive, and collaborative environment. Throughout the year, we plan to hold events to showcase Latinx identity professionally, socially, and culturally. This group Association for the Latinx MBA Advancement (ALMA) was formerly named Haas Latinx Business Club 4/26/24 LL
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Haas MBA RSO, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: ALMA at Haas aims to create a community for Latinx students who also consider the United States their home nation.

Name: Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs at Berkeley
Description: Founded in 2012, Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs (ACE) at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley.
