Other past projects include teaching De-Cal courses, hosting internship workshops, holding nutrition fairs, arranging coffee chats, and coordinating collaborations with other health organizations on- and off-campus. Prospective future events include career dinners, mixers with public health professionals, panels, and fireside chats. Check out our Instagram to stay updated!
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Sponsored by the UC Berkeley School of Public Health, we are the first public health group on campus to provide students with a professional and supportive network.

Name: Cal Veterans Group
Description: The Cal Veterans Group (CVG) was created in 2004 by a UC Berkeley student veteran looking for a way to bring together military veterans on campus, reach out to returning vets across the community, and provide resources and mentorship for future students. Currently, we engage in all of this work plus more. From philanthropic activities, outreach to local community colleges, and advocacy on legislation pertaining to veterans, we serve to become a beacon for vets hopeful of gaining access to and succeeding in higher education. The Group is a student organization led by undergraduate student veterans. We usually hold meetings every two weeks during the Fall and Spring semesters, and encourage as many veterans as possible to be involved! During official meetings we invite representatives to give presentations on topics ranging from veteran‚Äôs advocacy to job recruitment. Joining and becoming involved with the Cal Veterans Group is a great opportunity to expand your professional and social networks! Veteran alumni are great contacts whether you aspire to attend graduate school, or hit the ground running in the job market following graduation. Additionally, we throw social events like Tailgates (on Cal football game days), or just hang out! Our Instagram page is our primary means of communication. Here you will be kept up-to-date with group happenings! IG: @cal.veterans.group
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations
Summary: The Cal Veterans Group (CVG) is a community building organization that connects student-veterans and military-affiliated students across campus!

Name: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Lacrosse
Description: Since its founding in 2008, we have made a significant impact on west coast lacrosse. In the 2019-2020 preseason, we ranked among the top 20 in the country, and with continued success, finished among the top 10. Preseason practice begins in the fall and resumes in the spring during our regular season. We travel all over the West Coast, and games are held on the weekends. We welcome all levels of experience!
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Lacrosse is a strong and competitive member of the WWLL and WCLA. We are a tightly-knit team, and aim to foster an environment of both academic and athletic excellence.

Name: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Soccer
Description: Check us out on Instagram for more information and follow our team! @Calwclubsoc Please note that the roster listed here is not how you join the official Club Sports Roster. To do so, reference the Cal Sports website and register via IM Leagues. Please see https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/womens-club-soccer/
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: The Cal Women‚Äôs Club Soccer team promotes a competitive and community-focused environment. The club is made up of almost 25 talented women, offering players a soccer experience at varying levels of competition.

Name: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Volleyball
Description: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Volleyball is a competitive athletic program in Division 1 of the NCCVL (https://nccvlw.org). We compete against Cal Poly SLO, Santa Clara, Sonoma, UC Davis, and Stanford at the league level and teams from all over the country at the national level each season. The bears won the National Club Championship in 2022 and placed 3rd in the 2023 and 2025 National Championships. For more info - https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/womens-club-volleyball/
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Volleyball fields a competitive team of dedicated players. They are in Division 1 of the NCCVL and compete against local schools at the league level and teams from all over the country at the national level each season.

Name: Cal Women‚Äôs Club Water Polo Team
Description: The Cal Women‚Äôs Club Water Polo team is a part of the Sierra Pacific League in the Collegiate Water Polo Association (CWPA). We attend several tournaments throughout the season including both invitationals and CWPA official tournaments, culminating in division championships and, if we win, Nationals! We practice 2-3 times a week in the Fall and 3-4 times a week in the Spring, which is our main competition season. We emphasize competitiveness, but also work hard to make the experience fun and provide a community for our players. We are a no-cut team affiliated with the University, so whether you‚Äôre an Undergraduate or Graduate student, experienced player or brand new to the sport, please come check us out! For more info - https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/womens-club-water-polo/
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: The Cal Women‚Äôs Club Water Polo Team is a nationally top-ranked team, and although we aim to remain highly competitive, the top priorities of the team are academics, camaraderie, and fun.

Name: Cal Women‚Äôs Squash
Description: See https://calsquash.weebly.com/ See https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/womens-squash/
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: Established in 2008, the Cal Women‚Äôs Squash team was the first women‚Äôs squash club team at a public university on the West Coast. We are a member of the College Squash Association (CSA) and compete in the National Team Championship each year.

Name: Cal Women‚Äôs Ultimate (Pie Queens)
Description: For more info visit our website
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: Also known as the Pie Queens, we are a program that strives to introduce people to ultimate frisbee and create a great community. We travel a fair amount to tournaments throughout the year and have multiple teams to fit anyone‚Äôs schedule!

Name: CalGreeks Alcohol Task Force
Description: CAT is a group of students from various backgrounds that work with the greek councils towards a safer and more educated community with respect to alcohol. CAT has a double mission: - Monitor the social events of the greek community in order to ensure all safety rules are being followed. - Educate students to a responsible way of partying and drinking alcohol.
Categories: CalGreeks Fraternity & Sorority Affinity Groups
Summary: CAT is a group of students from various backgrounds that work with the greek councils towards a safer and more educated community with respect to alcohol.

Name: CALICO Informatics Competition üíô
Description: Why solve problems when you can create them instead? The CALICO Informatics Competition (CALICO) organizes programming contests to help students learn problem-solving and algorithms in a fun and exciting way! Our main event is a semiannual hybrid online/in-person team contest with 1,500+ contestants from around the world featuring a broad range of topics and challenges for all skill levels. From problem writing to event logistics to contest infrastructure to art, everyone can find a way to help! Joining CALICO is a great way to learn computer science, meet friends, and have fun! There is NO APPLICATION PROCESS--anyone is welcome to join, regardless of background or prior experience! We have general meetings every Friday 6:00 PM at Soda/Cory, as well as various worksessions throughout the week for our different branches. Join our team Discord to see our current meeting schedule! We organize the club primarily using Discord, where we post announcements, meeting schedules, and discuss everything. To get access, please fill out this form: https://forms.gle/Yr8cb22YCR9G4FVcA For more information about the contest, check out our website: https://calico.cs.berkeley.edu/ Also follow us on ig: https://www.instagram.com/berkeleycalico/
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Why solve problems when you can create them instead? CALICO organizes semiannual algorithmic programming contests with students from around the world to teach problem-solving and algorithms in a fun and exciting way! No experience needed to join!

Name: California Health Professional Student Alliance at Berkeley
Description: The idea and first versions of CaHPSA, active under several different names, started around 2005 as a loose association of campus level leaders who had a passion for health reform and primarily organized around Lobby Day each year. Parker Duncan, the first Medical Student Fellow, was extremely involved in the development of the student leaders during these years. In 2009, involved campus student leaders, along with the statewide Lobby Day team, held their first student leadership meeting to brainstorm ways to structure the organization for the future. There was a general consensus that additional organization at the state level could be a useful tool for CaHPSA. The mission statement was developed from a rougher draft of the previous year. The core functions of the organization were agreed upon to be "Educate ‚Äì Advocate ‚Äì Grow" and statewide positions were developed from these core functions. CaHPSA at Berkeley too aligns with the belief "health justice for all" and endeavors to carrying the following goals: Support efforts to improve quality of and access to health care in California Provide opportunities for students to develop health advocacy and communication skills Educate and train future health and medical professionals to become effective health advocates Engender a sense of social responsibility among students Advocate for a single-payer health system We offer programs such as Project White Coat to certify students in helping more people enroll in health insurance and prepare for the annual Lobby Day which occurs in Sacramento. Health Alerts helps students train to be better advocates for healthcare reform. This group [California Health Professional Student Alliance at Berkeley] was formerly named [California Health Professional Student Alliance at UC Berkeley] - 2/5/21 IZ
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Political & Advocacy Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: We aim to promote healthcare justice in our community by training members to become effective health policy advocates, connecting with legislators to give students a greater voice in enacting healthcare reform, and volunteering for the underserved.

Name: California Ice Hockey
Description: California Ice Hockey was founded on the understanding that intercollegiate club sports provide a unique opportunity to unite students of all backgrounds in the cultivation of a strong sense of community, academic excellence, and sportsmanship. Founded in 1918 and officially recognized as a Varsity Team in 1928, California Ice Hockey has a distinguished history. After a hiatus during World War II, the program reemerged as a Club Sport and has been competing in the PAC-8 conference since 1996. As an ACHA Division 2 organization, we offer athletes the opportunity to compete across the country while continuing to pursue their academic interests and foster relationships within the wider Berkeley community. Following our 2024-2025 season, we are looking to build of a historic 25-0 regular season, including sweeping ACHA D1 university Oregon at their home rink, and qualifying for the Western Regional tournament.
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: California Ice Hockey strives to foster a supportive environment both on and off the ice. We welcome anyone interested in playing ice hockey to try out for our team and to grow their community at UC Berkeley.

Name: California Mock Trial
Description: Mock Trial is a team-based speech competition that combines elements of law, speech, debate, and theatre. As a simulation of trial advocacy, Mock Trial also includes simulations of courtroom procedure and technique that reflect a real trial. Cal Mock Trial is UC Berkeley‚Äôs official Mock Trial Team. Since its founding in 1999, Cal Mock Trial has been a nationally ranked program and has consistently competed at the top levels of collegiate mock trial. As part of its competitive season, Cal Mock Trial regularly travels across the tournament to compete. Recent years have seen the Golden Bears competing and winning trials at locations such as Washington DC, New York City, Miami, Chicago, and Los Angeles. Cal Mock Trial is a constant presence at the National Championship Tournament each year, often qualifying two separate teams and placing among the top ten programs in the nation.
Categories: OASIS Sponsored Organization, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, ABSA - Budgeted over $7500 Organizations
Summary: Cal Mock Trial is UC Berkeley‚Äôs official Mock Trial Team. Mock trial is a team-based competition that combines the elements of law, speech, debate, and theater. Since its founding in 1999, CMT has been one of the top-ranked programs in the country.

Name: California Public Interest Research Group üíô
Description: CALPIRG Students is a student-run, student-funded nonprofit at eight of the UCs that, through grassroots organizing and advocacy, fights to protect our environment, make college more affordable, and reinvigorate our democracy. CALPIRG stands for California Public Interest Research Group, fighting against private/special interests who have a lot more money, but we have the people power. With over forty years of grassroots organizing experience, there is no other nonprofit like CALPIRG Students. CALPIRG has advocated for changes we all now take for granted, such as mandatory seat belts in cars and nutrition labels on food. In just the past couple of years, we've committed California to 100% clean electricity by 2045 (we started the '100%' motto everyone now knows is referring to renewable energy), committed UC Berkeley to 100% clean energy (the first major institution to do so), passed a statewide bag ban (we were known as the 'bag people'), registered thousands of students to vote, and much more. We're the largest student group in California with dues-paying members, so we're very supported! As our track record implies, we‚Äôre a very goals-orientated nonprofit. We have different campaigns (or teams) within our organization that have specific goals. Every semester, we have a variety of campaigns that we organize on, usually focusing on environmental conservation, student affordability, and/or consumer protection. If you are interested in learning how to make a campaign plan, build grassroots support, lobby your elected officials, and make real change, come check us out and see what we can accomplish together!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Political & Advocacy Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: CALPIRG Students is a student-run, student-funded nonprofit at eight of the UCs that, through grassroots organizing and advocacy, fights to protect our environment, make college more affordable, and reinvigorate our democracy.

Name: California Women's Rugby
Description: California Women's Rugby exists to provide a space for nonmale identifying athletes to play rugby on a competitive level as well as develop their skills regardless of experience. We begin preseason practices in the Fall semester, and our league season is in the Spring, where we compete competitively in the D1 Pacific Mountain rugby conference. In the 2024-2025 season, we were the College Rugby Association of America national runner-up in 7s and 15s. Off the field, California Women's Rugby provides a supportive community for all players and leadership opportunities. Also, check out our Instagram page @calwomensrugby, and our Facebook page "Cal Women's Rugby." We can't wait to connect with you both on and off the pitch!
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Sports Club
Summary: California Women's Rugby exists to provide a space for nonmale identifying athletes to play rugby on a competitive level as well as develop their skills regardless of experience.

Name: Californians, The
Description: The Californians is a dynamic group dedicated to providing campus and community service, leadership development and class unity for the purpose of making today‚Äôs active students into tomorrow‚Äôs active alumni. We're bringing back our class council system Seniors! Anyone interested is welcome! During the fall, The Californians participate in Homecoming and plan the December General Commencement for graduating seniors. In the Spring, The Californians plan Career Networking Seminar (CNS), an alumni networking session, and Cal 101, a panel for prospective students and parents of prospective students during Cal Day. Along with this, The Californians plan Senior Week, which include the long tradition of painting the Big C white and numerous other event, and May Commencement (Commencement speaker, performers, etc.) If you are interested in joining, please follow our Instagram @berkeleyscc!
Categories: OASIS Sponsored Organization, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The Californians is a dynamic group dedicated to providing campus and community service, leadership development and class unity for the purpose of making today‚Äôs active students into tomorrow‚Äôs active alumni.

Name: Calisthenics Club üíô
Description: Calisthenics at Berkeley is Berkeley's exclusive club for calisthenics training. We meet at least once a week to train different strength and technique movements. We have experienced leaders teach planche, muscle up, handstand, pistol squat, and everything in between. We love to train with a variety of skill levels. Even if you're a beginner, give our club a try! You can come once or every single week, no commitment necessary. If you have questions, reach out to us on Instagram @calisthenicsberkeley. You can find our new member form in the bio! W
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Our club is committed to creating an accessible and empowering environment for students to improve their fitness through bodyweight exercises. We meet weekly to train strength and technique. All experience levels are welcome!

Name: Call of Duty at Berkeley üíô
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: To provide Berkeley students with the opportunity to both compete in and play Call of Duty titles casually. We wish to host weekly events and socials that promote the game while strengthening our community!

Description: This organization is for demonstration purposes only

Name: CalSol üíô
Description: Founded in 1990, CalSol, the UC Berkeley Solar Vehicle Team, is a student-run racing team that designs, builds, tests, and races next generation solar vehicles. CalSol provides its team members with real world engineering and project management experience while developing and raising awareness of clean energy technologies. For more information, or if you're interested in joining, please visit our website, https://calsol.berkeley.edu/!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: CalSol, the UC Berkeley Solar Vehicle Team, is an ASUC-sponsored student-run racing team whose mission is to design, build, test, and race next generation solar vehicles.

Name: Camp Kesem Berkeley üíô
Description: With over 5 million children impacted by a parent's cancer, Kesem must continue expanding to meet this need. Kesem is the largest national organization dedicated to this unique population, and for many children, their Kesem experience is a life-changing event‚Äìproviding them a community of children with similar experiences, and a safe and welcoming environment to have fun and rediscover their childhood. Beyond that, our replicable and highly scalable funding model also allows for rapid expansion. Kesem now serves 10 times the number of children supported ten years ago. In summer 2019, more than 10,200 children attended over 100 week-long sessions of Kesem held at fun and exciting campsites from coast-to-coast. And with your help, we hope to continue supporting more and more children each year! Thank you for being an important part of our growth as we support children through and beyond their parent's cancer with innovative, fun-filled programs that foster a lasting community!
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Kesem is a nationwide community, driven by passionate college student leaders, that supports children through and beyond their parent's cancer. Kesem provides free year-round support & summer camp for children who have been impacted by a parent's cancer.

We are located at the corner of Bancroft & Telegraph in the MLK Jr. Building and Eshleman Hall. We house the Cal Student Store, Amazon Hub+, Event Services, the Berkeley Art Studio, Creative Lab, Food Pantry, OASIS, Public Service Center, OCF, BWell at BNorth, the ASUC and GA Student Governments, and much more!
Summary: The UC Berkeley Student Union is the hub of student life at Cal! Shop, book space, study, eat, have fun, and access resources.

Name: Campus Dept | Basic Needs Center
Description: The Basic Needs Center acts as a central hub to support students in their journey to access essential services that impact health, belonging, and overall well-being. The Basic Needs Center team is committed to fostering belonging and advocating for justice on the UC Berkeley campus through a robust model of prevention, intervention and emergency relief efforts addressing holistic needs. We define basic needs as an ecosystem that includes: financial stability nutritious, accessible, cultural reflective, and sufficient food safe, secure and adequate housing (to sleep, study, cook and shower) health equity accessible transportation tech-equity equitable support for students with disproportionate basic needs experiences including but not limited to students with disabilities, parenting students/students with dependents

Name: Campus Dept | Bears for Financial Success
Description: Bears for Financial Success is a peer-to-peer financial wellness program housed in the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office at UC Berkeley. We offer workshops and one-on-one appointments to help students manage their personal finances in college and beyond.
Categories: Campus Departments
Summary: .Peer-to-peer financial wellness program that helps students manage their personal finances.

Name: Campus Dept | Bears that Care
Description: Bears That CARE (BTC) is an active bystander initiative to make our campus safer. Through interactive workshops about bystander intervention, Bears That CARE educates and empowers individuals to effectively and safely intervene in potentially harmful or violent situations. We strive to create a community of care. Our staff is comprised of peer educators. Peer educators provide workshops to student groups across campus and actively promote violence prevention through a variety of programs, as well as lead workshops for academic and student affairs departments. Our work is based off of using the CARE model to safely intervene in potentially harmful situations. Confront the situation, Alert others, Redirect attention, Engage afterwards. Our interactive workshops include a variety of topics and can be customized to your need! We host workshops on: - General Bystander Intervention - Consent - Advanced Consent - Alcohol Education - Social Identities and Microaggressions - Mental Health - Suicide Awareness Learn more at https://csi.berkeley.edu/prevention/btc/
Summary: Bears that CARE (BTC) is active bystander initiative through the Center of Support and Intervention that aims to make campus a safer community by empowering individuals to intervene in harmful situations. Take care of your fellow bears!

Description: The Berkeley Art Studio offers classes in ceramics, design, painting, drawing, and photography. The Studio has a rich history of providing quality art instruction for our members through our staff of professional artists. The Berkeley Art Studio is a welcoming place for students and artists at various skill levels. Berkeley Art Studio registration is open to the entire community as well as UC Students, Faculty, and Staff. Over it's 40 year history the Berkeley Art Studio has proven to be more than just a space, but a community of artists committed to their craft.
Categories: Campus Departments
Summary: The Berkeley Art Studio offers classes in ceramics, design, painting, drawing, and photography. Update for Fall 2020: All classes are offered online through Zoom.

Name: Campus Dept | Cal Dining
Description: At Cal Dining, we believe that ‚Äúbreaking bread together‚Äù is a unique aspect of dining on-campus with friends, faculty, or staff. Our focus is on nourishing the Cal community, both for physical and social well-being, through customer-driven programs, culinary excellence, and campus social responsibility.

Name: Campus Dept | Cal Interfaith Council
Description: ‚ÄúCal Interfaith Council‚Äù is a group of committed local faith-based leaders who have agreed to meet approximately once a month, or at a times of crisis, to come together to engage with each other and the campus community to discuss and address issues that are pertinent to the University of California Berkeley community This is a volunteer organization whose membership requirements are simply summarized by acknowledging the following: A commitment to actively participate in regular meetings. A respect for all faiths Cal interfaith Council would like to invite you to fill out a Religious Accommodations Questionnaire. For further information regarding UCB religious accommodations, please visit this page. Refer to the Accommodation of Religious Creed Policy for further information. Current membership roster is linked here MESSAGE OF LOVE FROM THE CAL INTERFAITH COUNCIL: We are clergy and faith leaders on and around the UC Berkeley campus and are members of the Cal Interfaith Council. We acknowledge that in this time of deep political division, the Cal campus is experiencing a heightened sense of turmoil and distress, particularly around a series of provocative high profile political speakers/events and a wide range of responses by members of the Cal community and beyond. Our spiritual and theological traditions offer deep wisdom for turbulent times like the ones we are now experiencing. When our national climate sensationalizes division and violence, scapegoats and stigmatizes the vulnerable and disenfranchised, and gives a platform to hate, we are committed to embodying this wisdom here in Berkeley to amplify the voices of love, peaceful protest, civic dialogue, and zero tolerance for hate speech. As faith leaders from a variety of traditions and religions, we affirm the value of free speech and exchange of ideas, and honor a long legacy of respectful engagement across differences. Honoring our differences, and the complexity of the present moment in our city and our country, we stand united in and for love, and we commit to working for a just world for all, starting here on the Cal Campus. Signed by Cal Interfaith Council
Summary: Cal Interfaith Council is a group of committed local faith-based leaders who have agreed to meet approximately once a month, or at a times of crisis, to come together to engage with each other and the campus community.

Name: Campus Dept | Cal Performances
Description: Cal Performances is the performing arts presenting, commissioning, and producing organization based at the University of California, Berkeley. The origins of Cal Performances date from 1906, when stage actress Sarah Bernhardt appeared at the William Randolph Hearst Greek Theater to help rebuild public morale after the devastating San Francisco earthquake and fire in April of that year. Over the subsequent century, Cal Performances grew to become the largest, multi-discipline performing arts presenter in Northern California, and one of the largest university-based arts presenters in the United States. Traditional and non-traditional artists regularly appear on or near the UC Berkeley campus in the theaters and concert halls managed by Cal Performances, including Mikhail Baryshnikov, Wynton Marsalis, Cecilia Bartoli, Bryn Terfel, Mark Morris, Yo-Yo Ma, Philip Glass, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Merce Cunningham, Pina Bausch, Bill T. Jones, Peter Sellars, and Robert Lepage; as well as artists based in the San Francisco Bay Area like John Adams, Lou Harrison, Margaret Jenkins, Paul Dresher, Kronos Quartet, Joe Goode, Kaila Flexer, Jon Jang, and Sarah Cahill. Cal Performances is also instrumental in facilitating the touring of large ensembles from abroad and has hosted such companies as the Grand Kabuki Theater of Japan, the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballet companies, Lyon Opera Ballet and Orchestra, the Kirov Orchestra, the Russian National Orchestra, the Berliner Ensemble, the Beijing People‚Äôs Art Theater, the Gate Theater of Dublin, Les Arts Florissants, Ballet Nacional de Cuba, and Nederland Dans Theater, among others. Cal Performances presents over 100 performances annually in five venues‚ÄîZellerbach Hall, Zellerbach Playhouse, Hertz Hall, and Wheeler Hall on the UC Berkeley campus, and First Congregational Church of Berkeley‚Äîand in site-specific locations and other spaces. The performances range among Modern and Classical Dance, Theater, Instrumental and Vocal Recital, Early Music, Opera, Chamber Music, Jazz, New Music, World Music, Dance & Theater, Circus Arts, and a speaking series. Cal Performances serves some 150,000 patrons annually through performances and arts education, residency, and community programs.
Summary: Cal Performances presents phenomenal music, dance, theater, and circus arts performances from all over the world. Visit https://calperformances.org/ for information on the stellar artists on our 2021-22 season, access to student discounts, and much more!

Description: The Disability Cultural Community (DCC) Center at UC Berkeley welcomes all new students to visit our Zoom room during the Fall 2021 GBO virtual resource fair. We are excited to meet you and share information that can help you transition into your experience and form community as a new Cal student. When: Friday, August 20, 2021 from 1:00 PM-4:00 PM Where: via the Zoom platform, join by using the following link. Join Zoom Meetinghttps://berkeley.zoom.us/j/99043775635 We invite you to: Get information about the Disability Cultural Community Center on campus Obtain information on upcoming events and services offered Learn about the history of the Disability Rights Movement and community Honor the history and significance of how the center came into being Discover information around Self-advocacy and how to connect with other disabled student organizations Opportunities to be connected with other students ...and more Please contact us if we can provide any accommodations to facilitate your participation and access. Direct any questions, comments, recommendations, or requests to Ann Wai-Yee Kwong, Coordinator, at awkwong@berkeley.edu.

Name: Campus Dept | Future Histories Lab
Description: Future Histories Lab is home for students interested in the intersection of social change, urban space, and the arts. By taking our courses you can earn an Undergraduate or Graduate Certificate in Urban Humanities. We research stories of place in order to propose new futures. We believe that understanding the history under our feet is necessary to plan for change in our communities. We use art, storytelling, technology, and installations in public space to illuminate and analyze questions of equity, race, and environment. Faculty, students, and community members work together to conduct collaborative, place-based research and create public-facing websites, performances, memorials, artistic interventions, and policy proposals. We are based jointly at the Arts & Humanities Division and the College of Environmental Design, with participation from many parts of campus. We welcome students from all disciplines to join our community. Start your certificate this fall by enrolling in Restorative Justice in Urban Planning and Policy: Storytelling for Racial Healing & Justice or take our 1-2 unit colloquium Place-Based Storytelling Techniques and Technologies. To find out more visit our website: https://futurehistories.berkeley.edu/
Categories: Campus Departments
Summary: We research stories of place in order to propose new futures. By taking our courses students can earn a Certificate in Urban Humanities while working towards a more socially just future. We welcome students from all disciplines to join our community.

Name: Campus Dept | New Student Services
Description: New Student Services‚Äô mission is to give each student the support and resources needed for a successful transition to the Berkeley campus: academically, socially, emotionally, and culturally. Here you‚Äôll find a guide through the overall Golden Bear Experience, which consists of four major components: Golden Bear Advising, Golden Bear Prep, Golden Bear Orientation and Getting Your Bearings. Whether you are an incoming undergraduate first-year or a transfer student, please take the time to read through the information here. Your transition to Berkeley begins online as soon as you accept your offer of admission! Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us. Our staff is here to answer your questions and offer advice. Welcome to Cal and Go Bears!
Summary: New Student Services‚Äô mission is to give each student the support and resources needed for a successful transition to the Berkeley campus: academically, socially, emotionally, and culturally.

Name: Campus Dept | OASIS - Organization Advising & Student Involvement Services
Description: The OASIS Center helps you create your pathway to involvement in the UC Berkeley community. Want to establish a new student org, or re-register your existing student org? Want advising on efficient org management? We provide guidance to the resources that will help you succeed, from CalLink page management to funding, space reservation, and event planning tools. We're even here to help with effective promotion strategies for your org, and smooth transition tools for leadership changes. Registered Student Organizations (RSOs) at Berkeley provide a sense of community and belonging for our campus community. The Organization Advising & Student Involvement Services (OASIS) team is here to help student orgs achieve their organizational purpose while also ensuring a positive campus impact and healthy experience for members. University recognition as a Registered Student Organization (RSO), as defined in Berkeley Campus Regulations Implementing University Policies, gives your organization official recognition only while on campus. It also gives you the ability to access campus resources such as funding opportunities, event & facility access, and access to student organization event insurance. It is important to note that RSOs are separate entities from the University, and RSO programs, events, and activities do not represent UC Berkeley. Being a Registered Student Organization and RSO Signatory comes with many campus privileges and responsibilities. You will need 4 students who are willing to serve as the Signatories for your organization. The four of you will be responsible for upholding our university‚Äôs mission, values, and policies as they relate to the Student Organization experience. Visit the CalLink Organization Directory for a complete list of Student Organizations, and click here to meet the Student Org. Advisors. Questions? Contact a Student Org Advisor. Make sure to follow us on Instagram @UCBerkeleyOASIS for important updates!
Categories: Campus Departments
Summary: The Organization Advising & Student Involvement Services (OASIS) team is here to help student orgs achieve their organizational purpose while also ensuring a positive campus impact and healthy experience for members.

The foundation for the services we offer is in the values we hold as an organization: academic success; a supportive and developmental transition for students and families; shared community living and cooperative learning; optimal leadership opportunities for students, and a practice of inclusion and social justice.

Description: For details about P&T's Mobility Programs, including recruiting for the AC Transit/ Class Pass Committee and the Mobility and Equity Committee, please visit our website. Our Vision and Mission In support of the University's core academic and public service mission, Parking and Transportation is dedicated to delivering transportation systems that complement long-term growth and development, and enhance and protect the physical attributes of the campus and surrounding area. To improve the quality of life for the UC Berkeley community by providing safe, convenient, and well maintained parking and transportation options, while promoting and facilitating alternative modes of transportation. Berkeley Moves! Alternative Transportation Unit Parking & Transportation provides, to the best of their ability, alternative campus transportation modes and opportunities and incentives for the campus to ditch their cars and use public transit, carpooling, active transportation (walking and biking) and much more. Berkeley Moves! also has a trip planning and ridematching website that allows for campus affiliates to connect with others for commuter opportunities, as well as trip planning throughout the Bay Area and beyond.

Name: Campus Dept | PATH to Care Center
Description: The PATH to Care Center leads the efforts to transform our campus into a community that is free of sexual violence, sexual harassment, intimate partner violence, and stalking through prevention, advocacy, training, and healing. We collaborate with the campus community to make social change with the goals of preventing, intervening in, and responding to harassment and violence, eliminating oppression, and creating the culture and environment we all aspire to and deserve. We envision a campus community free of violence and grounded in social justice. This vision will be realized when every member of our community is a beacon of support and respect for those around them. Mission The PATH to Care Center leads the efforts to transform our campus into a community that is free of sexual violence, sexual harassment, intimate partner violence, and stalking through prevention, advocacy, training, and healing. We collaborate with the campus community to make social change with the goals of preventing, intervening in, and responding to harassment and violence, eliminating oppression, and creating the culture and environment we all aspire to and deserve. Vision We envision a campus community free of violence and grounded in social justice. This vision will be realized when every member of our community is a beacon of support and respect for those around them. Values We believe prevention comes first. We know that with time and concerted efforts, violence is 100% preventable, and we believe that, as a UC Berkeley community, we have a moral imperative to prevent violence and suffering. We center survivors. Survivors began and are imperative to the movement to end sexual violence across the country; their experiences and perspectives are critical to healing and transforming our culture in genuine and meaningful ways. We are grounded in social justice. We understand that violence is rooted in oppression and that oppression is intersectional, so our approach must also be intersectional. We commit ourselves to expanding access, practicing inclusion, and undoing oppression wherever and whenever possible. We believe safety is a right. Every human in our community should receive respect for their bodily and emotional integrity and autonomy ‚Äî always, in every situation. We practice self-care and kindness. Work grounded in these practices is more sustainable, effective, and transformative. We seek and value the wisdom of our community. We take a communal approach to our work, knowing that we are all learning from each other. We are optimistic and hopeful. We know that, as a community, we can eliminate violence and create the campus community we want. _______________________________________ Opened in 2014, the PATH to Care Center quickly became a cornerstone of support for UC Berkeley students, faculty, and staff. The Center‚Äôs first big milestone came when the Chancellor announced Berkeley would create a confidential advocate position, a crucial resource for survivors seeking services, as well as for those seeking to understand or pursue a university disciplinary process. Later in 2014, the first Bear Pact program launched, educating all incoming first-year and transfer undergraduate students about sexual violence prevention, with content designed and delivered by the University Health Services Health Promotion team. Following this, in the fall, the first advocate ‚Äì who would go on to become the Center‚Äôs first director ‚Äì was hired: Mari Knuth-Bouracee. The Center saw an immediate and overwhelming demand for services, which led to the ASUC and GA passing the Wellness Initiative Fee Referendum ‚Äì a commitment of student fees funding several initiatives, including a new advocate position for the Center. This Referendum solidified the University‚Äôs commitment to expanding the Center‚Äôs resources for all who need them, and helped lead to rapid growth: two advocates were hired, sexual violence prevention education was included for the first time in graduate student education, and an Assistant Director for Prevention joined the Center‚Äôs team. With the rapid expansion and demand for services, the Center quickly grew out of its one-room office and into a new space that included two counseling rooms for client meetings, crucial for confidentiality, in early 2016. In mid-2016, the Center added an Assistant Director for Survivor Support, a Program Analyst, and two Prevention Program Managers. The need for the Center was clear ‚Äì and in July, the US Office on Women‚Äôs Health awarded the University a grant, with the Center as the lead department, to continue to expand this work. The Center then launched a peer education program, which began with the hiring of 11 peer educators, as well as a Care Line, the 24/7 crisis line for the University. Continuing its focus on graduate student sexual violence prevention, the Center hired its first Program Manager for Graduate Prevention. The Center also launched The Well, a Black healing space co-led by a Center advocate. Since its launch, the Center has continued to deepen its focus on both survivor support and prevention. By late 2017, videos created by the Center highlighting these practices had been shown to over 15,000 students, faculty and staff (and continue to be shown each year); the Center launched Yoga As Healing groups; and the Center received further recognition when the Office on Violence Against Women awarded the University a grant, with the Center as the lead department. Another major milestone was successfully advocating for funding for a Prevention Manager for Staff and Faculty Programs; a role that was filled in 2018. Today, the Center continues to expand in both its staff capacity and in the services it provides, further solidifying its place as a key resource for the University.Contact us today for support!
Summary: The PATH to Care Center confidential advocates bring a holistic approach to supporting survivors. Advocates provide affirming, empowering, free, confidential support and bring a non-judgmental, caring approach to exploring all rights and resources.

Description: The Student Environmental Resource Center (SERC) cultivates a collaborative space to strengthen the collective effectiveness of the sustainability community, and provides resources for students to actualize their visions of a more equitable, socially just, and resilient future. Learn more at serc.berkeley.edu. Established 10.17.12, SB 85 F12.

Name: Campus Dept | Student Learning Center
Description: The Student Learning Center is the premier undergraduate academic support unit at UC Berkeley. Founded in 1973, the Center was established to provide a rigorous and inclusive space for undergraduates to collaborate, learn, and grow. We view peer collaboration as the touchstone of academic and personal success. The Student Learning Center has grown to serve more than 10,000 undergraduates annually‚Äîapproximately 30% of the university‚Äôs undergraduate population. Today, we‚Äôre recognized for our process-oriented, research-driven, and culturally informed approach to collaborative peer pedagogy. With a wide range of classes, programs, and events, the SLC seeks to push the boundaries of traditional learning models, while advancing our mission of undergraduate empowerment. To further foster academic excellence, we will continue to expand the breadth and depth of our innovative services. Our Mission The Student Learning Center supports a global community of learners as they navigate the cultural expectations and academic rigor of UC Berkeley. Through service models that honor their diverse starting points and meet them where they are, we aim to empower all students to realize their full academic potential and aspirations. Core Values Deliver service with integrity Approach learning as a process, not a product Create innovative pedagogy and practices that optimize student learning Operate from a student-centered framework Respect diverse ways of knowing and learning

Name: Campus Dept | Student Opportunity Fund (SOF)
Description: The Student Opportunity Fund provides professional development funds to individuals and groups that seek professional development opportunities and/or educational-focused experiences like conferences and professional meetings. The application for Fall 2025 is now open for professional development opportunities that took place between July 1, 2025 and December 31, 2025. Find the Application here. Please review our SOF Guidelines document to find FAQ‚Äôs. If you have any questions, please email Student Opportunity Fund at sof@berkeley.edu In community, Student Opportunity Fund Team

Summary: The Student Opportunity Fund provides professional development funds to individuals and groups that seek professional development on campus and educational-focused experiences like conferences and professional meetings.

Name: Campus Dept | Student Technology Services
Description: Student Tech Services (STS) is a program to ensure all graduate, professional and undergraduate students have access to: Information and education about key technology resources Knowledgeable, friendly, and responsive technical support Policies that all campus members are expected to be familiar with Opportunities to work in student IT jobs throughout campus We welcome you to reach out to us if you have questions or difficulties with internet and WiFi, Zoom, campus software, your personal device, security, and much more. (510) 642-HELP, sts-help@berkeley.edu

Name: Campus Dept | The Green Initiative Fund
Description: Do you... Need funding for your campus sustainability project? Want to know what projects have been funded by TGIF? Want to serve on a committee that awards sustainability grants? Need a student internship that will provide you with green job skills? Want to learn more about UC Berkeley's campus sustainability efforts? Need information regarding starting a green fund at your institution? If yes, then The Green Initiative Fund is for you! The Green Initiative Fund (TGIF) provides funding for projects that reduce UC Berkeley's negative impact on the environment and make UC Berkeley more sustainable. TGIF allocates funds to projects that promote sustainable modes of transportation, increase energy and water efficiency, restore habitat, promote environmental and food justice, and reduce the amount of waste created by UC Berkeley. Portions of the fund also support education & behavior change initiatives, student aid (via return to aid), and student internships. Students, faculty, and staff may submit project proposals, which will be selected for funding by an annually appointed grant-making committee (TGIF Committee), consisting of students, faculty, and staff, on which the students have the majority vote. Learn more at http://tgif.berkeley.edu.
Categories: Admin, Campus Departments, Environmental & Sustainability Student Organizations
Summary: TGIF is UC Berkeley's student-fee based campus sustainability fund. TGIF provides funding via grants for projects that reduce UC Berkeley's negative impact on the environment and make UC Berkeley more sustainable. Learn more at http://tgif.berkeley.edu

Name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Campus Libraries
Description: ‚Äã‚Äãvimeo.com/307130179 Welcome to the UC Berkeley Library! Considered the crown jewel of higher education in California, UC Berkeley relies on the Library every day to support its world-class teaching and cutting-edge research, and to enrich the experience of the thousands of students who have made the university their academic home. UC Berkeley has an amazing array of libraries, including Doe (an iconic beacon of information at the heart of campus) and libraries focused on specific fields, such as art history, earth science, and music. The Library offers countless resources and perks, including: Expert help from librarians. Tens of thousands of films to stream. Free e-books and audiobooks on OverDrive. A bounty of employment opportunities for students. A collection of more than 14 million volumes. Learn how to get the most out of the Library as a new student, and visit lib.berkeley.edu for more information.
Categories: Campus Departments
Summary: Campus libraries support student studies, provide a space for learning, and a community for our scholars ....

Name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Career Center
Description: We fulfill our mission through: A wide range of partnerships with employers, graduate schools, and campus academic and administrative departments that contribute to the breadth and effectiveness of our services. State-of-the-art technology that maximizes accessibility to our resources and services. First-class customer care that represents the highest level of customized quality service, demonstrated by: Providing accurate and consistent information and support, communicating in a positive and friendly manner Responding promptly and effectively to customer needs, always respecting others‚Äô diverse approaches and interests Embracing flexibility, anticipating opportunities for change, and constantly seeking ways to improve our services.
Categories: Campus Departments
Summary: We prepare undergraduates, graduate students, and alumni to make informed decisions about their futures by providing comprehensive resources, programs, and counseling on career development, internships, employment, and graduate school.

Name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Gender Equity Resource Center
Description: The Gender Equity Resource Center, fondly referred to as GenEq, is a UC Berkeley campus community center committed to fostering an inclusive Cal experience for all. GenEq is the campus location where students, faculty, staff and alumni connect for resources, services, education and leadership programs related to gender and sexuality. The programs and services of the Gender Equity Resource Center are focused on four key areas: Women* Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Queer+ (LGBTQ+) Sexual Harassment & Sexual Violence Men Through our many programs and services we strive to: Provide a space for respectful dialogue about sexuality and gender Illuminate the interrelationship of sexism, homophobia and gender bias & violence Create a campus free of violence and hate Provide leadership opportunities Advocate on behalf of survivors of sexual, hate, dating and gender violence Foster a community of women and LGBT leaders Be a portal to campus and community resources on LGBT, Women, and the many intersections of identity (eg race, class, ability, etc...) The Gender Equity Resource Center (GenEq) is a part of the Centers for Education Justice and Community Engagement, which is a cluster in the Division of Equity & Inclusion, University of California, Berkeley. *We welcome all who experience life through the lens of woman in body, spirit, identity - past, present, future, and fluid.
Categories: Admin, Campus Departments
Summary: GenEq is the campus location where students, faculty, staff and alumni connect for resources, services, education and leadership programs related to gender and sexuality. We are committed to fostering a safe, equitable and inclusive experience for all.

The UC Berkeley Public Service Center connects ideas, resources, and people to act for social justice, build healthy communities, and foster life-long commitments to public service.

Name: Campus Evangelistic Fellowship - Mandarin Group üíô

Name: Capital Investments at Berkeley
Description: Founded in 2012 and reincorporated in 2014, Capital Investments at Berkeley was created by and for students striving to obtain real trading experience and provide investors superior risk-adjusted returns. In a perpetually changing market environment, CIB prides itself in our creative approach to trading, implementing a wide variety of strategies using a large selection of financial instruments. Our investment philosophy is founded on the belief that capital preservation is more important than capital gains and in the long run a dynamic asset allocation and reactivity to market inefficiencies can generate above market returns. Further, we believe that as students, we have a unique perspective and differentiated views on markets, economies, and current events which provide rare opportunities for investors. Finally, we believe that as stewards of capital we have a deep responsibility to consider all stakeholders affected by our decisions, including our investors, employees of publicly traded companies, our communities, disadvantaged groups, the environment, and more. Only through active management and dedicated equity research can these responsibilities be fully materialized in investing. Our team leverages the unique skill-sets of our members and their varied academic and vocational backgrounds to deliver these returns to our partners. CIB draws on the combined experience of our members as employees of investment banks, hedge funds, asset managers, federal regulatory agencies, technology companies, legal firms, and start-ups notably including Morgan Stanley, JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Lazard, BlackRock, Blackstone, Centerview Partners, IMC, JMP Securities, the Federal Reserve, Dodge and Cox, Point72, Bain & Co., Vista Equity Partners, and Google. Our culture is data and performance driven; we combine the financial acumen of our veteran members with the entrepreneurial philosophy of our school to create dynamism within existing investment structures. This creativity and unique synthesis of information is the cornerstone of CIB‚Äôs idea generation. Our portfolio utilizes hedging strategies and a ‚Äúrisk-management first‚Äù approach to realize consistent returns that outperform the market. Trades are made through quantitative evaluation of a risk-reward profile and the ever-changing market environment. Capital Investments at Berkeley‚Äôs long term goals include achieving capital preservation and gains regardless of market conditions, maintaining our loyal investor base, continuing to leverage our extensive alumni network, and providing students interested in finance and investment management real world opportunities to create value and preparation for careers.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Founded in 2012, CIB is a student-run investment fund and finance club at the University of California, Berkeley, dedicated to providing investing knowledge, experience, and training to students and superior risk-adjusted returns to investors.

Name: Capri Club
Description: Capri Club focuses on intentionally teaching the leaders of FicB to take on a greater responsibility within the organization.
Categories: Spiritual Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Capri Club is an organization to equip and prepare leaders to teach and lead the members of FiCB.

Name: Caravan Travel & Style Magazine
Description: Caravan is UC Berkeley's only travel magazine, for which all staffers travel in a group to report on locations determined each semester. It is Caravan Magazine‚Äôs mission to offer travel-minded students the opportunity to create, and in this process of creation, grow as artists and collaborators. Our 25-person team is made up of exceptional writers, photographers, videographers, and designers who dedicate 3+ hours per week to the club over the course of a semester. The magazine aims to offer readers thoughtful interpretations of the scenes our team visits together. We try our best to cover subjects that interest audiences while producing meaningful insight. If you'd like to join our club, we encourage you follow us on Instagram at @caravan.magazine for the most immediate updates, as we typically recruit mid-semester. Our application, past issues, and more information can be found on our website. Feel free to message & dm us with any comments & questions!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Publication Groups, Media & Publication Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Caravan is an on-campus organization that produces a semesterly travel magazine, for which teams of staffers travel to report on locations.

Name: Career Readiness Program at Berkeley üíô
Description: Youth are the future leaders of tomorrow, as they are the future workforce for every imaginable industry. However, there is a present lack of an effective structure that adequately equips students with the tools necessary to work within industry, expecting students to have the self-knowledge to maneuver current systems. We are dedicated to supporting youth career development through hands-on technical experiences and providing youth with a supportive community they can thrive in.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: CRP at Berkeley aims to empower underprivileged students with career experience, by creating a platform that bridges the gap between education and the work industry, paving the way for a new wave of industry leaders.

Summary: The Caribbean Coalition at Berkeley seeks to foster intraregional community and dialogue among graduate students, faculty, and staff members who identify with and/or are in solidarity with Caribbean peoples and support their self-determined futures.

Name: Caribbean Student Association üíô
Description: Caribbean Student Association's purpose is to create a safe and inclusive space that is representative of students of Caribbean backgrounds. As well as to create opportunities to learn about the Caribbean and its many cultures for non-Caribbean interested students.
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: To create a safe and inclusive space for students of Caribbean backgrounds.

Name: Casa Esperanza üíô
Description: Casa Esperanza serves a shelter for women and children survivors of domestic abuse in Ensenada, Mexico. We aid these families by providing financial and emotional support, as well as creating health, wellness, and social empowerment programming to help them regain stability. We plan multiple trips to Mexico throughout the year. We fundraise depending on their specific needs, including funds for cleaning and hygiene products, clothing, bills, and scholarships for higher education. We create health workshops to bring health services to the women and children and to teach them how to maintain healthy practices. We also conduct social empowerment workshops, including career and educational support, to help the families at the shelter regain independence. Our mission is to bring UC Berkeley students of varied professional pathways together to both enhance our cultural awareness and collectively serve those in need.
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Casa Esperanza serves a shelter for women and children survivors of domestic violence near Ense√±ada, Mexico. We serve these families by providing financial and emotional support, as well as creating productive workshops to help them regain stability.

Name: Casa Joaquin Murrieta
Description: Casa Joaquin is home to 36 students per academic year and is conveniently located blocks away from the UC Berkeley campus. Casa Joaquin has a long tradition of supporting and meeting the needs of first-generation, low-income, UC Berkeley students, with the goal of increasing recruitment and retention. Through the support, mentorship, and leadership development curriculum of the Greenlining Leadership Academy, we work to: - empower student leaders of color to advocate for social justice and equity on campus and in their communities- inspire students to fulfill their true potential; nurture and develop leadership skills- foster a positive and healthy university experience- facilitate the development of life-long friendships and professional networks
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Casa Joaquin is a multi-ethnic residential community that supports leadership development and academic success while providing a nurturing living environment for UC Berkeley students.

Name: CASCADE: Community Service
Description: Cascade is a mentorship organization dedicated to developing a culture of compassion, service and empathy. We strive to fulfill our vision through hands-on learning, activities, and applied community service. We started off in 2022 by mentoring elementary school children in Alameda county through an original program specially developed by our members. Our 6-week long program culminated in a capstone project of compiling care packages benefiting various underserved communities in the Bay Area. This year, we are looking to expand our mission and explore other avenues of service, and hope to bring empathy and compassion to a wider audience. Cascade seeks to recruit Berkeley students passionate about engaging in their local communities. This program will offer its volunteers the unique opportunity to develop strong bonds within the Cascade family and beyond.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage
Summary: CASCADE is a mentorship organization dedicated to developing a culture of compassion, service and empathy.

Description: Catholic Students at Cal is the campus-based student fellowship of Newman Hall - Holy Spirit Parish, the Catholic Center for the University. We strive to foster a community where we can grow in faith and fellowship as brothers and sisters in Christ through Bible studies, Rosary group, game nights, and more! We also connect students to other groups of the larger parish community like Newman Grads, the Student Ministry Team, and FOCUS missionaries, among many others. All are welcome! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w1VMVTgi7Po This group [Catholics at Cal] was formerly named [Catholic Students at Cal - Newman Hall] - [9/24/24] [AP]

Name: CED Students of Color üíô
Description: To develop and expand the academic and social support, mentorship, career networking, and advocacy efforts for students of color and other underrepresented students within the College of Environmental Design. Students of color include those who identify themselves as African American, Native American, Asian American, Latina/o, and Pacific Islander. However, CEDSOC is inclusive and embraces all forms of diversity, including LGBTQ students, low-income students, and allies who value and work for equity and justice within low-income communities and communities of color. CEDSOC also promotes and advocates for greater attention and leadership toward social justice and equity within our respective fields. 2025 Board: Presidents: Shruti Venkatnarayan and Noelle Suh Treasurer/Secretary: Mario Valadez Departmental Chair - City Planning: Alex Stern Departmental Chair - Architecture: Departmental Chair - Landscape Architecture: Jose Alfredo Lopez Admissions Chairs: Andrea Lyn Mateo, Lisa Tran, Jamie Noh Diversity Campaign Chair: Events Chair: Julian Rocha International Student Chairs: Nishtha Kashyap Undergraduate Co-Chairs: Jamie Noh and Andrea Martinez

Name: Celli@Berkeley
Description: What is better than a cello? Many, many cellos!! A young and passionate group dedicated to dynamic performances in concert halls and alternative environments, CELLI@BERKELEY is an ensemble comprised of UC Berkeley students who come from a diverse background in musical training. Celli@Berkeley members are involved in multiple academic fields including Music, Physics, Political Science, Biology, Journalism and Computer Science. Celli@Berkeley provides students with the opportunity to perform works outside of the traditional concert hall. By assembling talented young cellists at Cal, Celli@Berkeley strives to highlight the versatility of the cello, inviting audiences to share in a world of music they might not be exposed to otherwise. Collaborations with composers in the Berkeley student and national new music community have led to newly commissioned works. Celli@Berkeley has played classical favorites to pop song arrangements in a variety of performance spaces, including Sproul Plaza, the Berkeley Art Museum, the Berkeley Farmer's Market, ACCI Gallery, and the Berkeley Half Marathon. On sunny days, Celli@Berkeley can be heard performing pop arrangements near Sather Gate as CelliPOP!ÔøΩÔøΩ
Categories: Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Celli@Berkeley seeks to generate new works for the cello ensemble repertoire. As a student organization, our goal is to provide a creative space for individuals to discover their own musical style.

Name: Central Americans for Empowerment at Berkeley üíô
Description: Our mission is to empower folx who identify as Central American to find the right resources to navigate in and out of Cal. We strive to work with other Latinx organizations to ensure that our narratives continue to be heard at Cal and beyond, including advocating for a Central American Studies Department. In addition to creating a space where we can share with one another and learn about our Central American roots, we encourage future members to actively engage in solidifying this organizational space, and collectively work to ensure that it remains at the University of California, Berkeley to welcome future Central American students. Stay updated with current events and announcements on our Instagram: @cafeucb
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Our mission is to help folx who identify as Central American, in building community and successfully navigating higher education. Stay updated with current events and announcements on our Instagram: @cafeucb

Name: Central Asian Student Association at Berkeley üíô
Description: Central Asian Student Association at Berkeley is here to represent and nurture the beautiful culture of Central Asia, countries such as Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and more countries and cultures which are associated with Central Asian culture. In our club we wish to build a strong, diverse and loving community of people that come from a similar background.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Statement of Purpose: The Central Asian Student Association at Berkeley promotes cultural celebration, academic excellence, and community involvement, enhancing the UC Berkeley experience.

Name: Chabad Jewish Student Group at Berkeley
Description: Our student group is committed to providing the Jewish community at Cal with fun and meaningful events and programs! From delicious home-cooked Shabbat meals to High Holiday Services, the UC Berkeley academic community is invited to participate in any and all activities. No matter where you place yourself on the spectrum of Jewish practice, Chabad invites you to enjoy exploring your heritage in a warm, welcoming environment.
Categories: Spiritual Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Open all year round, we provide each and every Jewish student with a home away from home at Cal. Stop by for authentic delicious home-cooked Shabbat meals and experience one of our many ongoing classes and events!

Name: Cheese Club
Description: Cheese Club is a haven for students to convene and enjoy cheese in community. Our mission is two-fold: to explore cheeses from different cultures across the globe, and to use cheese as a catalyst for conversation about the agricultural practices and social impact of today‚Äôs complex food systems. Our club is relaxed and lively ‚Äî come for good tunes, good convo, and CHEESE! Whether you‚Äôre a gruy√®re girl, burrata boy, or compt√© kid, Cheese Club welcomes you.
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Cheese Club is a haven for students to convene and enjoy cheese in community.

Name: ChemE Car
Description: The Chemical Engineering Car team builds a shoebox-sized car powered and controlled by chemical reactions for the annual AIChE-sponsored Chemical Engineering Car competition. Every year, we build two cars to compete at the Pacific Regional against other schools from California, in hopes of qualifying for the National competition. At our most recent competition in Spring 2022 at UCLA, we placed 2nd in the car performance competition, qualifying for nationals, and 1st in the poster competition. At our competition in Spring 2019 at USC, we placed 4th overall in the main competition out of 15 competitors. At our competition in Spring 2018 at UC Irvine, we placed 1st in the poster competition and 2nd in the car performance competition, qualifying for nationals. At UC San Diego in 2017, we placed 4th and 5th out of 12 competitors. We were not able to compete in 2020 due to COVID-19. For the Fall 2022 semester, we will be developing several power sources and control mechanisms, such as a Zinc Air battery, a Hydrogen Fuel Cell, and a Vitamin-C control clock. We hold weekly team meetings and lab work sessions Monday-Friday! If you have any questions, please contact us at berkeley.chemecar@gmail.com. The application process is pretty simple: there is a short written application through a google form. Each applicant receives an invite to a coffee chat. The aim of both these components is to gauge your interest and enthusiasm for the club. We do not require any prior experience and want to give an opportunity to every member of UC Berkeley. For more information about our team, visit our website at chemecar.berkeley.edu! Follow us on Instagram to get the latest team updates at @calchemecar Here are some useful links:- Rules: aiche.org/community/students/chem-e-car-competition-rules- Website: https://chemecar.berkeley.edu- About the teams: TBD CALAPALOOZA:Date/Time: TBDLink: TBD Social with CoC Student Orgs:Date/Time: Monday 8/22/22 @ 3:30 PM - 4:30 PM PDTLocation: College of Chemistry Plaza CoE GBO Tabling:Date/Time: Tuesday 8/23/22 @ 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM PDTLocation: In front of Bechtel INFO-SESSION:Date/Time: Monday 8/29/22 @ 6:30 PM - 8:00 PM PDTLocation: Tan 775 A+B Game Night:Date/Time: Thursday 9/1/22 @ 6:00 PM - 8:00 PM PDTLocation: Tan 775 A+B Social Night:Date/Time: Friday 9/2/22 @ 6:00 PM - 8:00 PM PDTLocation: TBA APPLICATION: TBADue Saturday 9/3/22 @ 11:59 PM PDT
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The UC Berkeley Chemical Engineering Car team builds a shoebox-sized car powered and controlled by chemical reactions for the annual AIChE-sponsored Chemical Engineering Car competition.

Name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Graduate Student Advisory Committee
Description: We seek to accomplish this by organizing events that promote open communication and discussion between graduate students and faculty, benefit the greater Bay Area community, and educate students to succeed both during and after graduate school.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: The mission of CBE GSAC is to foster community and provide both resources and a support network for Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering graduate students.

Name: Chemistry Graduate Life Committee üíô
Description: The Graduate Life Committee UC Berkeley Dept. of Chemistry Email us! | Visit our Website!Facebook | Twitter | Instagram Meetings first Fri. of month 11:00 AM Submit listserv announcements by emailing us!
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The CGLC provides academic, professional and administrative support to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry by advocating for student wellness, spearheading a department-wide diversity initiative, and coordinating social events.

Name: Chemistry Undergraduate Research Initiative and Enrichment at Berkeley
Description: CURIE (Chemistry Undergraduate Research Initiative and Enrichment) is a 2 unit P/NP DeCal class focused on providing inexperienced undergraduates with tools and skill sets that are indispensable to chemical research. Every semester, we take a group of inexperienced mentees with little to no knowledge of what research looks like at Berkeley, and we pair them with experienced mentors currently working in a research group to work on a mini research project. The semester's work is presented at the end of the semester in a poster symposium.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations
Summary: CURIE is a way for undergraduates without research experience to be mentored by undergraduates with research experience.

Name: Chess Club at Berkeley üíô
Description: The Chess Club at Berkeley is the best place to play the game of chess and any of its variants, or learn the game for the first time! We have no membership requirements, welcome players of all skill levels for casual play, and are happy to teach beginners. Join us on Discord to find out about our schedule and talk to our other members. Feel free to ask for games or post your favorite chess puzzles! We meet in person once every week and host a few tournaments throughout the academic year. We also host virtual arenas and are an active team in the Collegiate Chess League (CCL), the online chess league for college students. Join our chess.com club to play online!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Are you interested in playing or learning chess? Join the Chess Club at Berkeley! Players of all skill levels are welcome. We meet once every week in person.

Name: Chi Epsilon - Civil Engineering Honor Society
Description: Dedicated to the purpose of maintaining and promoting the status of civil engineering as an ideal profession, Chi Epsilon was organized to recognize the characteristics of the individual civil engineer deemed to be fundamental to the successful pursuit of an engineering career, and to aid in the development of those characteristics in the civil engineering student. Engineering, the application of scientific principles to the practical needs of society, is assuming a constantly increasing responsibility for the physical well-being of all people, and thus calling for competence of the highest order. This responsibility can be discharged only by a professional group whose members are possessed of a good basic technical ability, intelligence, moral integrity, and effective social poise in their relationship with the larger community of which they are part. To contribute to the improvement of the profession, Chi Epsilon fosters the development and exercise of sound traits of character and technical ability among civil engineers, and its members, by precept and example, toward an ever higher standard of professional service.
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Chi Epsilon recognizes the characteristics of the individual civil engineer deemed to be fundamental to the successful pursuit of an engineering career and aids in the development of those characteristics within civil engineering students.

Name: Chi Omega
Description: This diverse group of women supports and celebrates individual pursuits and interests while remaining united under the common bonds of the fraternity. In joining Chi Omega, our members enrich their college experience by growing as individuals, while also growing together as a sisterhood. Being a part of Chi Omega at Cal means you are among women who inspire you daily and encourage you to be the best you can be. Each woman in our chapter is unique, beautiful, and accomplished in her own way. Contact our President, Julia, at calchiomegapresident@gmail.com, or our Recruitment Chair, Elle, at calxorecruitment@gmail.com for more information. Go Bears, go Greek, go Chi O! Please visit our website, www.calchiomega.com, our Instagram (@calchiomega), or our Facebook (UC Berkeley Chi Omega) for more information!
Categories: CalGreeks Panhellenic Council (PHC) Sororities
Summary: The mission of Chi Omega is to promote lifelong friendships, involvement, scholarship, leadership, and service. Cal Chi Omegas are well-rounded women committed to personal growth and the growth of their sisterhood!

Name: Chicanx/ Latinx Architecture Student Association
