(Formerly Formerly Middle Eastern Law Students Association)
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Middle Eastern and North African Law Students Association (MENALSA) is an organization dedicated to fostering an empowering, holistic community for Middle Eastern and North African (MENA) students at Berkeley Law.

Name: Middle Eastern Business Association
Description: Established in 2020, the Middle Eastern Business Association (MEBA) is the first UC Berkeley business organization focused on harnessing the Middle Eastern/North African community with the resources needed to excel in the workplace. MEBA was founded with the intention of increasing representation in the workforce by fostering an inclusive community and providing professional development resources for the Middle Eastern student population
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MEBA strives to be an organization that provides Middle Eastern students with opportunities to grow and establish connections in the business sector.

Name: Middle Eastern North African Recruitment and Retention Center
Description: MENARRC is an academic resource on campus that supports student self-identifying as apart of the Middle Eastern North African community. Our organization focuses on helping those pursuing a higher education through community socials via recruitment and retention. MENARRC, formerly the Arab Recruitment and Retention Center (ARRC) changed the organization name as a way to make it known that our organization is inclusive of ALL Middle Eastern and North African identifying students.
Categories: RRC - Recruitment & Retention Center, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MENA-RRC is an academic resource on campus that supports those involved and interested in the Middle Eastern community. Our organization focuses on helping those pursuing a higher education through community socials via recruitment and retention.

Name: Military and Veterans at Berkeley Law
Description: Military and Veterans at Berkeley Law's mission is to create a community where veterans can help veterans succeed in law school and beyond. This means, first and foremost, promoting social cohesion among veterans and military service members at the school. Additionally, we seek to develop veteran-specific professional opportunities for our members, as well as host events geared toward educating the wider student body on military-related topics in the law.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: Military and Veterans at Berkeley Law is a group of former, current, and prospective members of the military services who seek mutual support and fellowship.

Name: Mindful Masters
Description: Mindful Masters members and leaders prioritize community building, self-reflection, and mindfulness strategies in order to reduce stress and promote relaxation for graduate students in the School of Social Welfare at UC Berkeley.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: Mindful Masters members and leaders prioritize community building, self-reflection, and mindfulness strategies in order to reduce stress and promote relaxation for graduate students in the School of Social Welfare at UC Berkeley.

Name: Minorities in Health Conference üíô
Description: Hosted by the Black Students in Health Association (BSHA), the Comunidad in Health Equity (CHE), the Pilipinx Association for Health Careers (PAHC), the Asian American Pacific Islander Health Research Group (AAPIHRG), and Cal Undergraduate Public Health Coalition (Cal UPHC), this free conference aims to educate students on health disparities that affect our communities and find ways to decrease these disparities by encouraging and inspiring both high school and undergraduate students to strive toward higher education and ultimately careers in health. Students will have the opportunity to network and interact with a variety of health professionals, medical students, and graduate students from schools throughout the Bay Area such as UCSF and UC Berkeley, attend beneficial workshops, participate in public health discussions, and better equip themselves for their journeys in these competitive career tracks. Additionally, students may have special access to free or greatly reduced MCAT and GRE Prep class by attending the conference and will have access to the UC Berkeley Health Careers Opportunity Program Manager for career and graduate education advising sessions after the conference.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: MIHC aims to educate students on community health disparities and decrease these disparities by encouraging and inspiring high school and undergraduate students to strive toward higher education and ultimately careers in health.

Name: Mixed @ Berkeley Recruitment and Retention Center - MRRC
Description: As a Recruitment and Retention Center, we strive to recruit, retain, and empower students of multicultural/multiethnic/multiracial heritage at UC Berkeley.
Categories: RRC - Recruitment & Retention Center, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Mixed @ Berkeley Recruitment and Retention Center - MRRC (formerly Mixed Student Union - MSU) is committed to recruiting and retaining Mixed students at UC Berkeley.

Name: Mobile Developers of Berkeley
Description: MDB is a vibrant, open community of developers seeking to drive change within and outside of Berkeley. Our community fosters a passion for first-class development, innovative ideas, and continued learning within an inclusive and supportive environment. MDB is a defining part of our Berkeley experience and continues to impact the lives of our members beyond the walls of the university. We strive to be at the forefront of the tech community, providing exceptional services to our clients and cultivating an excitement for technical development at large.
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MDB is the world's largest entirely student-run mobile development organization

Name: Molecular and Cell Biology Cell Developmental Neurobiological Association
Description: MCBcDNA (Molecular & Cell Biology, Cell Developmental, Neurobiological Association) serves the needs of the Molecular and Cell Biology undergraduate community, providing our peers with the resources for success! As a club, we provide a liaison between student and faculty members through a variety of organized events and workshops (e.g. MCB Emphasis Night, Research Night, Med School Night, Summer Opportunities Symposium, and many more). Aside from our duty to the MCB community, MCBcDNA provides a medium for its members to prepare for the professional world. Club members will develop essential social, organizational, and communication skills as they interact with their club peers, plan events for the MCB community, and participate in MCBcDNA.
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MCBcDNA is an MCB department-sponsored student organization serving the needs of the MCB undergraduate community through a variety of events and workshops. Members plan, organize, and execute events for the MCB community.

Name: Molecular and Cell Biology Undergraduate Student Association
Description: mcbUSA works in tandem with the MCB Undergraduate Advising Office (UAO) and other biology-related clubs to provide an excellent student experience at Cal. We are run by a group of driven, passionate, and hardworking MCB students who all want the best for all students in any biology field. We aim to facilitate the formation of relationships between students and faculty, and explore different paths of biological careers in health and industry. By providing valuable resources and hosting a variety of events, we strive to promote the professional and educational development of students at Berkeley. We also organize the annual Summer Undergraduate Research Program to assist students in finding research opportunities. Also check out our semesterly Poster Symposium where undergraduates are given the opportunity to present their research or literature reviews in a formal setting for fellow students, professors, and researchers! We are recruiting this semester! More information about our recruitment timeline and events can be found here: https://mcbusa.studentorg.berkeley.edu/recruitment/
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Molecular & Cell Biology Undergraduate Association (mcbUSA), the original MCB student organization sponsored by the MCB department, is a committee-based student organization.

Name: Molecular Cell Biology Graduate Student Organization üíô
Description: The GSO is organized and run by MCB graduate students, acting as a liaison between the university-wide Graduate Assembly, MCB, and our grad students.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The GSO is organized and run by MCB graduate students, acting as a liaison between the university-wide Graduate Assembly, MCB, and our grad students.

Name: Molecular Environmental Biology at Berkeley üíô
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Molecular Environmental Biology at Berkeley aims to create a community for students majoring in MEB and the broader biology and environmental science communities.

Name: Mongolian Student Association
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations
Summary: The Mongolian Student Association aims to promote the presence of Mongolian culture and art on campus. We support the Mongolian community in the Bay area by volunteering at various events throughout the year. Membership is open to all.

Name: Mood Psychology at Berkeley üíô
Description: As a student organization, we are dedicated to building a supportive community for international students who are challenged by mental problems. We will achieve our goals through the following approaches: 1) helping international students to gain a better understanding of mental health problems and to learn effective self-care methods to manage stress; 2) facilitating international students to communicate their mental difficulties and guide them to different psychological services based on their needs; 3) forming a student-led research group under the guidance of a faculty member that investigates the barriers that prevent the international students at Cal from obtaining the mental health services they need and explore the strategies to address these obstacles; 4) pairing up new international students with current international students to help them build a new support system at Cal. We will also post original mental health articles on social media, host speakers, present workshops, and connect with counseling service on campus. By taking these proactive steps, Mood Psychology hopes to promote mental health for international students and help them thrive in their study abroad experience at Cal.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Mood Psychology strives to improve the psychological well-being of students at UC Berkeley by generating awareness of mental health issues and promoting access to mental health resources.

Name: Motorsport Mechanics of Berkeley
Description: MMoB is dedicated to creating a positive and welcoming community with a shared passion for motorcycles and motorsports. Our goal is to educate students on repairing motor-vehicles and providing students with hands on mechanical engineering experience. We also promote a safe and inclusive environment for those interested in motor vehicles, especially for women because it is a largely male dominated industry.
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MMoB is dedicated to educating students on repairing their own motor-vehicles and providing students with a motorsport community. We intend to educate our members and provide a location and tools to perform repairs.

Name: MotoStudent of California
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MotoStudent of California represents the University of California at Berkeley at the MotoStudent racing competition. It strives to foster a strong sense of community and help its members apply their newly learned engineering skills.

Name: MOVE: AA Community Organizing Fellowship (Formerly known as: MOVE: API Organizing Fellowship)
Description: The MOVE Asian American Community Organizing Fellowship aims to bridge the on-campus and off-campus Asian American (AA) community and develop the next generation of AA community organizers. MOVE facilitates the political consciousness and critical thinking of student fellows through social justice-based experiential learning by placing UC Berkeley students at local community organizations. Through our praxis-based approach to community organizing, we aim to bridge the on-campus and off-campus Asian American community, facilitate critical consciousness among the next generation of community organizers, and shift political conditions both on- and off-campus. MOVE was established in 2017 by Asian American undergraduates inspired by the Third World Liberation Front, the UC Berkeley Public Service Center, and Seeding Change's National Fellowship Program for Asian American Organizing and Civic Engagement. Since its founding, MOVE has served 50 student fellows and partnered with 16 CBOs, and it is currently housed within the Asian American Political Activation program (AAPA) under Asian Pacific American Student Development (APASD). This group MOVE: AA Community Organizing Fellowship was formerly named MOVE: API Organizing Fellowship - 10/5/21 Angelica M.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: MOVE aims to bridge the on-campus and off-campus Asian American (AA) community and develop the next generation of AA community organizers, by placing UC Berkeley students at local community organizations.

Name: Multi-Cultural Greek Council
Description: We, the undersigned Greek organizations have joined together to form this council known as the Multi-Cultural Greek Council at the University of California, Berkeley in order to better meet our individual needs, voice our concerns and promote the greater good of our community. Our official charter date is February 2007. We recognize that there are certain areas of action and programming that can be best carried out by the joint efforts of all such organizations. As culturally based organizations, we strive to promote and uplift our common heritages and history. As a council we shall uphold our commitment to service, scholarship and the values of sisterhood and brotherhood. Member Organizations: 11 Sororities, 6 Fraternities Alpha Epsilon Omega Fraternity*Armenian Interest Fraternity Alpha Gamma Alpha Sorority*Armenian Interest Sorority alpha Kappa Delta Phi Sorority*Asian Interest Sorority Delta Xi Phi Multicultural Sorority, Inc.*Multicultural Interest Sorority Gamma Rho Lambda Sorority*LGBTQ & Ally Interest Sorority Gamma Zeta Alpha Fraternity, Inc.*Latino Interest Fraternity La Unidad Latina Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.*Latino Interest Fraternity Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Inc.*Latina Interest Sorority Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc.*Latina Interest Sorority Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc.*Latino Interest Fraternity Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Inc.*Latina Interest Sorority Phi Lambda Rho Sorority*Multicultural Chicana/Latina Sorority Phi Sigma Rho Sorority*Engineering & Technology Interest Sorority Sigma Epsilon Omega Fraternity*Gay and Queer Interest Fraternity Sigma Omicron Pi Sorority*Asian American Interest Sorority Sigma Pi Alpha Sorority, Inc.*Chicana / Latina Interest Sorority Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority*Multicultural Asian-Interest Sorority
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, CalGreeks Fraternity & Sorority Affinity Groups
Summary: Multi-Cultural Fraternities and Sororities

Name: Music Connection, The üíô
Description: The Music Connection (TMC) aims to provide free, supplemental music tutoring for young musicians in the Berkeley and Oakland area through in-class tutoring and private lessons. By doing so, TMC provides young students with a strong foundation in music, which will help them to develop cooperation, self-confidence, and an appreciation for music. We are an organization that currently has about 70 tutors and continues to grow through our success within UC Berkeley and our surrounding communities. We provide free music lessons to students in the Berkeley community in many different forms. Our tutors are UC Berkeley students from a variety of academic backgrounds, but all with extensive musical experience. TMC is a way for students at Berkeley to become involved in the surrounding community by connecting with their students and sharing the expressive and creative gift that is music. Tutors are given the opportunity to connect with the community, practice music, and hone valuable teaching skills. Our programs include In-Class Tutoring and Private Tutoring. We emphasize tutoring for low-income students who may not have ready access to music lessons. In addition to our two main tutoring programs, we also host free events for the local Berkeley community. Our past events outside of our end-of-semester TMC Recital include College Music Days, Spring Music Festival, and Instrument Petting Zoo. For our College Music Days, we invite BUSD/OUSD students to visit a rehearsal of the UC Berkeley Symphony Orchestra or UC Berkeley Wind Ensemble and play along. Every April, we host a Spring Music Festival, during which students can perform a piece for UC Berkeley Music Department faculty and receive feedback. On Cal Day, we lead an Instrument Petting Zoo, during which children may try out different instruments.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Music Connection (TMC) aims to provide free, supplemental music tutoring for young musicians through in-class tutoring and private lessons in the Berkeley and Oakland area.

Name: Music Meditation Club üíô
Description: Discover spiritual solutions to material problems through musical mantra meditation, philosophical discussion and free vegetarian food. Everyone and anyone is welcome!The Music Meditation Club at UCB helps enhance and balance out the lives of students through musical mantra meditation, soulful philosophical discussion and sumptuous vegan snacks. We meet every week and have a variety of other exciting events throughout the year. All events are free for everyone!
Categories: Spiritual Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Music Meditation Club invites students to explore higher levels of awareness through mantra meditation, guided breathing, yoga and conscious foods.

Name: Muslim Law Students Association (formerly Berkeley Law Muslim Student Assn)
Description: The Muslim Law Students Association (MLSA) brings together Berkeley Law Muslims of diverse sects, backgrounds, and cultures under a unified community. (formerly Berkeley Law Muslim Student Association)
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: The Berkeley Law Muslim Student Association (BLMSA) brings together Berkeley Law Muslims of diverse sects, backgrounds, and cultures under a unified community.

Name: Muslim Mental Health Initiative üíô
Description: The purpose of MMHI is to provide mental wellness programming and services to the Muslim community at UC Berkeley. MMHI creates a partnership between the Muslim Student Association, Counseling & Psychological Services (CAPS), and Khalil Center, a psychological and spiritual community wellness center pioneering the professional application of Islamic spiritual tradition to modern psychology. Khalil Center strives to provide culturally and spiritually congruent, professional, accessible, and affordable mental health care for all. Grounded in Islamic traditions, Khalil Center aims to lead professional clinical care, education, and research in advancing holistic mental and spiritual wellness. Khalil Center provides individual, family, and group psychotherapy; community workshops and seminars; and cultural competency training for mental health providers working with Muslims. As a part of MMHI, Khalil Center counselors will provide on-campus services focusing on the promotion and destigmatization of Muslim mental health and prevention, such as, but not limited to: drop-in consultation hours, biweekly support groups, cultural-sensitivity trainings for CAPS staff, and workshops throughout the semester. These efforts are all tied to spirituality, including addressing Islamophobia, stress management, time management, mitigation of depression/anxiety, relationships, suicide/violence prevention, community development, and more.
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose of MMHI is to provide mental wellness programming and services to the Muslim community on campus. MMHI creates a partnership between Muslim students, CAPS, and the Khalil Center to provide psychological wellness resources.

Name: Muslim Student Association
Description: The Muslim Student Association (MSA) at the University of California, Berkeley originated to bring together Muslims of diverse backgrounds and cultures under one unified, organized, proactive community. The MSA stands upon the principles of Islam, including inclusiveness, responsibility, and action. As an organization focused to support and uplift Muslim students at UC Berkeley, we strive to remain inclusive of all who wish to understand, appreciate, and practice their Islamic faith and live without compromising their morals and beliefs. The MSA engages in educational initiatives, open to the general public regardless of faith background, in order to address and clear misconceptions regarding Islam. The MSA also encourages and invites anyone willing to stand up for truth, justice, and peace. Aside from fostering a social community for Muslims, the MSA encourages mental, physical, and spiritual development through an array of spiritual activities, political engagement, academic forums, athletic programs, and charity events. The ultimate goal of the MSA is to encourage both Muslims and non-Muslims to grow intellectually, physically, and spiritually during their tenure at UC Berkeley and to become more enlightened, responsible, and just individuals.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Spiritual Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, ABSA - Budgeted over $7500 Organizations
Summary: Through the worship of Allah and cultivation of a space rooted in Islam, the Muslim Student Association seeks to facilitate interaction and growing experiences for those identifying as Muslim and people of other belief systems.

Name: Muslim Tech Collaborative üíô
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: MTC is a home for Muslims in the tech space to collaborate on building technical projects to solve problems, educating the youth with tech skills, and leveling up their careers through our professional network and entrepreneurial resources.

Name: Muslims of Haas
Description: Muslims of Haas (MoH) is a dynamic business affinity group that aims to establish a vibrant network and community for undergraduate students, graduate students, and alums within the Haas School of Business who identify as Muslims. Our primary focus is to foster mentorship and facilitate job placement while actively advocating for the advancement and inclusion of Muslims in the business world. At the core of our mission, Muslims of Haas is dedicated to meeting the unique needs of our community members within a business context. We provide a supportive environment that fosters professional and personal growth through tailored programs and initiatives. These include mentorship opportunities, career development workshops, industry panels, networking events, and entrepreneurial endeavors. Our vision extends beyond fulfilling immediate needs. Muslims of Haas aims to cultivate a strong internal foundation that offers valuable resources to our members, empowering them to excel in their academic pursuits and future careers. In addition, we strive to establish enduring partnerships with university administration, industry leaders, and relevant organizations both on and off campus. By building these connections, we aspire to elevate the influence and recognition of Muslims of Haas as a respected and influential business group within the Haas School of Business and the broader business community. We firmly believe in the power of collective ideas and contributions. Muslims of Haas actively encourages community members to share their insights and initiatives, fostering an environment of collaboration and innovation. We provide opportunities for individuals to lead central projects and delegate responsibilities to committees and community members based on their expertise and capacity. By engaging our members, we ensure that Muslims of Haas remains a dynamic and responsive organization, consistently providing valuable support and opportunities. Serving on the Muslims of Haas board is an exceptional opportunity for driven community members to develop as business leaders. Board members will acquire invaluable skills in strategic planning, organizational management, effective communication, and entrepreneurial thinking. In addition, through their involvement, outstanding community members will gain firsthand experiences that will equip them to become influential leaders within the business world, championing the interests of Muslims and promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion in the business community. Muslims of Haas is committed to fostering an inclusive and empowering environment for Muslims pursuing careers in business. We are dedicated to supporting our members' personal and professional growth, building a strong network, and advocating for positive change in the business world. Together, we strive to create a lasting impact within the Haas School of Business and beyond.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Muslims of Haas (MoH) champions Muslim inclusion in business, focusing on mentorship, placement, and growth within Haas and beyond.

Name: Mycology Club at Berkeley
Description: Specifically this clubs hopes to: Foster individual scientific development and a community around mycology. Encourage every club member to interact with mycology how they desire. Our calendar will be populated with events from all other California mycological associations. Foster more of a Socratic learning experience in which it is encouraged to generate individual projects that will help interaction with mycology and the natural world. This could range from learning how to ID Fungi to making art!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Environmental & Sustainability Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: We intend to create a space for students interested in mycology to hone their mycological and biological skills and enjoy mushroom related fields such as taxonomy, identification, and foraging.

Name: Myopia Control Club at Berkeley (MCC) üíô
Description: Myopia Control Club (MCC) at Berkeley aims to introduce students to the clinical aspects of evidence-based myopia control. By 2050, the prevalence of myopia (nearsightedness) is expected to rise to 50%. Myopia progression causes vision-threatening complications that can be mitigated with corrective lenses, atropine, etc. Guest speakers from Berkeley Optometry, industry and research come to share new developments in myopia control and provide hands-on fitting workshops. We plan to also offer opportunities for student clinicians to assist with patient care and get hands-on experience with key instruments.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Myopia Control Club aims to introduce students to the clinical aspects of evidence-based myopia control. We hold seminars and workshops with hands-on learning regarding the various modalities of myopia control such as atropine and corrective lenses.

Name: Myriad Legal Consulting
Description: Myriad Legal Consulting aims at providing law firms in our area with strategic advice to improve their organizational strategy and identify areas for development in their firm. We utilize startup technology and LegalTech to aid our clients.
Categories: Political & Advocacy Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Myriad Legal Consulting aims at providing law firms in our area with strategic advice to improve their organizational strategy and identify areas for development in their firm. We utilize startup technology and LegalTech to aid our clients.

Name: National Association of Minority Landscape Architects (NAMLA) at Berkeley
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: NAMLA at Berkeley is a student organization aimed to provide space, resources, and community for minority and underrepresented communities in the landscape architecture field.

Name: National Lawyers Guild, Berkeley Law Chapter
Description: National Lawyers Guild (NLG), Berkeley Law Chapter, seeks to bring together law students dedicated to using the law to advance civil rights and social justice. NLG Berkeley Law is a chapter of NLG, a national bar association of progressive and movement lawyers, law students, legal workers, and jailhouse lawyers who have long acted as the legal arm in social justice movements challenging the systemic criminalization of poverty and race. NLG Berkeley Law supports the objectives of NLG, as articulated in its Constitution. Our aim is to create a collective space of action for those dedicated to protecting and expanding the civil rights and liberties of the masses in the face of persistent attacks upon them. This includes ensuring the safety and dignity of the working class, people of color, immigrants, women, LGBTQIA+ and gender non-conforming people, people with disabilities, and people experiencing poverty and homelessness. As an anti-racist, anti-capitalist, and anti-imperialist collective of students, we stand in solidarity with global struggles for self-determination from Ferguson to Palestine. We are committed to using the law as an instrument for the protection of all people until a system of true justice is achieved.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: National Lawyers Guild, Berkeley Law Chapter is a chapter of NLG, a national bar association of progressive and movement lawyers, law students, legal workers, and jailhouse lawyers who have long acted as the legal arm in social justice movements.

Name: National Optometric Student Association
Description: The National Optometric Student Association (NOSA) is the student extension of the National Optometric Association (NOA). NOSA is a service organization open to all and dedicated to providing the delivery of effective and adequate eye care to minority and underserved communities. In addition, NOSA creatively markets the field of optometry in an effort to increase recruitment and retention of underrepresented minorities into the profession. The association shall strive to stimulate and encourage high professional, intellectual, and social relationships with members of optometric programs as well as other health professional student organizations.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: NOSA is a service organization open to all and dedicated to providing the delivery of effective and adequate eye care to minority and underserved communities.

Name: National Organization of Minority Architects Students
Description: What is NOMAS? NOMA stands for the National Organization of Minority Architects, an organization dedicated to giving a platform for minority architects to advance their place in the architectural industry, fight social and environmental injustices (not necessarily limited to architecture), and bring unity to a diverse body through shared visions and goals. NOMAS is the NOMA representative for Student university chapters. Learn more about NOMA here: https://www.noma.net/about-noma/ and established NOMAS chapters here: https://www.noma.net/nomas-chapters/ Learn about SFNOMA here: http://www.sfnoma.net/ Why does Berkeley need NOMAS? And why now? Berkeley is famous for its student involvement with the social discourse and the individual unlearning processes of biases and stereotypes. However, the Architecture students of the CED represent a passionate, yet frustrated student body, regarding the diversity of architects studied, redundancy and hypocrisy in the curriculum, and the treatment of peers in the LGBTQ+ community. The CED has one of the most diverse architecture student bodies nationally; however, that statistic is not an excuse for an unsatisfactory student experience, academically and socially. Today, at the height of the BLM Movement, is a perfect opportunity for students and faculty to raise a NOMAS Chapter and foster productive dialogue for the benefit of the student experience. For more information or any questions, please fill out our interest form: For more information, please fill out our interest form: https://forms.gle/yPSR2gKaDRzEkPxT6
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: We are dedicated to giving a platform for minority architects and students to advance their place in the architectural industry, fight social and environmental injustices, and bring unity to a diverse body through shared visions and goals.

Name: National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC)
Description: To stimulate the member organization to foster and sponsor projects which will raise the educational, moral and cultural consciousness of the campus and community. Member Organizations: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. - Alpha Epsilon Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. - Rho Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc. - Gamma Alpha Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc. - Epsilon Mu Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. - Kappa Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. - Beta Psi Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. - Omicron Psi Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc. - Gamma Beta
Categories: CalGreeks Fraternity & Sorority Affinity Groups
Summary: To develop unity and cooperation among the Greek letter organizations. To promote and coordinate a positive image for the individual NPHC member organizations and for the NPHC itself.

Name: Native American & Indigenous Business Association üíô
Description: The Native American & Indigenous Business Association (NA&IBA) is a student affinity group at UC Berkeley Haas that aims to: Promote the success of Native American and Indigenous students. Raise awareness of issues facing Native and Indigenous communities within business, education, and policy. Build a culture of unity, respect, and cooperation‚Äîboth among Indigenous students, and between them and the broader Haas / MBA community.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Haas MBA RSO, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: NA&IBA is a community of business students that seeks to promote the success of Native American & Indigenous students, create awareness around Native issues, and foster a positive culture of unity, cooperation, and respect.

Name: Native American Law Students Association
Description: The Native American Law Students Association (NALSA) at Berkeley Law strives to support Native American law students, enhance campus discourse on federal Indian law and issues affecting Indian Country, and foster a strong, inclusive community built on unity, cooperation, and respect. As an academic, professional, and social resource for Native law students and allies, NALSA seeks to form and maintain relationships with alumni, Berkeley Law faculty, other affinity groups on campus, attorneys that work with Indian Country, and the local Native community to advance its mission. Through professional development programming, social events, and mentorship opportunities, NALSA supports the prosperity of its members, pursues opportunities for engagement with federal Indian law and the Bay Area Native community, and creates a supportive community for Native students and their allies at Berkeley Law. NALSA at Berkeley Law is an active chapter of the National NALSA.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: NALSA at Berkeley Law strives to support Native American law students, enhance campus discourse on federal Indian law and issues affecting Indian Country, and foster a strong and inclusive community.

Name: Natural Hair Collective üíô
Description: The Natural Hair Collective‚Äôs mission is to empower black students to embrace their natural hair's beauty through our decal class, our community-wide hair workshop events, and a published guide. As a publications & cultural RSO, we foster community and creativity by: Publishing an online natural hair guide that publicizes on/off-campus braiders, hairstylists, and barbers specializing in curly and afro-textured hair, etc. Facilitating a decal class discussing and exploring the intersection of natural hair and the black experience. With this class, we hope to teach students the history and stigma of Black Hair, the traditional hairstyles of the African Diaspora, how to love their natural hair, how to care for their natural hair, and how to do select protective styles. Hosting campus community-wide events allowing students to learn curly hair tips and be in community with each other (our events are open to all students, and we hope to see you there)! Our goal is to educate students about Afro-textured hair, championing self-love, confidence & black pride in the process! Follow our Instagram & TikTok to find out more ways to get involved in our club!
Categories: Media & Publication Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category, Black/African American Student Community
Summary: NHC‚Äôs mission is to empower black students to embrace their natural hair's beauty through classes, events, and a published guide. We stand for inclusivity, authenticity, and self-discovery, championing self-love, confidence & black pride!

Name: Natya at Berkeley
Description: Founded in March 2013, Natya is UC Berkeley's premier Indian classical dance team. We perform locally for cultural events and compete nationally in the collegiate Indian classical dance circuit. We proudly craft and choreograph each of our award-winning pieces ourselves. Natya at Berkeley was the reigning national champions of the origins circuit in 2023 and 2024. Past Awards: Origins 2024 - 1st Place Mayuri 2024 - 1st Place Laasya 2024 - 1st Place Origins 2023 - 1st Place Mayuri 2023 - 1st Place Laasya 2023 - 3rd Place Origins 2022 - 2nd Place Laasya 2022 - 1st Place Mayuri 2020 - 1st Place Hansini 2020 - 1st Place Laasya 2019 - 1st Place Hansini 2019 - 2nd Place Dhirana 2019 - 1st Place and Most Traditional Award Our dancers are a diverse group of UC Berkeley students who hail from all over the country and abroad, but are united by our love to practice and perform classical Indian dance. Natya auditions are held at the beginning of each Fall semester. https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChg5GUXTf9P45DJGV0qQpPw/playlists
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Natya at Berkeley is UC Berkeley's Indian classical dance team. We aim to cultivate artistic talent and cultural awareness by performing locally and at nation-wide intercollegiate competitions. Auditions are held at the beginning of each Fall semester.

Name: Nazakat at Berkeley
Description: Much of the campus population and even the greater Berkeley population recognizes the talent of Nazakat at Berkeley, formerly known as Kathak at Berkeley, a dance team trained in the ancient North Indian classical dance known as Kathak, and invites us to perform and even compete. We are known for our use of contemporary music in addition to classical music to accompany our intricate footwork, complex hand gestures, and facial expressions in self-choreographed routines, as well as for our extraordinary level of synchronization. With our unique style of dance, we plan to collaborate with other student performing arts groups on campus. We welcome all Cal students who are trained in Kathak to join us in spreading the joy of dance and appreciation of our unique genre.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Cal's Premier Kathak Dance Team!

Name: Needles to Neurons at Berkeley
Description: We aim to cultivate the public on the importance of neurosurgery and to inspire a newfound interest in neurology. We exist to bring awareness to neurological disorders and how practice and presentations can strike a passion for surgery.
Categories: Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: We exist to bring awareness to neurological disorders and how practice and presentations can strike a passion for surgery.

Name: Nepali Student Association at Berkeley üíô
Description: By bringing together all Nepali students on the Berkeley campus, we wish to promote the Nepali heritage throughout the campus and its students. We wish to further diversify the Nepali heritage in the Berkeley campus by assisting other Nepali students in schools and community colleges through community outreach and mentorship activities. We also strive to join hands with other organizations and partake in various programs to benefit the student population at large.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Promote Nepalese culture and further diversify the Berkeley campus through peace and understanding.

Name: Net Impact at Haas üíô
Description: The purpose of this club is to mobilize a new generation to use their careers to drive social and environmental transformational change on campus, in their workplaces, and in the world. Net Impact‚Äôs mission is to connect like-minded individuals who aim to use business as a force for environmental and social good by providing events and programming for members to connect, learn, and collaborate.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Haas MBA RSO, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose of this club is to mobilize a new generation to use their careers to drive social and environmental transformational change on campus, in their workplaces, and in the world.

Name: Net Impact Berkeley
Description: Net Impact Berkeley (NIB) is the UC Berkeley undergraduate chapter of Net Impact, an international organization of over 100,000 students and professionals with the shared goal of creating a more socially and environmentally sustainable world through responsible business practices. In addition to being an ASUC-sponsored registered student organization, we have also been sponsored by the Haas School of Business and the Center for Responsible Business. Every semester, we work on several impact-driven strategy consulting projects for all kinds of clients operating in a wide range of industries/areas. Our project teams (typically 5 people) consist of several consulting associates led by a project manager, and are the core component of the NIB member experience. Beyond our consulting work, we also provide a wealth of academic & career resources, training programs, learning opportunities, and other initiatives to advance our members' personal growth and professional development. NIB is a tight-knit social community‚Äîour members frequently organize fun events and activities with each other and also make connections within our network of nearly 250 alumni. We recruit new undergraduate students from all majors and backgrounds every semester and do not require any prior consulting or business experience. Please visit our website for more information on our work and how to apply.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Net Impact Berkeley is a premier undergraduate student consulting group at UC Berkeley focusing on sustainability and social impact strategy projects for social enterprises, businesses, and non-profits.

Name: Neuroscience Club at Berkeley
Description: Purpose: The Neuroscience Club at Berkeley intends to bring together students who are interested in neuroscience and its related fields, such as biology, cognitive science, and more. We aim to create a collaborative atmosphere where members can gain a deeper understanding of neuroscience, share their interests, and inspire one another through opportunity and creative learning. Diversity in neuroscience: NCSB will explore the wide range of neuroscience topics, ranging from biological aspects to computational technology. This diversity will offer members a scope of the entire field of neuroscience. Connections: Our club will provide presentations and panels with PhD students and current undergraduate neuroscience students to provide valuable insights into the field and highlight the impact of neuroscience. Development: To aid in the personal development of each member, NCSB will offer workshops on skills such as building strong resumes, crafting emails to potential mentors, and navigating all opportunities available in the field of neuroscience. Collaboration: This club will offer networking opportunities and foster community between members and professionals who are in the field. We will share resources, experiences, ideas as we support each other‚Äôs development and careers in neuroscience.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The Neuroscience Club at Berkeley serves as a community for all students that are interested about the field of neuroscience and other related fields. We aim to create an inspiring, collaborative atmosphere that involves opportunity and resources.

Name: Neurotechnology at Berkeley
Description: Neurotech@Berkeley is UC Berkeley‚Äôs premier neurotechnology organization. üß† We are a community of passionate and intellectually curious minds doing all things brain-related: from engineering innovative solutions to the biggest problems in neurotechnolgy through software, hardware, and wetware, to educating the Berkeley community with our student-run neurotechnology DeCal (‚ÄùIntroduction to Neurotechnology‚Äù); from developing top-notch engineering solutions for industry partners to publishing mind-blowing thought pieces in our own magazine; from hosting inspiring talks from neurotech experts to co-organizing the annual California Neurotechnology Conference. If you're passionate about brains, we are the community for you! To find out more, please visit our website (neurotech.studentorg.berkeley.edu / brainlikeberkeley.com) and come talk to us in the first two weeks of every semester on Sproul Plaza, and stay up to date with our events through Instagram (@calneurotech)! Related Words: Brain, Neuro, Technology, Neuroscience, Pyschology, Cognitive Science, BCI, BMI, EEG, MRI, Imaging, Engineering, Electrical, Hardware, Mechanical, Biomedical, Bioengineering, Software, Signal Processing, Machine Learning, ML, AI, Wetlab, Academic, Research, Conference, Innovation, Entrepreneurship, Industry, Consulting, Writing, Edit, Publish, Podcast, Brain Like Berkeley
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: As Berkeley‚Äôs premier neurotechnology org, we're a community of passionate minds doing all things brain-related: building BCIs, educating through our DeCal, hosting exciting events, publishing magazines, and consulting. Click to find out more! üß†

Name: NewSpace at Berkeley
Description: NewSpace at Berkeley is a student organization dedicated to space education, career development, and fostering innovation at UC Berkeley. The club provides opportunities through its NewSpace Entrepreneurship DeCal course, organizes major events like the Berkeley Space Symposium, and connects students with industry professionals for mentorship and networking. By bridging technical and business aspects of the NewSpace economy, it helps students gain hands-on experience and prepare for careers in the space industry.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: NewSpace@Berkeley connects the Berkeley student community to the emerging commercial space industry. We aim to connect and educate students from all majors about the opportunities currently available to them in the NewSpace economy

Name: Next Generation Consulting at Berkeley
Description: NextGeneration Consulting (NGC) is a student-run management consulting organization that provides leading-edge solutions to clients of various sizes and industries. At NextGen, we recognize how diversity is now more paramount to success than ever before. By providing hands-on experience to our members, we help mold better-qualified students, inside Berkeley-Haas and beyond.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: We are a student club that provides strategic consulting for clients in all industries and aims to improve access to the business experience for everyone.

Name: Nigerian Students Association
Description: Special focus will be placed on Nigerian heritage, culture, and community; however, the organization promotes solidarity and positive learning environments across different cultures and institutions. It serves as a home away from home for those aiming to further explore their Nigerian roots, while also serving as a welcoming, engaging space for others to learn and experience. Through the multitude of culturally-inspired events, activities, and programs, NSA aims to bridge the gap between Black Americans, children of African immigrants, and the greater Cal community so that we can begin to develop a better understanding of each other and embrace our similarities rather than focus on our differences. Check out a recap of one of our biggest events The Wedding Party hosted on March 16th, 2024! We were able to host around 400 people across the Bay Area and showcase Nigerian Culture https://www.instagram.com/reel/C6zknxMPA3Q/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link&igsh=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: A supportive space for Africans and those interested in Nigerian culture. It strives to promote cultural diversity, celebrate Nigerian heritage at Cal, and challenge common misconceptions about Africa typically broadcasted in the media.

Name: Nikkei Choral Ensemble
Description: Do you like to sing? Enjoy making friends? Have a favorite vegetable? Well then NiCE might be the group for you! Nikkei Choral Ensemble (commonly known as NiCE) is an all-inclusive a cappella group that arranges and performs primarily Japanese and English songs. We take beatboxers and singers in all vocal parts, so if you are interested in learning more, please reach out to us at nikkeichoralensemble@gmail.com. No Japanese knowledge required (:
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Nikkei Choral Ensemble (NiCE) is an a cappella group that arranges and performs Japanese and English songs and loves having fun!

Name: Nikkei Student Union üíô
Description: UC Berkeley's Nikkei Student Union, founded in the spring of 2002, is the biggest Japanese-American interest organization on campus. We are a one of a kind organization melding our interests in our Japanese American heritage with social and community events. And no, you don't have be Japanese to join! We put on events such as an annual Day of Remembrance, Matsuri, craft and cooking socials, and organize volunteer opportunities with various Bay Area organizations. We also have joint socials with different student groups. Whether you are interested in getting involved in the JA community, looking to make friends, or want to play sports, we offer a variety of options for you. So feel free to check out our club. Follow our instagram for the latest news! @BerkeleyNSU
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: UC Berkeley's Nikkei Student Union is the largest Japanese-American (JA) interest org. on campus. We incorporate our JA heritage in social and community events through the semester. And no, you don't have be Japanese to join! Everyone is welcome

Name: NODE üíô
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: NODE‚Äôs goal is to increase incoming numbers and retention of URM graduate students at UC Berkeley in the Chemistry Department by providing mentorship and building a better community to aid in supporting our graduate students.

Name: Noetherian Ring, The
Description: The Noetherian Ring (NRing) is a member-run organization that supports gender-minority graduate students, postdocs, professors, and staff in the Mathematics Department of the University of California at Berkeley.The goal of this group is two-fold. One is to indicate a presence of women and gender minorities in the math department and provide information for students potentially interested in pursuingmathematics. The other is to provide a network for women in the UC Berkeley mathdepartment and facilitate social and professional development activities.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: The Noetherian Ring specifically organizes for women and gender minority students at the graduate level and above in mathematics who are affiliated with UC Berkeley.

Description: NISA brings together the North Indian community at Berkeley by creating inclusive events/a space where people of this group can meet/interact with one another. We plan to run a dance competition where teams can perform Raas, a North Indian dance style.

Categories: Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage
Summary: We‚Äôre a lower-voices a cappella group known for our fun performances and fresh takes on popular songs! Since our founding in 2000, we‚Äôve gone million-view-viral on YouTube multiple times, released an album entirely composed of original songs, and more!

Description: We take on strategy projects from clients across all industries. Our interdisciplinary teams of undergraduate consultants work closely with clients to understand their unique needs and goals, and develop customised solutions to address their challenge.

Name: Nuclear Is Clean Energy Club üíô
Description: We aim to educate club members, UC Berkeley students, and members of the public aboutnuclear reactors, waste, and technology. Through tabling and other events, we will engage withmembers of the community about the use of nuclear power when building carbon-free powergrids. The ultimate goal of this club is to engage the campus community in a discussion of howbest to use nuclear technology in the pursuit of a better world.

Summary: The central missions are to facilitate direct student-faculty communication and curate enriching graduate experiences. NST GradSAC offers student leadership positions and organizes social events to strengthen community ties and encourage networking.

Name: Oakland Asian Student Educational Services üíô
Description: As a small mentoring program who served under-resourced children in Oakland, Oakland Asian Student Educational Services (OASES) has grown into an organization of 150 volunteers that serves Lincoln and Franklin Elementary Schools in Oakland. We mentor over 400 elementary school children each year regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual identity, or religious belief. OASES's vision is that all students in the public education system reach their fullest potential and are supported to achieve success in school, careers and civic life. OASES achieves this by empowering youth with limited resources through education, mentorship, and service to strengthen the Oakland community. As a project of EBAYC (Where young people grow, thrive and lead!), we guide youth to be safe, smart, and socially responsible.
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: OASES was founded in 1983 by a group of UC Berkeley undergraduates who wanted to provide a critical safety net for youth living in Oakland‚Äôs Chinatown.

Name: Ocean Society of Berkeley üíô
Description: Ocean Society of Berkeley is an ocean interest club that focuses on fun, educational, and hands-on events that connect Berkeley students with the Bay Area community and the outdoors. Join our Slack or email list for updates on meetings and events, as well as cool ocean-related news and articles! During Fall 2025, we meet on Wednesdays at 6:30pm at McCone Hall. Everyone is welcome! Fill out this form to receive our emails about meetings and trips! Follow us on Instagram: @caloceansociety
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Ocean Society of Berkeley is an organization that promotes ocean awareness, environmentalism, and outreach while creating a community of students who share an interest in the ocean and related fields.

Name: Older Wiser Law Students of Berkeley
Description: Older, Wiser Law Students provides a sense of belonging and community to non-traditional and second career students, helping them transition to and anchor themselves in the Berkeley Law community. Our objective is to connect students from diverse career backgrounds and to help them thrive in their studies at Berkeley Law by allowing them to share advice and mutual support in an informal setting.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: Older, Wiser Law Students provides a sense of belonging and community to non-traditional and second career students, helping them transition to and anchor themselves in the Berkeley Law community.

Name: Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Inc.
Description: Established with ASUC 11/9/11 SB 137 Fall 2011 After 3 years of hard work, dedication, and perseverance, Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated received recognition by the Pan-Hellenic Council at the University of California, Berkeley. In May of 2011, five strong and dedicated womxn took Berkeley by storm as members of Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated first UC Berkeley line, Alpha line. These womxn came together to create an opportunity for other womxn at UC Berkeley to also find a sisterhood that they could identify with. Although many womxn were unable to join the sisterhood as undergraduates, and become part of the Alpha line, their hard work and dedication is and will forever be recognized.
Categories: CalGreeks Multicultural Greek Council (MCGC) Fraternities & Sororities, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The mission of Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated is to serve and educate people of diverse backgrounds through sisterhood, leadership and guidance.

Name: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.
Description: University of California, Berkeley chapter of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the faculty adviser, in the Science Hall (now known as Thirkield Hall). The three liberal arts students were Edgar A. Love, Oscar J. Cooper and Frank Coleman. From the initials of the Greek phrase meaning "Friendship is Essential to the Soul," the name Omega Psi Phi was derived. The phrase was selected as the motto. Manhood, Scholarship, Perseverance and Uplift were adopted as cardinal principles.U.C. BERKELEY QUES‚Äô HISTORY MILESTONESŒ© Original chapter founded in 1925Œ© First Epsilon Mu line 6-10-83Œ© Epsilon Mu incorporated 9-28-84Œ© 2nd Vice District Representatives ‚Äô90, ‚Äò96, '14Œ© District Chapter of the YearPast Community Service Chapter Activities Include:Œ© Safe-sex & health awareness workshops Œ© Academic programs Œ© High school mentoring and tutoringŒ© Speakers seriesŒ© Feeding the homeless Œ© Campus organization leadersŒ© Voter registration drives Œ© Scholarship fundraisers Chapter Alumni Include:Œ© Past Basileus (President), Sigma Iota Graduate Chapter (Oakland)Œ© Former Basileus, Alpha Rho Graduate Chapter (Berkeley)Œ© Former 12th District Representative, 2012-14Œ© Many actively work in the communityŒ© Senior managers in Silicon Valley Œ© Former NFL football playerŒ© Several are attorneysÔøΩÔøΩ Neurosurgery physician at UCLAChapter AcademicsŒ© 90+% graduation rate (bachelor degrees)Œ© 33% of alums obtained graduate degreesŒ© Weekly study groupsŒ© Scholarship programs
Categories: CalGreeks National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) Fraternities & Sororities
Summary: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc. was founded at Howard University on Friday November 17th, 1911. Manhood, Scholarship, Perseverance and Uplift were adopted as cardinal principles. The fraternity was originally established at UC Berkeley in 1925.

Name: Omicron Delta Epsilon
Description: Omicron Delta Epsilon is one of the world's largest academic honor societies. The objectives of Omicron Delta Epsilon are recognition of scholastic attainment and the honoring of outstanding achievements in economics; the establishment of closer ties between students and faculty in economics within colleges and universities, and among colleges and universities; the publication of its official journal, The American Economist , and sponsoring of panels at professional meetings as well as the Irving Fisher and Frank W. Taussig competitions. Currently, Omicron Delta Epsilon has 669 chapters located in the United States, Canada, Australia, the United Kingdom, Mexico, Puerto Rico, South Africa, Egypt, France, and United Arab Emirates. With such a broad, international base, chapter activities vary widely, ranging from invited speakers, group discussions, dinners, meetings, etc., to special projects such as review sessions and tutoring for students in economics. Omicron Delta Epsilon plays a prominent role in the annual Honors Day celebrations at many colleges and universities. Learn more: http://www.omicrondeltaepsilon.org/aboutus.html
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Omicron Delta Epsilon is an economics honor society that aims to recognize scholastic attainment and honor outstanding achievements in economics, as well as establish closer ties between students and faculty within UC Berkeley's economics department.

Name: Open Project
Description: We are a group of students striving to redefine tech club culture at Berkeley. Open Project is dedicated to creating a space for passionate students to meet and work on projects that make a positive difference in the world - without the unnecessary selective application process. Our mission is to foster an inclusive and welcoming environment where members can collaborate in designing and developing a project they are passionate about, while learning various technical skills and frameworks through hands-on projects. We encourage personal and professional growth through development workshops, guest speaker events, and opportunities to work with real clients.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Open Project is a student organization that strives to build an open community for creators passionate about working on tech projects most meaningful to them, with a focus on data science and software development.

Name: Operation Smile at Berkeley (Formerly Operation Smile) üíô
Description: Every three minutes a child is born with a cleft, and chances are that one in ten of those children will not be able to see their first birthday. Even if these children survive, they will have to face constant battles with social stigma, malnourishment, and speech impediments. But each child deserves to have another chance, to have access to the safe, proper medical care that could help alleviate some of the challenges they face as a result of their condition. This is what Operation Smile is all about. Here at Berkeley, we are determined to make an impact in not only our community by raising awareness, but also globally by raising funds to help children be able to reveal their smile for the very first time in their lives. Operation Smile has approved the Operation Smile at Berkeley Volunteer Program! Our club members will become Volunteer Program Leaders, guiding middle and high school students to create blankets for surgery patients and cards of emotional support for Operation Smile's surgeons, nurses, and social workers the mission trips. The program centers advocacy for cleft condition awareness, as well as a mobilization of youth to enact meaningful change and support for children undergoing cleft surgery around the world. Together, we will make the world smile. This group [Operation Smile at Berkeley] was formerly named [Operation Smile] - [9/23/21] IZ
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Operation Smile at Berkeley is a global organization with medical specialists from over 80 countries that provides surgical services for individuals with congenital conditions of cleft lip and cleft palate.

Name: Optimir Consulting
Description: Optimir Consulting is a non-profit consulting group dedicated to making a positive social impact in the Bay Area and beyond by providing results-driven solutions for non-profits and start-ups. Our student consultants are a dedicated group that come from a variety of academic disciplines. We develop and expand our consultants through fast-paced training and workshops that aim to optimize our client‚Äôs operations. At Optimir, we pride ourselves on making strong connections within our club to provide mentorship and support as students complete their undergraduate degrees.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Optimir Consulting is a non-profit consulting student group that aims to provide innovative and substantial strategy improvements for various industry clients in the start-up and non-profit world.

Name: Optometric Business Management Club of Berkeley (formerly known as Private Practice Club of Berkeley)
Description: Our purpose is to help students prepare for and make the transition from clinical education to the real world, business aspects of private practice optometry. We will inform and educate optometry students what private practice consists of and explore the opportunities, rewards, and challenges of the field. This will be accomplished with the help of guest speakers, student panels, and relevant corporation presentations.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: Optometric Business Management Club at UCB School of Optometry (formerly known as Private Practice Club at UCB School of Optometry)

Name: Orthodox Christian Fellowship at Berkeley üíô
Description: Orthodox Christian Fellowship (OCF) is the official collegiate campus ministry program under the Standing Conference of Canonical Orthodox Bishops in the Americas. There are OCF members with a variety of religious beliefs. We welcome all followers of God, orthodox or not! Please join us on Tuesdays for enjoyable and enlightening OCF evenings: Divine Liturgy, 6:00 PM Warm Dinner, 7:00 PM Spiritual Discussion & Fellowship, 7:40-8:30 PM
Categories: Spiritual Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category

Name: Our Monologues (formerly V-Day at Berkeley)
Description: ‚ÄúOur Monologues‚Äù is a student-led production featuring the real stories of students at UC Berkeley, and sponsored by the Gender Equity Resource Center. The show welcomes all students to participate so long as they are committed to fostering a safe and inclusive space‚Äì with an emphasis upon students who are women*, BIPOC, femme, nonbinary, transgender, SVSH survivors, disabled, and/or queer or allies as well as their relationships to gender, race, sexuality, and other intersections of their identity. Our mission is to end gender-based violence and promote gender equity on our campus and in our world. All proceeds of the show go to organizations around the Bay Area that align with our values. *We welcome all who experience life through the lens of woman in body, spirit, identity- past, present, future, and fluid. Check us out at Calapalooza and our infosessions for more information about the show and how to audition! Also feel free to stop by the GenEq Community space (202 Chavez) or email us at ourmons@berkeley.edu with any questions.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Undergraduate Organizations, LGBTQ+ Student Organizations
Summary: Our Monologue places students with historically marginalized identities at the center. It is the largest educational performance platform for gender-based violence on campus, bringing together a community of healing, liberation, resistance, and education

Name: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics üíô
Description: oSTEM aims to unite the LGBTQ+ students within the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to foster a strong professional and social network as well as to promote awareness of their presence in all communities. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Fall 2025 meetings are Thursdays 7-8PM in the QARC Center (Hearst Annex A15): Please fill out our interest form: https://tinyurl.com/berkeleyostem
