Summary: oSTEM aims to unite the LGBTQ+ students within the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to foster a strong professional and social network as well as to promote awareness of their presence in all communities.

Name: Outlet üíô
Description: Outlet aims to build a unified arts community at UC Berkeley and open access to all visual arts to beginners and advanced artists, thus creating a centralized organization where artists of varying interests and backgrounds can come together and grow creatively and socially.We further serve both the campus community and the wider Bay Area community by providing access to arts education through workshops and classes taught by student studio heads in areas where such opportunities may not be available, such as local schools and hospitals. Outlet also encourages guest studio heads to spread awareness and appreciation for art.Our workshops are held as scheduled from 7-9 pm every Monday. Members may submit works to be showcased on Discord or be featured on our social media pages, as well as hang out with other members during socials. Join us to meet new artists and learn new techniques or mediums in a friendly, open environment!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Outlet aims to provide a space for budding visual artists to develop their skills, showcase their work, and have an outlet for expression. We strive to serve the campus and the larger community by providing open access to the arts and arts education.

Name: Outsiders üíô
Description: California is home to gorgeous mountain ranges, coastal beaches, forests and deserts‚Äì‚Äìyet there is constant lack of diversity and unequal access to nature/outdoor activities. Outsiders is a new outdoor club created by and for people of color. Noticing the lack of diversity and inclusion in outdoor activity spaces on campus, this club was created to break down racial barriers and enrich local experiences for POC-identifying folks looking to spend more time in nature. Outsiders encourages POC-identifying to partake in exciting trips, coordinate passions and hobbies, and connect with others that want to explore our gorgeous state and the outdoors. There will be coordinated trips that explore hiking, backpacking, climbing, kayaking or paddle boarding, and much more.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category, Black/African American Student Community
Summary: Outsiders is an outdoor club created by and for people of color. Members will be encouraged to partake in nature-based activities as well as gain the experiences and knowledge to comfortably lead trips.

Name: Overwatch at Berkeley üíô
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Overwatch at Berkeley focuses on uniting and supporting students who are passionate about Overwatch. We provide a space for students to play together, to learn, and to grow through gaming.

Name: Pakistani Student Association
Description: The Pakistani Students Association (PSA) at UC Berkeley was formed to provide Pakistani/South Asian students a channel through which to raise awareness about Pakistan and promote its deep cultural heritage. We host social, cultural and professional events throughout the year to bring the Pakistani campus community together, aid various humanitarian causes, and bring to light current issues in Pakistani/South Asian society and politics.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: To promote cultural awareness, education, ethnic diversity, and deconstruct myths and stereotypes pertaining to Pakistani peoplehood.

Name: Paleontological Society of Berkeley üíô
Description: The Paleontological Society of Berkeley is a community at Berkeley that connects students interested in paleontology to one another. We meet once a week at VLSB 3007 (Fridays, 5:30-6:30pm) to discuss paleontology news, share student presentations about paleontological topics of their interest, and provide connections into the paleontological research world. We also do field trips to nearby fossil sites and parts of our university's fossil research collections, as well as talk with guest speakers including UC faculty, grad students, and other paleontologists. Anybody interested in anything about ancient life is welcome to attend our meetings! Join our discord server at: https://discord.gg/X2C9RYnGVs
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Paleontological Society of Berkeley aims to connect students interested in paleontology with each other and the UC paleontological community at large.

Name: Palestinian Public Health at UC Berkeley üíô
Description: Palestinian public health is an organization dedicated to global equity, mentorship, and advocacy. We provide marginalized representation in health along with mentorship and heath resources promoting health equity and justice for all. This is a platform for Palestinians on this campus and across the nation as well as an opportunity for those of interdisciplinary backgrounds to learn about health inequities and receive mentorship/career opportunities. Students of all backgrounds and career pursuits are welcome to join! There is no application process and we encourage all interested to fill out our membership form found through this link: tinyurl.com/pphmember24 Feel free to contact us with any questions through email or message us on Instagram (pph.ucberkeley@gmail.com, IG: @ucb_pph)!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Political & Advocacy Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: PPH is dedicated to advocacy and mentorship. We provide Palestinian representation in health, raise awareness of the health inequities Palestinians face, and provide mentorship/career opportunities for underrepresented and marginalized students.

Name: Panhellenic Council (PHC)
Description: The Panhellenic Council (PHC) is the governing body for 13 sorority chapters on campus. Twelve chapters are associated with the National Panhellenic Conference (an umbrella organization for 26 international women's fraternities and sororities), and one is a local chapter, unique to UC Berkeley's campus. Berkeley PHC includes Alpha Chi Omega, Alpha Delta Pi, Alpha Phi, Chi Omega, Delta Delta Delta, Delta Gamma, Delta Sigma, Gamma Phi Beta, Kappa Alpha Theta, Kappa Kappa Gamma, Pi Beta Phi, Sigma Kappa, and Zeta Tau Alpha. The council serves to promote CalGreeks‚Äô core values: leadership, scholarship, friendship, and service. Please visit our website at www.calpanhellenic.com/fallprimaryrecruitment for more information on how to register. The registration link is also linked below.
Categories: CalGreeks Fraternity & Sorority Affinity Groups
Summary: The Berkeley Panhellenic Council is the governing body for 13 sorority chapters on campus. The council serves to promote CalGreeks‚Äô core values: leadership, scholarship, friendship, and service.

Name: Paper Crane
Description: We are Paper Crane, a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that provides weekly creative art workshops at UCSF Benioff Children‚Äôs Hospital in Oakland. Our big aim is to contribute a relief and support system for children who spend a lot of time there. Currently, we are designing and donating art kits to the kids, but we are hoping to begin in-person workshops at local libraries and the hospital! We also want to host workshops on campus for students to destress and have fun! -- In Japanese culture, the crane is referred to as the ‚Äúbird of happiness‚Äù and an ancient Japanese legend promises that anyone who folds a thousand paper cranes will be granted a wish by the gods. Just like folding one paper crane at a time, we hope to spread smiles, one at a time, to create something beautiful. We know that even though a single person (or a single organization) can‚Äôt change the world, changing a single person‚Äôs world for even a moment is worth the effort. -- Through artistic expression, we hope to alleviate some of the burdens of illness and injury and provide these kids with an inclusive environment in which they can feel safe and happy. We believe strongly in the cathartic powers of art, and the ability to empower and spread positivity and community using art as the medium. Hopefully, through our workshops, we can aid the children in their process of healing. -- By recruiting volunteers on campus, we hope to expand to more hospitals and increase the number of weekly workshops to form even more meaningful connections with kids who need it the most. -- If you would like to learn more about our club, we will be holding info sessions towards the beginning of each semester. More information and zoom links on our website and Instagram page: @papercraneatberkeley -- Applications are due at the beginning of each semester and interviews are held on Sat and Sun of the same week. Please email us or DM us on Instagram if you have any questions!.
Categories: Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Paper Crane aims to create a support and relief system for hospitalized children by providing expressive art workshops at hospitals.

Name: Paragon Consulting at Berkeley
Description: Paragon Consulting is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that serves BIPOC entrepreneurs and small businesses by providing pro-bono consulting services. Our mission is to increase the representation of first-generation, underrepresented, and low-income Berkeley students in the consulting practice. The purpose of Paragon is to provide its members with the tools and experience to successfully compete in today‚Äôs demanding workforce while giving back to the small and POC business community.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Paragon Consulting provides BIPOC-owned small businesses in the Bay Area innovative and creative solutions to industry-defining challenges, while providing opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduate students.

Name: Parliamentary Debate at Berkeley
Description: Parliamentary Debate at Berkeley is the most competitively successful student-run debate team in the history of the National Parliamentary Debate Association. We accept members of all experience levels, whether you‚Äôre a former debater or have never seen a debate round before, and the team guarantees that all members can attend tournaments for no personal cost. NPDA is a limited-prep style of debate, with arguments about domestic policy, international relations, scientific research, philosophy, and critical theory. Unlike other types of parliamentary debate, our team focuses more heavily on critical thinking and argument construction rather than speaking style and persuasion. Members compete in partnerships, sharing responsibilities for pre-round preparation and in-round argumentation. Parli at Berkeley will be continuing practices and competition online during the fall. We‚Äôve put together lectures and other resources to get new members on board, and we‚Äôre planning to offer 8-10 practices a week to make sure we can adapt to your schedule.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage
Summary: Parliamentary Debate at Berkeley (PDB) is UC Berkeley‚Äôs NPDA debate team. We provide individuals of all experience levels with the opportunity to successfully compete in intercollegiate parliamentary debate.

Name: Partners In Health Engage at Berkeley üíô
Description: If you are interested in joining for the 2025-2026 academic year, please contact us at pih.engage.ucberkeley@gmail.com. At PIH Engage at Berkeley, we recognize a call to action against vast global health inequity. We leverage our position as members of the UC Berkeley community to support the work of international non-profit, Partners In Health, in improving health outcomes in the poorest regions of the world. We accomplish this through 3 core committees: Advocacy, Education, and Fundraising. We seek to treat not only the symptoms but the causes of vast health inequity, and to do so whilst prioritizing the dignity of patients and partnering with local organizations. We are committed to building a fun and diverse community of individuals from across disciplines, experiences, and skills: all championing the cause of global health. In everything we do we keep the advancement of the right to health at the forefront of our actions.
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: PIH Engage at Berkeley is committed to advancing individuals' right to health locally, nationally, and globally. We accomplish this through 3 core committees: Education, Fundraising & Advocacy.

Name: Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinxs üíô
Description: The Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinxs (P4), is dedicated to the advancement of Pilipinxs, Pilipinx-Americans and People of Color (POCs) in law, business and other professional fields in lieu of the economic, legal and social condition of Pilipinxs and the a Pilipinx-Americans across the United States. We, the core of P4, will develop, empower, and establish strong leaders to combat systems that oppress Pilipinxs, Pilipinx-Americans and POCs generally in said fields. We will strive to build a network of pre-professionals and professionals that persist as a support system after we leave the space. We will encourage and demystify graduate and professional programs while promoting and uplifting underserved communities. We will organize our communities to continue the fight for social, political, legal, economic equality and justice for all; and do therefore ordain and establish our Constitution. P4's Mission is: To support those interested in business, law and other professional fields To establish a community motivated to advance the socio-economic status of POCs via professional development To build a network of pre-professionals and professionals that continues to support one another after graduation To increase diversity in graduate and professional programs, specifically, but not limited to, law and business related programs To encourage career paths and service in all sectors: private, public, and non-profit
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinxs (P4), is dedicated to the advancement of Pilipinxs, Pilipinx-Americans and People of Color (POCs) in law, business and other professional fields.

Name: Patient Advocacy Student Group
Description: Patient Advocacy Student Group (PASG) offers unique patient-centered clinical experiences in partnership with UCSF for students interested in pursuing careers in healthcare. Students have the opportunity to interface with providers and patients while learning clinical technology and systems in partnership with UCSF. PASG promotes patient-centered communication and trains students to advocate for patients. The student group offers professional development and networking opportunities oriented towards healthcare and medicine.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Patient Advocacy Student Group (PASG) offers unique patient-centered clinical experiences in partnership with UCSF for students interested in providing healthcare.

Name: Paws for Mental Health
Description: Paws for Mental Health is an organization that seeks to promote mental health through canine companions. The unconditional love of a dog can relieve feelings of stress, anxiety, and/or depression. However, having a dog is oftentimes not a viable option to students here at UC Berkeley. Our objective is to host regular gatherings and events of local dogs along with their owners and other students to provide a positive and safe space for de-stressing and relaxing. This can allow for students to forget about the daily rigors of academia and unwind. This group Paws for Mental Health was formerly named De-Stress with Dogs - 9/25/20 IZ (PLC)
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Paws for Mental Health is an organization that seeks to promote mental health through canine companions.

Name: Payment for Placements at Berkeley üíô
Description: The purpose of the Payment for Placements chapter at Berkeley (P4P at Berkeley) is to foster community and solidarity amongst graduate students who are required to complete unpaid field placements or internships to graduate.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose of the Payment for Placements chapter at Berkeley (P4P at Berkeley) is to foster community amongst graduate students who are required to complete a field placement or internship to graduate.

Name: Perennial QT Film Club üíô
Description: Perennial is a film club that focuses on LGBTQ+ representation in film and media, holds discussions over these themes, and aims to write and produce short film with those same themes in mind. Our goal is authentic and radical representation, and to create a culture of making films for us by us. We hold discussions about what issues we see present in queer and trans representation today, workshops on using film equipment, and produce up to one film a semester. We intend to be a part of the solution, and create representation through our own short films that incorporate exactly what we think is currently missing.
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, LGBTQ+ Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Our purpose is to write and produce short films with a focus on LGBTQ+ representation and themes. We intend to discuss issues of queer and trans representation in media and use that to create our own original short film scripts.

Name: Perennial: The Undergraduate Environmental Journal of Berkeley
Description: A forum for the Berkeley community to share insights on environmental issues. We hope to encourage student action and scholarship, discuss solutions to critical issues, and promote diversity of identity and opinion in the field. We publish editorial articles and research papers on a wide variety of environmental topics each semester.
Categories: Media & Publication Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: A forum for the Berkeley community to share insights on environmental issues. We hope to encourage student action and scholarship, discuss solutions to critical issues, and promote diversity of identity and opinion in the field.

Name: Period Project at Berkeley, The üíô
Description: Through our three pillars --education, advocacy, and service -- The Period Project at Berkeley is constantly advocating for freely accessible menstrual products, providing menstrual products to those in need, and elevating the conversation about periods by raising awareness on menstrual health.
Categories: Political & Advocacy Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: We are an organization dedicated to fighting period poverty and removing the stigma surrounding menstruation through service, education, and policy.

Name: Perspective Magazine
Description: Perspective Magazine is a student-run publication printed on a bi-annual basis that offers anyone interested in Iran or the Iranian-American diaspora an outlet to explore the Iranian culture and key issues affecting the community. We aim to provide an original and authentic perspective of our heritage by both celebrating the richness of Iranian culture and analyzing it critically. Through our work, we hope to encourage an open and honest dialogue surrounding Iranian society, both among ourselves and throughout the world.
Categories: Media & Publication Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: We're a student-run publication offering anyone interested in Iran or its diaspora an outlet to explore the culture & analyze key issues affecting the community. Our aim is to provide an authentic perspective of the heritage, for ourselves & the world.

Name: Phalanx: Pre-Medical Consulting üíô
Description: The pre-medical path is a hard one - which is why Phalanx is here to help. As an independent, student-run and founded group, we seek to provide free pre-medical consulting, long term mentorship, and a myriad of resources from experienced pre-medical students to incoming freshmen at Cal. We particularly seek to encourage initiative, innovation and the pursuit of unique passions among our clients. In this way, we hope to instill in them the values and skills needed to succeed not only as a pre-medical student and medical school applicant, but also as the future physician-leaders in science, medical technology, and public health.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: An organization dedicated to providing pre-medical consulting services, mentorship, and a network of support to a select group of incoming pre-medical freshmen at UC Berkeley. Services are provided by a team of upperclassmen consultants.

Name: Phi Alpha Delta Law Fraternity, International üíô
Description: Phi Alpha Delta is UC Berkeley's oldest and largest pre-law fraternity, providing its membership with unrivaled leadership experience, tailored professional development, and access to an accomplished alumni network. Involvement in PAD is enriching, not only in terms of professionalism, but also in terms of personal development. As we explore the legal field and take important steps towards law school admission, we learn to work successfully alongside one another, developing broad interpersonal skills, tolerance, and mutual respect for our brothers and sisters. Cultivating Professionalism Our fraternity wants to do more than simply create a space where students interested in the law can come together. We want to provide our members with the skills and knowledge to go on to law school, careers in the legal field, and any other professional aspiration they may have. Through our Membership Development program, our professional events, and our many networking opportunities, members will find themselves graduating with a plethora of tools for their futures. Investing Service Law is not a field solely aimed at making money and gaining influence. Members of PAD find that we put just as much emphasis on the fairness and equity of law. To that end, our members take the skills they've acquired at Berkeley and in our fraternity to help the wider community and make a positive impact in the lives of others. Our Philanthropy committee makes it a point to provide accessible opportunities to reinvest time into making a difference. Promoting Fraternalism PAD may be a place to hone your skills for the future, but ask any member and they will say that one of the most important pieces of PAD for them is the community. By creating an environment where new and old members can get to know each other and form lasting friendships and meaningful connections, our fraternity ensures that, by joining, you become a part of the biggest family at Cal. Encouraging Leadership We take pride in giving members the tools they need to become leaders in the fraternity, on campus, and beyond. After the completion of Membership Development, new members have the opportunity to become more involved by applying to committee directorships. Others take the skills they've learned to become active in other organizations. We've had PAD members take leadership roles in the ASUC, Daily Californian, Undergraduate Political Science Association, Berkeley Project, and many many more. Recruitment Video
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Berkeley Chapter of Phi Alpha Delta Law Fraternity was established to provide its members with unrivaled leadership experience, tailored professional development, and access to an accomplished alumni network, all focused around the legal profession.

Name: Phi Beta Sigma, Fraternity Incorporated
Description: Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity was founded at Howard University in Washington, D.C., January 9, 1914, by three young African-American male students. The Founders, Honorable A. Langston Taylor, Honorable Leonard F. Morse, and Honorable Charles I. Brown, wanted to organize a Greek letter fraternity that would truly exemplify the ideals of brotherhood, scholarship, and service. The Founders deeply wished to create an organization that viewed itself as ‚Äúa part of‚Äù the general community rather than ‚Äúapart from‚Äù the general community. They believed that each potential member should be judged by his own merits, rather than his family background or affluence‚Ä¶without regard to race, nationality, skin tone or texture of hair. They desired for their fraternity to exist as part of an even greater brotherhood which would be devoted to the ‚Äúinclusive we‚Äù rather than the ‚Äúexclusive we‚Äù. From its inception, the Founders also conceived Phi Beta Sigma as a mechanism to deliver services to the general community. Rather than gaining skills to be utilized exclusively for themselves and their immediate families, they held a deep conviction that they should return their newly acquired skills to the communities from which they had come. This deep conviction was mirrored in the Fraternity‚Äôs motto, ‚ÄúCulture For Service and Service For Humanity.‚Äù The fraternity exceeded the prevailing models of Black Greek-Letter fraternal organizations by being the first to establish alumni chapters, to establish youth mentoring clubs, to establish a federal credit union, to establish chapters in Africa, and establish a collegiate chapter outside of the United States, and is the only fraternity to hold a constitutional bond with a predominantly African-American sorority, Zeta Phi Beta (ŒñŒ¶Œí), which was founded on January 16, 1920, at Howard University in Washington, D.C., through the efforts of members of Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity. The Outta Pocket Omicron Psi Chapter was chartered on January 25, 1985 on the campus of the University of California Berkeley by 7 men: Anthony Sykes, James Jackson, Marvin Gibson, Earl Watson, Norman Dawkins, Booker Crisp, Cedric Nellum.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, CalGreeks National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) Fraternities & Sororities
Summary: Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. was founded at Howard University in Washington, D.C., January 9, 1914. Our motto is Culture for Service and Service for Humanity and our principles are Brotherhood, Scholarship, and Service.

Name: Phi Chi Pre-Health Fraternity
Description: We are, first and foremost, a co-ed pre-health interest group for undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley. Within the society, we have a brotherhood between members who share a common goal of entering the health field. Members receive exclusive access to lectures and advice from accomplished guest speakers, including members of the admission board of graduate schools, and to a network of Phi Chi alumni and supporters for informative and career-seeking purposes. Aside from the academic benefits, we are also members of a brotherhood ‚Äì we help students form relationships with each other and within the pre-health undergraduate population through collaboration with groups of similar interests on campus.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: We are, first and foremost, a co-ed pre-health interest group for undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley. Within the society, we have a brotherhood between members who share a common goal of entering the health field.

Name: Phi Delta Epsilon
Description: Phi Delta Epsilon was founded in 1904 by Aaron Brown at Cornell University Medical College. Our UC Berkeley Chapter (CA Iota) was founded in 2007 by Tony Chen and Felix Wong, with the sponsorship of Dr. Bernard Greigo. Today, Phi Delta Epsilon has over 70 medical school chapters and over 50 premedical chapters all over the United States and abroad. Phi Delta Epsilon is UC Berkeley's premier international co-ed medical fraternity. Phi Delta Epsilon not only offers an environment for professional networking opportunities, but also establishes long lasting friendships of brotherhood, sisterhood, and family. Members are offered opportunities to build solid foundations in ethics and philanthropy. Through active participation in leadership workshops, members also develop professional skills pertinent for the path of medicine. We provide members with contacts and resources to help them through their undergraduate career.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Phi Delta Epsilon International Medical Fraternity creates physicians of integrity with a life-long commitment to our guiding principles of philanthropy, deity, and education though fellowship, service, mentoring, and formal training.

Name: Phi Delta Theta
Description: Phi Delta Theta was organized with three principle objectives: The cultivation of friendship among its members, the acquirement individually of a high degree of mental culture, and the attainment personally of a high standard of morality. These objectives, referred to as the Cardinal Principles, have guided over 225,000 men since 1848 when the Fraternity was founded at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. The Fraternity teaches men that these areas of commitment, outlined in The Bond of Phi Delta Theta, are not to be viewed as separate ideals, but as areas of discipline for daily life. Developments intellectually, in leadership, and human service (to name a few) are vital to the men of Phi Delta Theta. A member will support, and in turn have the support of, his brothers as these principles are lived out.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: The oldest continuous chapter at Berkeley. A brotherhood with a rich tradition that emphasizes academics, honor, and fraternal bonds.

Name: Phi Kappa Psi
Description: Over 150 years ago, two college students, William H. Letterman and Charles P.T. Moore, in the college town of Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, were nursing and watching their stricken friends during an epidemic of typhoid fever. Through the long night vigils, an appreciation of the great joy of serving others came into their lives. Calling a number of others to join them, a Brotherhood was founded on February 19, 1852. It flourished, and gradually extended to other colleges and universities throughout the country. Pragmatic idealists, the founders of Phi Kappa Psi sought a new fraternity ‚Äì a fraternity that should complement the work of the university by cultivating those humanities without which the educated man fails of his greatest usefulness, founded upon the great joy of serving others. The centennial anniversary Phi Kappa Psi was at the old home of the Widow Letterman in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, on February 19, 1952. Over 100 members of the Fraternity gathered together for this occasion including three of the grandsons of the Founders. A bronze tablet commemorating the centennial was moved to the Pennsylvania Alpha chapter house. In the Fraternity‚Äôs first 100 years, Phi Kappa Psi had grown to 56 chapters, 40 Alumni Associations and 40,000 initiates. Phi Kappa Psi today has ninety-seven chapters in thirty-four states and the District of Columbia with 4,778 active student members. There have been nearly 113,000 men initiated. Unlike most national fraternities, the constitution of Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity vests control over its affairs in the student members through the election of six of the ten members of the Executive Council and voting control at the GAC. The Endowment Fund of Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity is a foundation that provides financial support for education programs of the Fraternity and financial support through scholarships and grants to its members. The Endowment Fund has approximately $50 million in assets, and ranks largest among the endowments established by other fraternity and sorority organizations.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: The Cal Gamma Chapter of Phi Kappa Psi has grown to be a driving, dynamic force in the campus community. Brothers enjoy a vibrant social calendar, pursue active leadership roles on campus and contribute to various philanthropic endeavors.

Name: Phi Kappa Sigma
Description: The vision of Phi Kappa Sigma is ‚ÄúLifelong growth and development of the Fraternity and its members.‚Äù This focus makes a perfect practice field for growing personally, refining life skills, developing leadership, and experiencing real-world situations in a safe, supportive environment.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities

Name: Phi Kappa Tau
Description: The UC Berkeley Chapter of Phi Kappa Tau‚Ä¢ Was founded in 1921 as the Nu (13th) chapter.‚Ä¢ Has the distinction of being one of the few fraternities on campus to have never lost its charter.‚Ä¢ Boasts 26 spacious rooms in our Chapter house which is owned by the brothers of the fraternity.Our National Chapter:Phi Kappa Tau was founded March 17, 1906 at the University of Miami in Ohio. Since then, 146 chapters have been chartered and over 100,000 men have been initiated into our brotherhood. Philanthropy:The brothers of Phi Kappa Tau work every semester to raise money for the SeriousFun Children‚Äôs Network (formerly known as Hole in the Wall Camps). This organization was founded in 1988 by Phi Tau alumnus Paul Newman. The money we raise helps facilitate camps in 31 countries for children with life-threatening illnesses. Over 100,000 children have attended these camps free of charge as a result of Phi Tau‚Äôs national efforts.Leaders on Campus:Members of Phi Kappa Tau at Berkeley have prominent roles in Berkeley‚Äôs Model United Nations, campus administration, and intramural sports. Brothers of Phi Tau also take part in club sports, boxing, and the Interfraternity Council.More than just a four year Experience:Membership in Phi Kappa Tau not only enhances each brother‚Äôs college experience, but provides opportunities to enrich one‚Äôs life after graduation. Our alumni network flourishes from coast to coast, even showing a presence internationally. Graduates often find work after college as a result of recommendations from other Phi Tau alumni. Moreover, the friendships created within our fraternity last decades longer than the time spent in school.
Categories: CalGreeks Interfraternity Council (IFC) Fraternities
Summary: The UC Berkeley Chapter of Phi Kappa Tau was founded in 1921 as the Nu chapter, and has the distinction of being one of the few fraternities on campus to have never lost its charter. The house has a commitment to brotherhood.

Name: Phi Lambda Rho
Description: On August 14, 2022, a group of 6 Latina/Chicana women established the Iota Chapter of Phi Lambda Rho at UC Berkeley. They brought forth this beautiful organization in order to uplift women of color at Cal through sisterhood, mutual support, & love. We hope that bringing Phi Lambda Rho to Berkeley will create a supportive sanctuary within this historically white-serving institution for the growing number of Latinas on campus to flourish. Phi Lambda Rho Sorority Inc., is a multi-cultural Chicana/Latina sorority popularly known as ‚ÄúRhosas‚Äù or ‚ÄúRhos.‚Äù Sisters of Phi Lambda Rho organize and execute events catered to their four pillars -- Academics, Cultura, Philanthropy, and Sisterhood --throughout the year, making them an active and professional sorority in the community.The sorority serves as a retention group for aspiring young women in college who wish to leave a positive impact in their communities by engaging in service to the community while displaying a sense of cultural pride and fostering life-long bonds. Follow us on Instagram: @ucberkeleyrhosas For more information, contact us at flr.iota.president@gmail.com
Categories: CalGreeks Multicultural Greek Council (MCGC) Fraternities & Sororities
Summary: Phi Lambda Rho

Name: Phi Sigma Rho
Description: Founded in 1984, Phi Sigma Rho is a sorority for women in engineering and engineering technologies with over twenty-five chapters nationwide! Through Phi Sigma Rho, our members develop a lifetime sisterhood. Our Objectives: To foster and provide the broadening experience of sorority living with its social and moral challenges and responsibilities for the individual and the chapter. To develop the highest standard of personal integrity and character. To promote academic excellence and support personal achievement, while providing a social balance. To aid the individual in the transition from academic to the professional community. To maintain sorority involvement with the alma mater and the community through responsible participation. To maintain the bond of sisterhood with alumnae members through communication, consultation, and participation in Sorority functions. For philanthropy, Phi Sigma Rho (both at Berkeley and nationally) works with the Girl Scouts and Leukemia/Lymphoma organizations. At Berkeley, we also look for other opportunities to give back to the community, especially the STEM one. For academic and professional development, we have study groups, resume/interview tips, career panels, and tech talks. For more information, visit https://www.calphirho.com/ or our national website http://www.phisigmarho.org/.
Categories: CalGreeks Multicultural Greek Council (MCGC) Fraternities & Sororities
Summary: Phi Sigma Rho is a social sorority for women in engineering and engineering technologies.

Name: Phil And Sophie's Club at Berkeley
Description: ‚ÄúThe unexamined life is not worth living. ‚Äù Phil & Sophie‚Äôs Club aims to be the home of philosophy lovers who pursue to live examined lives. We would love to learn from both western and eastern thought traditions, hoping it would inspire reflections on our past and future. ‚ÄúPhilosophers have always been trying to interpret the world; the point, however, is to change it. ‚Äù We aim to open the door towards wisdom for young students, who are the future of the world. By pondering the constant meanings of those philosophical questions which have existed from the beginning of human civilization, it should be believed that the thoughts produced by the young minds have the power to lead the world forward. ‚ÄúLike bone cut, like horn polished; like jade carved, like stone ground. ‚Äù We aim to provide such a stable platform, not only for students to ‚Äúcut and polish‚Äù themselves by questioning their ideas in deep reflections, but also for them to ‚Äúcarve and ground‚Äù themselves by proposing and engaging in genuine philosophical discussions. Discussions with other different minds is important because it would spark new thoughts as well as motivate us to think about the similarities behind all the differences. We hope that the Phil & Sophie‚Äôs Club will become the spiritual home of all those seeking wisdom, and together we will form meaningful bonds of thought, which will change the world.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups
Summary: We hope that the Phil and Sophie‚Äôs Club will become the spiritual home of all those seeking wisdom, and together we will form meaningful bonds of thought, which will change the world.

Name: Philosophy Forum üíô
Description: Join us on Thursdays from 6:00‚Äì8:00 PM in the Howison Library (located on the 3rd floor of Philosophy Hall). Philosophy Forum fosters a lively and active community of Berkeley undergraduates brought together by our interest in and love of philosophy, while encouraging a campus-wide interest in philosophical inquiry. At our weekly meetings, professors, graduate students, and undergrads present lectures on their philosophical work, followed by an open period of Q&A discussion. We also hold socials throughout the semester, and informal dinners after each weekly meeting, where students can connect and build community in a relaxed setting. There are no attendance requirements for members‚Äîplease drop in whenever you're interested and available. We look forward to seeing you there!
Categories: Academic Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Join us Thursdays 6‚Äì8 PM at Howison Library! Phil Forum fosters a lively and active community of undergraduates brought together by our interest in philosophy. Make friends, watch interesting presentations, and discuss a variety of philosophical topics!

Name: Phoenix Consulting Group
Description: Phoenix Consulting Group is UC Berkeley‚Äôs premier healthcare consulting organization. We‚Äôre a diverse community of scientists, engineers, business leaders, and policymakers that hope to change the world through our passion for healthcare. We develop dynamic business strategies to help companies solve problems, working with large companies like Abbott and Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in addition to startups like Oxbridge Clinical and GambitBio. We have also built our own healthcare startup accelerator, Health Engine. Come to our events to learn more about our community!
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Phoenix Consulting Group is a UC Berkeley management consulting group focused primarily on businesses and startups in the pharmaceutical, medical, and healthcare industries providing strategic and technical consulting opportunities.

Name: Phoenix Symphony at Berkeley
Description: Phoenix Symphony at Berkeley is a music group that blends East Asian traditional instruments with western and other instruments, to lead people to explore East Asian culture and exchange diverse minds through the enchantment of music. https://www.tiktok.com/@phx.symphony
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Phoenix Symphony at Berkeley dedicates to the spread of East Asian traditional music, cooperation with multicultural arts, and promotion of East Asian culture.

Name: PhotoCubs üíô
Description: We are the joint student chapter of the SPIE (International Society for Optical Engineering), Optica (formerly, Optical Society of America), and the IEEE Photonics Society at the University of California, Berkeley. The club is operated by students who are dedicated to advancing the field of optics. Our members are affiliated with several departments on campus including Electrical Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, Astronomy, Vision Science and Optometry. We are commited to promoting the optics community on campus. To become involved in PhotoBears, attend a PhotoBears meeting or contact the current members. (formerly known as Photobears)
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: PhotoCubs is the joint student chapter of the SPIE (International Society for Optical Engineering), Optica (formerly, Optical Society of America), and IPS (IEEE Photonics Society) at the University of California Berkeley.

Description: Check out our website: http://www.berkeleypse.org Check out our facebook: https://www.fb.com/berkeleyPSE/ At Pi Sigma Epsilon, we pride ourselves in our professionalism, close-knit community, leadership opportunities, and diversity. Our brothers grow together through sales & marketing projects, case competitions, professional development workshops, internal events and more. We‚Äôre here to help you succeed at Cal and beyond.

Summary: PI SIGMA EPSILON The only co-ed marketing, sales, and management business fraternity on campus.

Description: Pi Tau Sigma is the national Mechanical Engineering Honors Society. We pride ourselves in connecting our members with faculty, industrial contacts, and other ME students as well as helping out in the community, all the while having fun.

Description: Pickleball at Berkeley is a competitive pickleball team. We hope to play recreationally, practice, and challenge other college pickleball clubs.

Summary: Pickleball at Berkeley aims to create a inclusive space for anyone interested in pickleball. We will promote camaraderie and an active lifestyle with recreational practices, friendly tournaments, and competitions with other college pickleball clubs.

Name: Pilipino American Alliance üíô
Description: Our Mission Statement: "In the ongoing attempt to serve and interact with the Pilipinx community, the Pilipinx American Alliance stands to promote a network of social support through the encouragement of political action, academic excellence, and cultural awareness while celebrating cultural diversity." Our website is currently under construction. For now, you can find a central hub to all of our ongoing events and applications at the link below! linktr.ee/ucbpaa In the mean time, please email any questions to paa.chair@gmail.com and follow our social media handles below to stay updated on our organization and how to get involved! Hope to see you around :)
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Undergraduate Organizations, Cultural & Identity/Cultural & Ethnic Student Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, ABSA - Budgeted over $7500 Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category

Name: Pilipino American Law Society üíô
Description: The Pilipino American Law Society (PALS) at Berkeley Law seeks to create a supportive community for Filipino American students during their time in law school. PALS facilitates this through mentorship, social events, and professional networking. PALS welcomes all individuals, regardless of ethnic background.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Pilipino American Law Society (Berkeley Law) hopes to encourage the pursuit of a legal profession and create a supportive community with an emphasis on Pilipino American students by facilitating discourse and networking.

Name: Pilipino Association for Health Careers üíô
Description: The Pilipino Association for Health Careers started through a group of students who recognized the need for a support system among Cal pre-health students. PAHC aims to promote current health issues in and around the Pilipino community, as well as extended communities. We develop a structure of dedicated students to integrate their knowledge, experience, and skills to seek information on various health issues and careers. PAHC provides information and services to aid the Pilipino community especially and, in addition, to all who are health conscious both academically and individually. Mission: To serve as a support group for those who are interested in health careers and to educate the community of health-related issues relative to Pilipinos and their extended communities.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Pilipino Association for Health Careers started by a group of students who recognized the need for a support system among Cal pre-health students. PAHC aims to promote current health issues relative to Pilipinos and their extended communities.

Name: Pilipino Basketball Association
Description: The Pilipinx Basketball Association, more canonically known as PBA, is committed to providing a relaxed environment for any and all Pil-identifying students who appreciate the passion and camaraderie that comes with playing organized sports. Our mission is to develop meaningful relationships rooted in the sport, and we accomplish this by hosting weekly open-gym sessions, semesterly tournaments, Intramural Sport participation, and other seasonal events.
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The Pilipinx Basketball Association, is committed to providing a relaxed environment for any and all Pil-identifying students who appreciate the passion and camaraderie that comes with playing organized sports.

Name: Pilipinx Academic Student Services
Description: Pilipinx Academic Student Services is an entirely student-run organization formed in 1985 to address the educational concerns of Pilipinx students in pursuit of higher education. PASS attempts to remedy the lack of representation among the University's student population with respect to the growing Pilipinx population of California. The organization focuses primarily on increasing the educational opportunities available to these students through the implementation of various informational resources, support, and referral services. We provide programs targeted specifically toward the recruitment of high school and community college students, as well as programs for the retention of the University's registered students. PASS endeavors to maintain its commitment to the surrounding communities and to the University through efforts to preserve educational interest.
Categories: RRC - Recruitment & Retention Center, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Committed to the Recruitment and Retention of Pilipinxs into Higher Education, Since 1985.

Name: Pilipinx Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers
Description: Our Mission: Established in 1988, the Pilipinx Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers (PASAE) serves as a close-knit support group for students in the technical fields, providing student members a space for social interaction, cultural understanding, professional guidance, and academic support. What We Do: PASAE provides a variety of events and resources for our members. We provide a social and cultural space for students in the technical fields to cultivate connections with students of similar backgrounds and de-stress through events like PAS‚ÄôGlade and Chill and PASAE‚Äôce Skating. Professionally and academically, we provide workshops and access to our network of alumni working in industry through events like our Alumni Mixer and Gilead Panel. Reach out to us via Instagram or email, and we hope to see you soon :)
Categories: Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated Hearst Storage
Summary: Established in 1988, the Pilipinx Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers (PASAE) serves as a close-knit support group for students in the technical fields, providing student members a space for professional, social and cultural connections.

Name: Pioneers in Engineering üíô
Description: PiE's mission is to create engaging STEM experiences that provide students in the Bay Area with the tools, resources, guidance and inspiration to build their own future. Staff members design, build and lead a variety of programs and lessons in a project-based environment, with the goal of making things that can also inspire and educate others. We stress mentorship and "learning by doing," which is why our flagship program is a high school robotics competition that we design, produce and host every year. We also develop hands-on lessons to bring directly to classrooms, and workshops for DIY projects or basic technical software That's why we design, produce, and organize the competition in-house for about 20 high school teams in our community. Our vision is that everyone involved -- high school students and college mentors and staff -- have the opportunity to be both students and teachers to each other. All our STEM programs create a learning community where students have role models and resources going into the future -- and they in turn can 'pay it forward' by perpetuating this kind of philosophy.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: PiE creates engaging STEM experiences for students in the Bay Area. Design, build and lead: produce a high school robotics competition, create hands-on lessons, and lead workshops that enable students to learn while building and having fun.

Name: Plaintiffs' Law Association üíô
Description: The Plaintiffs‚Äô Law Association (PLA) is a student organization at Berkeley Law and an official AAJ* chapter dedicated to cultivating future plaintiff-side attorneys. We are a comprehensive resource for students interested in plaintiff-side careers‚Äìproviding community support, professional guidance, and exposure to a variety of practice areas. PLA hosts speaker events with prominent practitioners, connects students to mentors, and shares employment opportunities with current and former members. We are also committed to fostering community. We provide a space for students to support and encourage each other from day one, and engage with a robust alumni network. More broadly, we want to dispel the myth that the only career opportunities for law students are in BigLaw, government, and the nonprofit sector. A career as a plaintiff-side lawyer is fulfilling, financially rewarding, and impactful. We are also dedicated to making the profession accessible to underrepresented groups. That is why diversifying the plaintiffs‚Äô bar is a priority for PLA. Overall, the Plaintiffs‚Äô Law Association aims to equip members with the tools, knowledge, and relationships they need to succeed as future plaintiff-side advocates. *The American Association for Justice is the largest nonprofit organization for plaintiffs‚Äô lawyers in the United States.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: PLA is dedicated to cultivating future plaintiff-side attorneys. We are a comprehensive resource for students interested in plaintiff-side careers‚Äìproviding community support, professional guidance, and exposure to a variety of practice areas.

Name: Planning Students Association
Description: Who are my Planning Students Association (PSA) Leaders? Organizational Positions - January 2025 to December 2025 Co-Presidents, Lisa Tran and Isabelle Hernandez This person organizes the PSA meetings and makes sure that other officers and event organizers have what they need to get their jobs done. The president also meets regularly with the Department Chair and acts as a primary contact between the students and the Department on all issues including, but not limited to, course offerings, departmental operations and the PDST (also/formerly known as the PDF). Vice President/Treasurer - Shubhra Sharma This person works closely with the President to keep the PSA humming through joint agenda-writing and acting as a sounding board. The officeholder also tracks the finances of the PSA, helps other officers and event organizers submit funding and reimbursement requests, and prepares funding applications to the Graduate Assembly. Social Chairs - Marguerite Spaethling and Carson Mays This person is responsible for planning student involvement in the Holiday Party in the fall and the Planner Prom in the spring. The Social Chair helps out organizers of other events to manage logistics and get volunteers. The Social Chair also organizes and facilitates small, informal lunch discussions and happy hours with students and faculty members. GTKY get-togethers provide an opportunity for students and faculty to meet to discuss topics such as: planning as a career, advice for budding planners, personal experiences in the planning field, etc. Major responsibilities include: contacting professors to set up times/dates and sending out lunch announcements to the MCP current students email list. Alumni Liaison - Deni Arellano and Shruti Venkatnarayan This person works with departmental faculty, staff and students to plan for the development of a robust alumni network. This will include facilitation of creating an alumni database and drafting of an overall plan for alumni engagement. The liaison will be the student point of contact for a large alumni event, a facilitator of smaller events, and responsible for continued upkeep of the network. Communications Chair - Jon Atkins This position oversees the Google group for incoming students, the MCP current students email list and the Planning-Announce email list. Recruitment Chair - Alex Kwong and Nishtha Kashyap This position helps the Department plan and recruit student volunteers for events targeted at prospective and incoming students, serving as a critical point of contact during this annual process. The team will work with the admissions team, keep current students informed of developments, and get to know the Department and College staff. American Planning Association (APA) Rep - Samantha Wu Rose This position sits on the board of the Northern California APA section, makes sure the PSA is meeting its requirements as an official student organization, and keeps the students informed of APA events. CED Interdepartmental Group (CEDIG) Rep - Yutong Li and Varun Pais This position for DCRP stands as part of a college-wide effort to bring the four different departments within the CED out of their silos. In cooperation with the CED Graduate Student Council, the CEDIG representative advocates for and facilitates interdepartmental collaboration through workshops, seminars, peer reviews, social events, etc. These events, whether academic or social, create spaces where CED students can come together to form a stronger sense of community. MCP Student-Faculty Co-Chairs - Noelle Suh and Andrea Martinez Along with the President, this position is a primary contact between the students and the Department. The job entails attending faculty meetings and curriculum-related meetings where they represent student views and takes minutes to keep students informed. The representative should solicit broad student feedback on items needing student input. This representative is informed of all faculty meetings, regular and ad hoc, and should attend all possible. Graduate Assembly (GA) Reps - Sam Arnett and Noelle Suh The GA Rep is required to attend at one GA-wide meeting per month (Thursdays at 6pm, usually 3-4 hours) as well as participate in one committee, which typically meet 1-2 times per month. Committees include external affairs (UC lobbying, etc), environmental, etc. The GA is responsible for funding for graduate organizations (like the PSA) and is the representative for graduate student interests within and outside of the University. UAW ‚Äì Union Liaison - Moneesha Kalamder By attending monthly UAW membership meetings, the PSA Union Liaison acts as a representative of DCRP to UAW meetings and will report back on important information pertinent to DCRP graduate students. This will provide for open communication between DCRP students and the Union, ensuring PSA members are informed about labor and equity issues on campus. Mutual Aid Chair - Julian Rocha This person works closely with CEDSOC and other CED student organizations to build and maintain a new program: a CED-wide lending library and mutual aid system. This program, launching in Spring 2022, will offer direct support to students with financial need, a library of reusable materials and shared space for community building activities. Lounge Ambassador - Andrea Torres This position is responsible for overseeing and maintaining the MCP student lounge, which includes orienting new students to the space, arranging locker distribution, organizing the cleaning schedule, and advocating for the lounge when necessary. Swag Chair(s) - Karna Goswami and Jamie Noh This position is responsible for designing, selling and delivering DCRP swag (clothing, mugs, tote bags, etc.) to DCRP students. Funds raised from sales go back to the PSA general budget to support events. MCP Archivist Co-Chairs - Ben Biniaz and Mei Mei Collins This position is responsible for compiling records in the MCP program to facilitate information sharing across cohorts, particularly related to maintaining institutional memory regarding coursework. Records may include course syllabi, student-solicited course information, lists of courses taken outside of the department, and capstones/theses. This also includes the maintenance of a job opportunities and funding database, and coordination with the alumni liaisons regarding the alumni database. As a new position, the major responsibilities include the initial development of database structures to maintain archives in the future.
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: The Planning Students Association (PSA) works with graduate students, faculty, and staff in the Department of City and Regional Planning (DCRP) to support career advancement; organize social events; and represent graduate interests within the department.

Name: Plant & Microbial Biology Graduate Student Group
Categories: Graduate Student Organizations
Summary: We are the representative body of the graduate students of Plant & Microbial Biology! We serve as the platform for department-wide updates on policy, Graduate Assembly meetings, faculty meetings, upcoming events, and recruitment, among other activities.

Name: Plant Futures at Berkeley üíô
Description: Increasingly, young adults are recognizing the broad based potential of a plant-centric food system to (i) address the climate crisis directly and urgently, (ii) prevent and heal diet-related chronic diseases, and (iii) ease nutrition insecurity. Plant Futures Initiative aims to meet students at an opportune moment in their lives, helping them to become enlightened eaters and advocates for positive food systems transformation, and bridging education, advocacy, and right livelihood.
Categories: Environmental & Sustainability Student Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Plant Futures is focused on accelerating the transition to plant-based food systems at the intersection of social justice, public health, and environmental sustainability by building a community around plant-based eating.

Name: PlexTech
Description: Our club's main operation is to provide software development consulting services to a broad spectrum of companies, including Atlassian, Zendesk, 100Thieves, and more. With a team of 5-6 other members, you can build a complete, high-impact product for clients in the course of a semester. We also provide a rigorous full-stack web development curriculum to new members; this track will equip you with the skills necessary to excel in software engineering positions, including but not limited to: React, Flask, MongoDB, and Figma. PlexTech's 50+ members are very tight-knit and we hold social events very frequently, ranging from chill hangouts to trips to Hawaii.
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: PlexTech abides by one crucial mission: to equip motivated, ambitious, and eager students with the necessary technical skills to advance the modern technological landscape.

Name: Pointe of Berkeley üíô
Description: Pointe of Berkeley provides ballet technique training for students of all levels and identities who are interested in building a strong dance foundation without the cost. We strive to create a welcoming community that highlights and builds upon our dancers' strengths. All classes are free, drop-in, and open to everyone. We look forward to dancing with you! REGISTER FOR FALL 2025 CLASSES HERE! FIND ALL IMPORTANT INFORMATION HERE!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: UC Berkeley's ballet club that offers free drop-in ballet classes. Inclusive to all dance abilities, genders, and backgrounds!

Name: Pokemon Club at Berkeley üíô
Description: Interested in Pok√©mon? The Pok√©mon Club at Cal strives to unite Pok√©mon fans in and around Berkeley. What you can expect from the club: Welcoming atmosphere for casual trading and battling Official console-game tournaments, including: within the club, intercollegiate, and at regional championships Online simulator tournaments: no preparation necessary! Metagame discussion Non-game-related activities: movies, trivia, etc. And more! Sound good? For information on meetings and events, please ask to be added to our mailing list by emailing pokemonclubcal@gmail.com, or join our discord server at https://discord.gg/jXxpc65XSt
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: Pok√©mon Club at Cal connects all Pok√©mon enthusiasts interested in battling, trading, or just meeting fellow Pok√©mon lovers.

Name: Poker at Berkeley
Description: Poker at Berkeley intends to bring the Poker community at Berkeley together through events, socials, and providing educational resources. Players of all skill levels are encouraged to get involved! Members of Poker at Berkeley also teach the Introduction to Poker Decal, Stat 198. The Decal intends to take students from having little to no experience to being able to win against their friends and at most low stake games. The course focuses on understanding the probabilistic and heuristic aspects of playing effective poker. The club serves a separate purpose from the Decal, with the Decal being intended to educate newer players while Poker at Berkeley primarily focuses on holding events. Poker at Berkeley hopes to build a strong community of players on campus through a variety of offerings to help students of all backgrounds get involved. Poker at Berkeley understands the ethical implications of gambling. At no point during any event affiliated with Poker at Berkeley will students be required or encouraged to wager real money. Poker at Berkeley further intends to provide resources for students concerned about their relationship with gambling. Some offerings that we plan to continue building out include: Semesterly large-scale multi-day poker tournaments open to members Smaller-scale club socials and sponsored events A vibrant online community via our Discord server Access to club poker solver software and computing resources Club coaching, study groups, and hand reviews to improve at the game
Categories: Recreational Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: Poker at Berkeley intends to bring the Poker community at Berkeley together through events, socials, and providing educational resources. Players of all skill levels are encouraged to get involved!

Name: Policy Debate (Cal Debate)
Description: Policy Debate (Cal Debate) The Policy Debate team teaches critical thinking skills and persuasive communication techniques to an elite group of students who compete at a national level. Our program trains students to debate diverse issues such as collective bargaining rights, clean energy policies, nuclear force postures, and antitrust law. Cal Debate is one of the most successful intercollegiate debate teams in the country; since 2000, Cal Debate has won the prestigious Copeland award for the number one ranked team in the nation three times, and has had a team in the Octafinals or farther of the National Debate Tournament for 11 of those years.Per the University, the Policy Debate team is also known as Cal Debate.
Categories: OASIS Sponsored Organization, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The Policy Debate Team at Berkeley (Cal Debate)

Name: Polish Club of Berkeley üíô
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Cultural & Identity/International Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The purpose of the PCB is to celebrate and promote Polish culture at UC Berkeley.

Name: Political Computer Science
Description: UC Berkeley is famous for being on the cutting edge of both technology and social justice‚Äì PCS brings these two worlds together into a single community. Members are united by a common interest in the intersection of technology and society, which they explore through research projects, discussions, debates, workshops, and articles. The ideal PCS applicant is passionate about this intersection, interested in discussing political and socio-technical topics with others who may have different ideas, and wants to join a small but dynamic community of creative nerds. Note: you do not need to have any particular skills or experiences to apply. We are proud to say that our diverse membership includes students in 30+ majors, from several different continents, who are pursuing transfer, PhD, and Masters paths at Berkeley. Our application is currently closed but feel free to apply in the Spring!
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Engineering/Computer Science Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: We are a group of students interested in the intersection of politics and technology. Our club hosts a variety of projects, discussions, and socials (as well as a DeCal!) for those who share this same interest!

Name: Power of a Princess
Description: Power of a Princess ("POP") is a student-run organization that aims to spread magic to children in need around the Bay area and beyond. Our team of princes, princesses, superheroes, and Jedi provides storytelling, crafts, sing-alongs, Q&As with characters, and much more to bring a magical experience to children in hospitals, low-income schools, or other in need groups free of charge. Character interactions give sick or underserved children a chance to forget their worries and focus on simply being a kid. Alongside sparking joy in children around the Bay Area, Power of a Princess brings our members together into a tight-knit community of Berkeley students that truly feels like a family. Our Ohana unites under our love of Disney and our desire to help kids in need. To join our club, you do not have to have a background in acting or the arts, although it is preferred, and you do not have to look a certain way (no one looks like the unrealistic body standards of Disney princesses)‚Äì‚Äìwe are dedicated to bringing a diverse, kind group of people together to do what they are passionate about! We will provide you with all necessary gear (i.e. wigs, costumes, etc.) to become your character at no cost. We hope you will join our Ohana and look forward to reading your applications. Hakuna Matata! Learn more about our organization here and find links to our application: linktr.ee/powerofaprincess
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Initiated Service Groups, Performing Arts Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, ABSA-Allocated ESH Storage
Summary: Power of a Princess is a student-run organization that transforms volunteers into children‚Äôs characters to visit hospitals, children‚Äôs organizations, low-income schools, and any other in need groups free of charge.

Name: POWER-Bay Area: Physical science Opportunities for Women in Education and Research
Categories: Service Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: POWER-Bay Area is a mentoring program and workshop series for Bay Area community college students and UC Berkeley transfer students interested in the physical sciences.

Name: Pre-Medical Honor Society
Description: The UC Berkeley Pre-Medical Honor Society (PMHS) is an organization for hopeful pre-meds and aspiring physicians to meet health care professionals, hear from medical school representatives from across the country, talk to professors and distinguished faculty, gain unique clinical experience, and attend workshops focused on the successful navigation of the Berkeley pre-med scene. Students are invited to join our open and positive community where people can learn from their peers and share helpful advice. The following are a few benefits of membership: - Medical school information sessions hosted by medical schools throughout the country - Opportunities to shadow physicians in the Bay Area in various specialties - Professor luncheons with club sponsors and other distinguished faculty members - Informational sessions regarding the MCAT, resumes, interviews, and the application process - Hefty discounts off BluePrint and Kaplan MCAT courses - Opportunities to participate in a variety of club-sponsored community service activities - Advice from past and present medical school applicants - Medical school tours - Mentorship from senior PMHS members and alumni Please visit https://pmhs.berkeley.edu/ for more information. If you are a prospective member, please complete this form: https://forms.gle/vhKmCezSBKskGtQY7
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: To provide service for pre-medical students at Berkeley, with the specific purpose of recognizing distinguished pre-medical students who have proven themselves exceptional in the academic and campus community.

Name: Pre-Nursing Society üíô
Description: Pre-Nursing Society at Cal seeks to support all UC Berkeley Pre-Nursing students both academically and socially by providing opportunities to learn about nursing specialties, academic and career pathways, and nursing schools through guest speakers and visits to various nursing schools in the Bay Area. Pre-Nursing Society offers students a network of peers with shared motivations and provides solutions to pre-nursing challenges through social support and educational interaction. The goal of PNS is to raise student awareness and establish nursing as a critical and rewarding occupation in health care. Learn more at www.berkeleypns.weebly.com
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: An organization to support UC Berkeley Pre-Nursing students academically and socially with opportunities to learn more about the career and to network them with peers. PNS hopes to raise student awareness and establish nursing as a rewarding occupation.

Name: Pre-PA Club at Berkeley üíô
Description: The Pre-PA Club is UC Berkeley's only club geared specifically toward the Physician Assistant path! The Pre-PA Club will offer a multitude of guest speakers from the PA field, numerous workshops to help in every aspect of the PA school application, volunteer opportunities and social events to connect with other Pre-PA students. All are welcome!
Categories: Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: By providing educational tools, Pre-PA school resources, and a space to meet other Pre-PA students, the Pre-PA Club at Berkeley aims to create a community at Cal for all students who are considering pursuing a career as a Physician Assistant.

Name: Pre-Pharmacy Informational, Learning and Leadership Society
Description: The Pre-Pharmacy Informational Learning and Leadership Society (PILLS) is dedicated to assisting students interested in the field of pharmacy. As the main pre-pharmacy organization on campus, PILLS was founded in response to the lack of support and resources available to students interested in pursuing a PharmD. PILLS provides Cal Students with the information and support needed to pursue pharmacy as a career and to apply to pharmacy school. PILLS has created a variety of programs aimed at educating our fellow Cal students about the field of pharmacy. Our goal is to provide information about pharmacy and related fields, as well as opportunities to explore the field, and to guide students through the transition from UC Berkeley to pharmacy school. ** PILLS is not exclusively for pre-pharmacy students. All students regardless of if they are planning to attend pharmacy school or if they are still undecided about the field, are welcome at all events.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations, Blue Heart Initiative Category
Summary: The Pre-Pharmacy Informational Learning and Leadership Society (PILLS) is the main pre-pharmacy organization on campus and is dedicated to assisting students interested in the field of pharmacy. Students pursuing other pre-health careers are welcomed too

Name: PreDental Society
Description: Our Mission The Pre-Dental Society is the only dental oriented and registered student organization of University of California, Berkeley. We are dedicated to improving the oral health of the surrounding communities while providing professional development for our members through initiatives in education, advocacy, and ethical professional standards. Our Commitment to Our Members Cal PDS supports fellow students by providing a forum to address their concerns regarding preparation for dental school and the field of dentistry. We make an effort to assist our members in becoming competitive dental school applicants through educational opportunities, community service, and exposure to the dental field. Past programs sponsored by PDS include conferences, dental professional presentations, dental school tours, socials, shadowing opportunities, practice DATs resources, dental student Q-and-A panels, in addition to a growing range of other events. Our Commitment to Our Community Cal PDS members are greatly encouraged to participate in community service activities offered. Many of our community projects are aimed at advocating dental education as well as oral and general health in underprivileged school-aged communities around the Bay Area. Our biggest project is the Dental Education Outreach Program (DEOP), with which we strive to make a lasting difference in the community through education of our youth.
Categories: ASUC Sponsored 2025-26-Student Activity Groups, Professional Student Organizations, Undergraduate Organizations
Summary: The Pre-Dental Society is a registered student organization of University of California, Berkeley. We are dedicated to improving the oral health of the surrounding communities while providing professional development for our members through initiatives.

Name: Pride Business Association
Description: PBA is the only LGBTQ+ business organization based at Haas, proudly sponsored by the Haas School of Business alongside corporate partners like EY, PwC, Vanguard, and Intuit. While rooted in Haas, we are open to all UC Berkeley students. We host professional networking events and social gatherings to connect queer students with each other and with leading firms.
Categories: Undergraduate Organizations, LGBTQ+ Student Organizations
Summary: Our mission is to empower LGBTQ+ undergraduate business students by fostering an inclusive community, providing professional development opportunities, and promoting leadership and advocacy within the Berkeley community and broader business world.
